en: How does your New Partner Programme works?.

ibo: Ọ sịrị na a tụpụtala atụmatụ ga-agbazi ịma aka site n' ịhụ maka arụmọrụ na inwe ọnụ ahịa dị írè n' ụlọ ọrụ, nakwa inyefe ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri n' aka ndị nnọrọ onwe.

en: There's a lot of talk about toilets lately.
ibo: E nwere ọtụtụ okwu banyere ụlọ mposi n' ikpeazụ a.

en: After the Obama administration told US schools to let transgender pupils use toilets matching their gender identity, everyone has an opinion about who should use which toilet.
ibo: Ka ọchịchị Obama gwasịrị ụlọakwụkwọ US ka ha hapụ ụmụ akwụkwọ e megharịrị okike ha ije mposi n' ụlọ mposi gosiri okike ha, onyeisi ọbụla nwere echiche banyere ụlọ mposi nke onye ga-eje na ya.

en: Meanwhile in the interest of public service, I'd also like to encourage a debate about 'how' toilets are used.
ibo: Ugbua n' ihi ọdịmma nke ọrụ ọha, m ga-achọkwa ịkwado arụmụka maka ojiji ụlọ mposi.

en: I encourage male readers to pay particular attention because I'm asking you to stop peeing on rather than in the toilet.
ibo: Ana m agba ndị ụmụ nwoke na-agụ ihe ka tinye uche pụrụ iche makana ana m agwa ha ka ha kwụsị ịnyụ mamịrị n' elu kama n' ime ụlọ mposi.

en: Were an alien species to conduct an in-depth study of the human species, they would say of Nigerian men – a well-adapted group, intellectually vigorous, entrepreneurial and charming, but with disgraceful toilet manners.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ụmụ ndị ọbịa eme nchọcha miri emi banyere mmadụ, ha ga-ekwu banyere ụmụ nwoke Naijiria---Òtù, sịrị ike ọgụgụ isi,

en: Of course there would be exceptions and some women would be similarly judged.
ibo: N' ezie e nwere ndị iche mana a ga-ekpe ụfọdụ ụmụ nwaanyị ikpe.

en: But the good number of male 'splashers' amidst us would bring the score down.
ibo: Mana ọtụtụ ụmụ nwoke n' ime anyị g-ebutu ọnụ ọgụgụ ahụ.

en: Since aliens may not land on earth in my lifetime, I conducted my own in-depth study about this corrosive issue.
ibo: Kemgbe ndị ọbịa enweghi ike ịbịa n' ụwa na ndụ m, emere m nchọcha nke m banyere okwu a.

en: The study did not (thankfully) involve visits to the Gents.
ibo: Nchọcha a (n' inye ekele) agụnyeghi nleta ụlọ mposi.

en: Rather it was undertaken (reluctantly) in the one given place where all genders share toilets, namely on airplanes.
ibo: Kama e mere (n' ejighị obi) n' otu ebe okike niile na-ejekete mposi, ya bụ ụgbọelu.

en: The study confirmed that using the shared toilets on flights to and from Nigeria is an extraordinarily unpleasant experience.
ibo: Nchọcha a gosiri na ijeko mposi n' ụgbọelu site Naijiria nakwa ịlaghachi Naijiria bụ ahụmihe adịghị ụtọ dị egwu.

en: In fact, the situation is such that on my next Nigeria bound flight I will bring a raincoat, rubber gloves and Wellies.
ibo: N' ezie, ọnọdụ a bụ nke na n' oge ọzọ m ga-aba ụgbọelu ịga Naijiria m ga-eweta 'raincoat', 'rubber gloves' na 'wellies. '

en: Jokes aside, toilet use is in truth a political issue.
ibo: Egwuregwu laa azụ, ojiji ụlọ mposi bụ n' ezie okwu ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị.

en: Fela Anikulapo-Kuti himself often connected the scatological with the political.
ibo: Fela Anikulapo-Kuti n' onwe ya mgbe ụfọdụ jikọrọ

en: Though judging by the lines, 'Long time ago African man no dey carry shit, we dey shit inside big big hole, na European man teach us to carry shit', Fela may have disagreed with me on toilet matters.
ibo: N' ezie e sowe ụgbara egwu ndị a: 'Ọtụtụ oge gara aga nwoke Afrịka anaghị ebu nsị, anyị na-anyụ nsị n' ime nnukwu ọhere, ọ bụ nwoke Europe kụziri anyị ibu nsị,' Fela nwere ike ghara ikwenyere m banyere okwu mposi.

en: Because in a sense, I am indeed advocating for western toilet habits.
ibo: Makana n' otu ụzọ, ana m akwado àgwà mposi ọdịda anyanwụ.

en: (By the way, I never imagined I would combine those last three words.).
ibo: (Ka o sila dị, echeghi m na m ga-agwọkọta okwu ikpeazụ atọ ahụ ọnụ.).

en: Moghalu, then, said that developing a policy framework to include strategic objectives, policy action and strategic plan for implementation to precede reforming the transport sector.
ibo: Mọghalụ, mgbe ahụ, kwuru na imeputa nlereanya iwu ga-agunye ebumnuche dị mkpa, ọrụ iwu, na atụmatụ dị mkpa na mmejuputa iwu ga-ebu mgbanwe ngalaba njem ụzọ.

en: To be clear, had we modernized the old African way of using the toilet to contemporary society it would be better suited both for the environment and for our bodies.
ibo: Ka ọ doo anya, ọ bụrụ n' anyị gbanwee ụzọ ojiji mposi Afrịka ochie ka ọ bụrụ ụzọ nke ugbua ọ ga-aka mma nyere gburugburu anyị na ahụ anyị.

en: But I'm thankful that at least airplanes don't use the hole system, or I would need to add a diving suit to my in-flight gear.
ibo: Mana ana m enye ekele na opekata mpe ụgbọelu enweghi usoro ọghere, ma ọ bụ agara m ekwesi ịgbakwunye uwe mmapụ na ngwa njem ụgbọelu m.

en: Toilet use is not only a political matter, but also a 'geopolitical' one.
ibo: Ojiji mposi abụghị nanị okwu ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị, kama ọ bụkwa nke mpaghara.

en: I hate to admit it, but I find myself making toilet habit comparisons between countries.
ibo: Akpọrọ m ikweta na ya asị, mana enwetara m onwe m n' ime ntule àgwà mposi n' etiti mba na mba.

en: It turns out that flights to and from the US are a particularly 'dry' experience.
ibo: Ọ pụtara na njem ụgbọelu jee na site US bụ ahụmihe adịghị ụtọ.

en: When you enter a toilet cubicle that has just been used by an American man, nine out of ten times it will be pristine.
ibo: Ịbanye ụlọ mposi nke nwoke Amerịka jere mposi na nso, iteghete n' ime iri ga-adị ọcha.

en: Maybe American men go to a special toilet training school? Or maybe they are just particularly good at tactical target aiming.
ibo: Ọnwere ike o bụrụ na ụmụ nwoke Amerịka na-aga ọzụzụ mposi n' ụlọakwụkwọ pụrụ iche.

en: [Sarcasm].
ibo: [Sakazim]

en: Whatever the case may be, I see no reason why my countrymen can't show equal consideration to their fellow human beings.
ibo: Ihe ọ bụla ọ bụ, ahụghị m ihe ndị obodo m agaghị eji gosi ntule ha nhanya n' ebe mmadụ ibe ha nọ.

en: Tottenham Hotspur's South Korean striker Son Heung-Min (L) and Tottenham Hotspur's Belgian defender Toby Alderweireld (R) celebrate on the pitch after the English Premier League football match between Wolverhampton Wanderers and Tottenham Hotspur at the Molineux stadium in Wolverhampton, central England on December 15, 2019.
ibo: Ònyè goolu Tottenham Hotspur bụ onye South Korea, Son Heung-min (L) na onye nchekwa Tottenham Hotspur bụ onye Belgium, Toby Alderweireld (R) nwere añụrị na piichi na ngwụsị asọmpi bọọlụ 'English Premier League' dị n' etiti Wolverhampton Wanderers na Tottenham Hotspur n' ama egwuregwu Molineux, central England na Disemba 15, 2019.

en: Tottenham won the game 2-1. Paul ELLIS / AFP.
ibo: Tottenham meriri n' egwuregwu ahụ 2-1. Paul ELLIS/AFP.

en: 'It is on this basis that we have decided to engage the civil society and all other stakeholders in the maritime subsector in the South East Geopolitical Zone.
ibo: 'Ọ bụ na ndabere a ka anyị ji kpebie inweta ọha mmadụ na ndị ngalaba mmiri na ndịda ọwụwa anyanwụ gbasara.

en: Jan Vertonghen's stoppage time header continued Tottenham's turnaround under Jose Mourinho as Spurs moved up to fifth with a 2-1 win at Wolves.
ibo: Isi nkwụsị oge Jan Vertonghen mara tụgharịrị ọnọdụ Tottenham n' okpuru Jose Mourinho dịka Spurs gbagoro n' ọkwa nke ise na mmeri 2-1 ha mmeriri Wolves.

en: Mourinho's men were largely outplayed at Molineux, but were ruthless with their chances to inflict Wolves' first league defeat in 12 games.
ibo: E meriri ndi òtù Mourinho ọfụma na Molineux, mana obi tara ha mmiri n' ohere ha nwetara iji nye Wolves mmeri izizi liigi n' egwuregwu 12.

en: Adama Traore's spectacular strike had cancelled out Lucas Moura's early opener before Vertonghen stooped to guide home Christan Eriksen's corner.
ibo: Shọtụ pụrụ iche Adama Traore gbara hichapụrụ ụzọ mmepe Lucas Moura gbara tupu Vertonghen ehulata iduga kọna Christan Eriksen ụlọ.

en: Spurs can now move into the top four before Christmas if they beat Chelsea at home next weekend.
ibo: Spurs nwere ike iso n' òtù anọ nọ n' elu tupu Kristimas ma ha merie Chelsea n' be ha na ngwụsị izu ụka ọzọ.

en: That speaks volumes for the impact Mourinho has made in less than a month in charge as Tottenham trailed Chelsea and the top four by 12 points when he was appointed.
ibo: Nke ahụ na-ada ụda banyere mmetụta Mourinho merela n' oge n' erughi otu ọnwa ọ bụrụ isi dị ka Tottenham na-eso nzọ ukwu Chelsea na òtù anọ ji akara 12 nọrọ n' elu mgbe a họpụtara ya.

en: Wolves drop to eighth as their longest unbeaten run in the top flight since 1962 came to an end, but there was little more Nuno Espirito Santo's men could have done to at least avoid defeat.
ibo: Wolves gbadara n' ọnọdụ nke asatọ dị ka ọkasị ogologo emerighi emeri ha n' arị elu elu kemgbe afọ 1962 bịara na njedebe, mana ọnwere obere ihe ọzọkwa ndị òtù Nuno Espirito Santos kara ime opekata mpe ka ha wee gbanarị mmeri.

en: After an industrious start by Wolves, it was Spurs who scored after eight minutes.
ibo: Ka Wolves jisiri ịrụsị ọrụ ike bido, ọ bụ Spurs bụ ndị nyere goolu ka nkeji eight gasịrị.

en: Son Heung-min's drive was beaten away by Rui Patricio but the ball was worked to Moura, who glided into the area before rifling in high from an angle for his third goal in seven games under Mourinho.
ibo: Rui Patricio kụdara mkpalite Son Heung-min mana a gbagara Moura, onye kpụbara n' ime

en: Wolves remained undaunted though and after Paulo Gazzaniga gathered Traore's low effort they began to create openings.
ibo: Wolves ka nọ n' obi isi ike n' ezie mana ka Paulo Gazzaniga chịkọtasịrị mbọ dị ala Traore ha bidoro kepụtawa ọhere.

en: Diogo Jota was a menace and it was from his work Raul Jimenez nearly levelled after 26 minutes but his low effort flashed wide.
ibo: Diogo Jota bụ ihe egwu mana ọ bụ ọrụ ya ka ọ fọdụrụ obere ka Raul Jimenez bibiri ka nkeji 26 gasịrị mana mbọ ya dị ala pụtara ihe.

en: Soon after Jota was denied by the recovering Davinson Sanchez after the defender's initial mistake allowed the forward through.
ibo: Ozigbo David Sanchez na-agbake agbake gọnahara Jota ka onye mgbachite mesiri mmejọ na mbido nke mere ka onye nọ n' ihu gafere.

en: Wolves continued to dominate but should have been 2-0 down nine minutes before the break.
ibo: Wolves ka na-emeri mana ọ kara ịbụ 2-0 na nkeji iteghete tupu ezumike.

en: Referee Stuart Attwell played a good advantage after Moura was fouled to allow Eric Dier forward.
ibo: Refirii Stuart Attwell nyere ezigbo uru ka a kwaturu Moura iji mee ka Eric Dier gaa ihu.

en: He played a cute one-two with Dele Alli to leave the midfielder with just Patricio to beat but his low strike hit the post.
ibo: Ya na Dele Alli gbara ezigbo pam pam pam ịhapụrụ nanị Patricio ọ nọ n' etiti ka ọ gafee mana shọtụ ọ gbasighi ike kụrụ na postu.

en: It would have been harsh on Wolves and they continued to push after the break.
ibo: Ọ kara isiri Wolves ike ma ha nọ na-agbalị ka ezumike gasịrị.

en: Jota failed to turn in Traore's cross and Gazzaniga pushed away Jimenez's shot.
ibo: Jota enwetaghị bọọlụ Traore gbanyere ya ma Gazzaniga kwapụrụ shọtụ Jimenez.

en: Spurs' defence had lived dangerously, with Vertonghen in particular struggling against the pace of Traore.
ibo: Nchekwa Spur nọ n' ihe egwu, Vertonghen n' onwe ya na-agbalị ijide nzọụkwụ Traore.

en: Wolves finally got their reward on 67 minutes.
ibo: N' ikpeazụ Wolves nwetara ụgwọ ha na nkeji 67.

en: Traore had given the visitors problems all game and he made them pay, collecting Jimenez's pass and unleashing a rocket which flew past Gazzaniga from 20 yards.
ibo: Traore enyeela ndị ọbịa nsogbu n' egwuregwu ahụ niile ma ọ mere ka ha kwụọ ụgwọ, nara paasị Jimenez ma gbapụ rọketi nke fere gafee Gazzaniga site na 20 yaadị.

en: Tottenham then never looked like restoring their lead before the late drama.
ibo: Tottenham adịghị ka ha ana eweghachite mmeri ma ncha tupu ngwụcha ejije ahụ.

en: Wolves remained the aggressors and Romain Saiss' glancing header four minutes later forced Gazzaniga into a fine stop.
ibo: Wolves bụlịrị ndị mwakpo ma isi ntachara Romain Saiss na nkeji nke anọ ka e mesiri manyere ka ọ kwụsị.

en: But Spurs silenced the hosts in the first minute of injury time when Vertonghen nodded in Eriksen's corner.
ibo: Mana Spurs mechiri ndị nnabata ọnụ na nkeji nke mbụ nke oge a gbakwunyere agbakwunye mgbe Vertonghen tara isi n' akụkụ Eriksen.

en: Manish Rohtagi is the Business Head for Simba Group of Companies.
ibo: Manish Rohtagi bụ isi azụmahịa ụlọ ọrụ Simba Group.

en: Simba Group has reiterated its commitment to empowering more Nigerians through its products and services.
ibo: Simba Group ekwuputala ọzọ nkwa o kwere inyekwu ndị Naịjirịa ikike site na ngwaahịa ya na ọrụ ya.

en: Business Head of Simba TVS, Mr Manish Rohtagi, speaks on partnership with some Microfinance Banks, while banks should lend more to customers, the business environment, economy and challenges faced by businesses operating in the country.
ibo: Onyeisi azụmahịa nke Simba TVS, Mr Manish Rohtagi, kwuru banyere ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ nke ụfọdụ Ụlọ akụ 'Microfinance,' ka ụlọ akụ ji kwesi ibinye ọtụtụ ndị ahịa ego, gburugburu azụmahịa, akụnụba na ọtụtụ ihe ịma aka azụmahịa ndị dị n' ala a na-ezute.

en: What is Simba Group all about?.
ibo: Kedụ ihe bụ Simba Group?

en: Simba Group has been in this country for over 30 years.
ibo: Simba Group anọọla n' ala a ihe karịrị afọ 30.

en: We started our business with bicycles and bicycle parts way back in 1988.
ibo: Anyị ji anyịnya ìgwè na ngwa anyịnya ìgwè bido azụmahịa anyị oge gara aga na 1988.

en: We are present in several key sectors that are critical to the development of the Nigerian economy including transport, power, IT, agriculture etc.
ibo: Anyị nọ n' ọtụtụ ngalaba bụ isi nke dị mkpa mmepe akụnụba Naijiria nke gụnyere njem, ọkụ, IT, ọrụ ugbo wdg.

en: The office you are in is the headquarters of our transport business.
ibo: Ụlọ ọrụ ị nọ n' ime ya bụ isi ụlọ ọrụ azụmahịa njem anyị.

en: We in partnership with TVS Motors India are the largest manufacturers of kekes (tricycles) in Nigeria and our two wheelers, also known colloquially as okadas, continue to reshape the Nigerian two-wheeler market.
ibo: Anyị, n' ịrụkọ ọrụ nke TVS Motors India, bụ ndị kasị emeputa keke na Naijiria ma 'two wheelers' anyị, nke a makwara dị ka ọkada, nọgide na-akpụgharị ahịa 'two wheelers' na Naijiria.

en: How does the TVS brand help the Nigerian Economy?.
ibo: Kedụ ka ụdị TVS si enyere akụnụba Naijiria aka?

en: Transport is essential to the functioning of any economy and is one of the main drivers of it.
ibo: Njem dị nnukwu mkpa nye arụmọrụ nke akụnụba ọbụla ma ọ bụ isi sekpu ntị n' akụnụba.

en: Our products address the last mile transport needs of Nigerians.
ibo: Ihe anyị mepụtara na-edozi ihe siri ike na njem okporo ụzọ na Naijiria.

en: It has been shown each tricycle or motorcycle sold creates employment for around four people as these machines not only require riders, but also mechanics, dealers and spares distributors etc.
ibo: E gosila na keke na ọgbatumtum ọbụla e rere na-enye ìhè dị ka mmadụ anọ ọrụ dịka machiini anaghị achọ so ndị na-anya ha, mana ha na-achọkwa ndị mekaniik, ndị na-ere ahịa na ndị na-ekesa akụkụ mapụtara.

en: That's even without considering our own employees.
ibo: Nke ahụ ọbụnadị bụ ileghara ndị ọrụ anyị anya.

en: Hence this industry is one of the biggest employment generators in the country.
ibo: N' ihi ya ụlọ ọrụ a bụ otu n' ime ụlọ ọrụ kasị enye ọrụ n' ala anyị.

en: Along with that we have been running several programmes that empower the youth of the country.
ibo: Ka anyị na-eme nke ahụ anyị na-emekwa ọtụtụ atụmatụ nke na-enye ndị ntorobịa nke ala anyị ikike.

en: We have worked with several government agencies including National Automotive Design Development Council (NADDAC), National Directorate of Employment (NDE) among others and trained countless people into becoming keke riders or mechanics for free.
ibo: Anyị na ọtụtụ ụlọ ọrụ gọọmenti arụkọọla ọrụ nke gụnyere 'National Automotive Design Development Council (NADDAC),' 'National Directorate of Employment (NDE)' n' ime ndị ọzọ ma zụọ ndị mmadụ dị agụta agụta ịbụ ndị na-anya Keke ma ọ bụ mekaniik n' efu.

en: We also try to partner with the State and Federal Governments so that we empower more and more youths.
ibo: Anyị na-agbalịkwa ka anyị na gọọmenti etiti na nke steeti na-arụkọ ọrụ ka wee na-enye ndị ntorobịa ikike na-aga.

en: Could you tell us a bit about Simba Group's other companies?.
ibo: I nwere ike ịgwa anyị maka ụlọ ọrụ Simba Group ndị ọzọ?

en: As I mentioned earlier, along with transportation, Simba Group is into power backup.
ibo: Dị ka m kwuru na mbụ, Simba Group nọ na-eme ndabere ike (power back up)

en: Our Luminous Inverters are the most popular inverter brand in the country, we are also heavily investing in the development of solar energy.
ibo: Invata anyị a kpọrọ 'Luminous Inverters' bụ ụdị invata a kasị mara n' ala anyị, anyị nakwa etinye ego nke ukwuu na mmepụta 'solar energy. '

en: Other companies in the group include Simba Agric where we focus on mechanisation which includes tractors and irrigation systems – both responsible for increasing agricultural productivity.
ibo: Ụlọ ọrụ ndị ọzọ so n' òtù a gụnyere Simba Agric ebe anyị na-elekwasị anya n' ìgwè ọrụ nke gụnyere traktọ na usoro ịgba mmiri---- ha abụọ na-eme ka ihe akụkụ na-emepụta

en: Simba Cycles sells bicycles, SimbaNET provides business connectivity solutions to corporates and Simba Infrastructure offers Business Communication Solutions in partnership with Avaya.
ibo: Simba Cycles na-ere anyịnya ìgwè, SimbaNET na-enye ụlọ ọrụ ọsịsa njikọta azụmahịa ma Simba Infrastructure na-eweta ọsịsa nzikọrita ozi azụmahịa site na njiko aka Avaya.

en: But basically, the focus area for me is transportation.
ibo: Mana ka ọdịna mkpa, akụkụ nlekwasị anya ma a sị m kwuo bụ njem.

en: What have been the challenges so far?.
ibo: Gịnị bụ ihe ịmaka ruo ugbua?

en: We get lots of support from government institutions but there is still a huge opportunity for public and private sector financial institutions to increase the access to cheap and collateral-free borrowing, in order to provide a major boost to the industry, and the economy at large.
ibo: Anyị nwere ọtụtụ nkwado si ewumewu gọọmenti mana a ka nwere nnukwu ọhere maka ewumewu nke ego ọha na nke nnọrọ onwe ịbawanye ọhere ibiri ego n' ụzọ dị mfe na nke enweghị ihe nnọchianya.

en: How many financial institutions have helped?.
ibo: Ewumewu nke ego ole nyerela aka?

en: There has been much progress, and impetus from the Central Bank as well.
ibo: A na-enwe nnukwu ọganihu nakwazị nkwado si 'Central Bank'

en: But there's still a long way to go before we really begin to see efficient financial models coming into play.
ibo: Mana a ka nwere ọtụtụ ihe a ga-eme eme tupu anyị ebido ịhụ nlereanya nke ego dị írè ịpụta ihe n' ezie.

en: There are few microfinance banks who have partnered with us and things are getting better.
ibo: Enwere ụlọ akụ 'microfinance' ole na ole ndị anyị na ha rụkọwarala ọrụ ma ihe na-aka mma.

en: If many more banks can come and offer people loans to buys kekes and okadas at a subsidised rate or even collateral free, then things will move much faster.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ọtụtụ ụlọaku nwere ike ịbịa ma binye ọtụtụ mmadụ ego iji gote Keke na ọkada n' ọnụ ala ma ọ bụ n' enweghi ihe nnọchianya, ihe ga-aga ọsọ ọsọ.

en: What are your projections for the nearest future?.
ibo: Kedụ ihe bụgasị ntule gị n' ọdị nso ọdịnihu.

en: We see limitless growth potential in the country and the growth quantum can be much bigger than any other countries.
ibo: Anyị na-ahụ otito ike mmepụta enweghi nsọtụ n' ala anyị ma kwantum otiti nwere ike ika nke obodo ndị ọzọ nke ukwuu.

en: Nigeria can be among the top 10 economies in the world.
ibo: Naijiria nwere ike iso n' akụnụba iri kasị elu n' ụwa niile

en: I truly believe that, and our investments in the economy certainly reflect that.
ibo: Ekwere m n' ezie nke ahụ, ma ego anyị tinyere n' akụnụba na-egosi nke ahụ n' ezie.

en: Is your organisation into any Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) activities?.
ibo: Ewumewu gị ọ na-eme emume Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)?

en: CSR has always been integral to the Simba Group.
ibo: CSR bụ akụkụ ahụ Simba Group kemgbe.

en: As part of our group philosophy of empowerment, even our CSR programmes follow the same ideology.
ibo: Dị ka fịlọsọfị ikike òtù anyị, ọbụnadị amụma CSR anyị na-eso otu echiche.

en: At the heart of our offering is our emphasis on training- something that we provide free of charge to mechanics and engineers who aspire to be mini-entrepreneurs or gainfully employed in the industries we represent.
ibo: Isi onyinye anyị bụ nkwụsị ike anyị banyere ọzụzụ----- ihe na-enye ndị mekaniik na injinia ndị chọrọ ịbụ ọbere enteprịnịọ ma ọ bụ inwe ọrụ na-akwụ ezigbo ụgwọ n' ụlọ ọrụ anyị na-anọchi anya ya n' efu.

en: We have intervened in times of national disaster, such as our actions and contributions during the recent Kano floods, and have been praised for our contributions to the victims of that terrible atrocity.
ibo: Anyị etinyela aka n' oge ọdachi nke obodo, dị ka omume anyị na ụtụ anyị otuto mmiri nke Kano na nso a, ma e tokwala anyị maka ụtụ anyị nyere ndị mmekpa ahụ dị egwu metụtara.

en: We believe in wome empowerment very strongly, and our efforts to support the development of women, have taken two forms.
ibo: Anyị kwenyesiri ike n' ikike ụmụnwaanyị, ma mgbalị anyị ịkwado mmepe ụmụnwaanyị, enwerela ụdị abụọ.

en: Firstly, we have partnered with the National Centre for Women Development (NCWD) to distribute cycles to girl students to encourage them to attend school.
ibo: Nke mbụ, anyị na 'National Centre for Women Development (NCWD) na-arụkọ ọrụ ọnụ ikere ụmụ akwụkwọ ụmụnwaanyị ịnyịnya ígwè iji gba ume ka ha na-eje akwụkwọ.

en: And secondly, we run the Queen Riders programme – a programme in which we train and certify women from under-privileged backgrounds to become Keke riders and help them on the path to self-employment by harnessing the ecosystem of financiers that we have created.
ibo: Nke abụọ, anyị na-ahụ maka atụmatụ nke Queen Riders----- atụmatụ anyị ji azụ ma na-agba akaebe ka ụmụnwaanyị si ndabere enweghi ka ọ hà ha bụrụ ndị na-anya Keke ma na-enyere ha aka n' inye onwe ha ọrụ site n' ijikọta usoro akụnụba ndị na-eweta ego anyị bidorola.

en: Celebrating its 125 years of research and impacts, the Natural Resources Institute (NRI), University of Greenwich, has acknowledged the positive impacts of a homegrown technological device developed in Nigeria on value chain development of the root and tuber crops in Africa.
ibo: N' oriri afọ 125 nke nchọcha na mmetụta ya, 'Natural Resources Institute (NRI), mahadum nke Greenwich, ekwela na mmetụta dị mma nke ngwaọrụ teknọlọjị e mepụtara na Naijiria maka' value chain development ' nke akụkụ mgbọrọgwụ na mba n' Afrịka.

en: The institute admits that smallholder farmers have benefited and would continue to improve their means of livelihood with the use of value-adding devices in the post-harvest management of their roots and tubers.
ibo: Ụlọakwụkwọ kwetara na 'smallholder' ndị ọrụ ugbo eritela uru ma ga-anọgide n' ịkwalite obibi ndụ ha site n' ojiji ngwaọrụ n' agbakwunye uru na nlekọta n' oge e wesiri ihe ubi nke mgbọrọgwụ na mba ha.

en: The device, called flash dryer, dries agricultural products such as yam, cassava, potato and other granulated food commodities for elongated shelf life, higher profitability and food security.
ibo: Ngwaọrụ a, a kpọrọ 'flash dryer', na-akpọkọ ihe akụkụ dị ka ji, akpụ, nduku na ngwongwo nri ndị ọzọ dị aja aja maka ogologo ndụ, uru dị elu na nchekwa nri.

en: The project that propped up the improvement of the design by Nobex Technologies was an initiative of Cassava: Adding Value for Africa (CAVA), facilitated by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and executed through multiple partnership.
ibo: Ọrụ ngo malitere ọganihu nke mmewe si n' aka 'Nobex technologies' bụ atụmatụ nke 'Cassava Adding Value for Africa' (CAVA), nke 'Bill and Melinda Gates' kwadoro ma mezuo ya site n' ọtụtụ nrụkọọrụọnụ.

en: One of the ways CAVA2 supports smallholders is by offering farmers more 'avenues for sales' for their cassava roots.
ibo: Otu n' ime ụzọ CAVA2 si agba 'smallholders' bụ site n' inye ndị ọrụ ugbo ọtụtụ ụzọ maka ọnụahịa mgbọrọgwụ akpụ ha.

en: To ensure a smooth flow of roots from farm to product, CAVA2 works with SMEs to expand and develop processing capacity; a key issue is the availability of quality equipment and after sales service.
ibo: Iji hụ na e nwere ezigbo nsọpụta nke mgbọrọgwụ site n' ugbo ruo n' ngwaahịa, CAVA2 ji SMEs arụ ọrụ iji mụbaa ma mepee ikike mmeputa; isiokwu bụ nnweta nke ngwá dị mma na ọrụ nsote ọnụahịa.

en: The Nigerian who developed the device in working with the institute, Mr Idowu Adeoya, fabricates equipment for drying and roasting root and tuber crops.
ibo: Onye Naijiria nke mepụtara ngwaọrụ na nrụkọ ọrụ ụlọakwụkwọ a, Maazị Idowu Adeoya, cheputara ngwá ịkpọ nkụ na ịhụ ihe akụkụ mgbọrọgwụ na mba n' ọkụ.

en: The improvement to the flash dryer, which dries agricultural products almost instantaneously, was started in 2006 when the fabricator was first contacted by specialists from the Federal University of Agriculture, Abeokuta (FUNAAB), led by the Country Manager of CAVA Nigeria, Professor Lateef Sanni, and a food processing specialist from NRI, Dr Andrew Graffham, from the Natural Resources Institute (NRI), University of Greenwich, the United Kingdom.
ibo: Ọganihu nyere 'flash dryer', nke fọrọ obere ka ọ bụrụ na ọ na-akpọkọ ihe a kọtara n' ugbo ozugbo, ka e bidoro na 2006 mgbe a kpọtụrụ fabriketọ n' izizi bụ ndị ọkachamara si 'Federal University of Agriculture, Abeokuta (FUNAAB), nke onye duru ha bụ onyeisi ọrụ nke CAVA obodo Naijiria, ọkammụta Lateef Sanni, na ọkachamara na mmepụta nri si NRI, Dr. Andrew Graffham, sị 'Natural Resources Institute', Mahadum nke Greenwich, United Kingdom.

en: As part of a FUNAAB-NRI collaboration, they had encountered a Nobex flash dryer at a factory in Akure, 300km from Lagos.
ibo: Dị ka nkewa mmekọrịta FUNAAB-NRI, ha ezutela 'Nobex flash dryer' n' ụlọ ọrụ dị n' Akure, 300km site Legosi.

en: The team was interested in collecting some data about the dryer, in order to look into its efficiency.
ibo: Òtù ọrụ ahụ nwere mmasị n' ịchịkọba data maka 'dryer' ahụ, iji leba anya n' arụmọrụ ọrụ ya.

en: Mr Adeoya welcomed Dr Graffham's interest and some months later, he was visited by NRI agricultural engineering specialist, Dr Andrew Marchant.
ibo: Maazị Adeoya nabatara mmasị Dr Graffham ma ka ọtụtụ ọnwa gasịrị, ọkachamara injinia ọrụ ugbo NRI, Dr Andrew Marchant, letara ya.

en: Improvements included reduced fuel usage from 374 to 65 litres per tonne of dried product; increased output from approximately 100kg an hour to around 330kg an hour of dried product; and increased efficiency, from 11 to 55 percent.
ibo: Ịka mma gụnyere mbeleta ojiji mmanụ ụgbọala site 374 gba 65 lita kwa tọn ihe kpọrọ nkụ e mepụtara ọhụrụ; mgbago na mmepụta site n' ihe dịka 100kg n' ime otu awa gbagoo ihe dị ka 330kg ihe kpọrọ nke e mepụtara kwa awa; mgbago n' ịrụ ọrụ nke ọma site 11 ruo 55 pesent.

en: Building on CAVA2's experience and progress with the fabricator in Nigeria, a complementary initiative is taking shape in Ghana, with the development of a new, fuel-efficient flash dryer on a smaller scale.
ibo: N' ịgbakwunye n' ahumihe CAVA2 na iji fabriketọ nweta ọganihu na Naijiria, icheputa ihe ha abụọ ga-arụkọ ọrụ na-ewere ọnọdụ na Ghana, site n' imepute 'flash dryer' ọhụrụ ji mmanụ ụgbọala arụ ọrụ nke ọma n' ọbere ọnụ Ọgụgụ.

en: The University of Lagos, UNILAG Muslim Community, has commended President Muhammadu Buhari for the merit award conferred on dedicated Nigerians who have proved to be exceptional in public service.
ibo: Ndị òtù Muslim nọ na Mahadum nke Legosi, UNILAG, etole onyeisi ala Muhammadu Buhari maka ùgwù kwesiri ekwesi o tunyere ndị Naịjirịa dị uchu ndị gosipụtara ịpụ iche n' ọrụ ọha.

en: Chairman, UNILAG Muslim Community, Prof.
ibo: Onyeisi oche ndị Muslim na UNILAG, ọkammụta

en: Lai Olurode, in a commendation letter made available to The Guardian, applauded the recognition of the Comptroller-General of Nigeria Customs Service, Hameed Ali and that of Registrar, Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB), Prof.
ibo: Lai Olurode, na leta ịja mma ọ wetara 'The Guardian, ' toro ncheta nke 'Comptroller-General of the Nigeria Customs Service,' Hameed Ali na nke 'Registrar, Joint Admission and Matriculation Board (JAMB), ọkammụta

en: Ishaq Oloyede as deserving of productivity merit award.
ibo: Ishaq Oloyede dị ka ndị irite ùgwù ịrụpụta ihe kwesiri.

en: Olurode said: 'The two institutions are truly exceptional and had really shown that we need not be consistently skeptical about our own goodness.
ibo: Olurode kwuru: 'Ewumewu abụọ pụrụ iche n' ezie ma gosikwa n' ezie na anyị ekwesighi inwe obi abụọ kwa mgbe banyere ịdị mma anyị.

en: 'Perhaps, there are thousands outside of these two individuals who can perform far better.
ibo: 'Ikekwe, e nwere puku kwuru puku n' abụghị mmadụ abụọ a ndị nwere ike ime karịa.

en: The lesson in these exceptional case studies is for other public office holders to take note of factors that had assisted the rise of these organizations to pockets of effectiveness,' he stated.
ibo: Ihe mmụta dị na nchọcha pụrụ iche a bụ ka ndị ọrụ ọha ndị ọzọ mụta ihe ndị nyerela nzukọ ndị a aka weta ịdị irè.

en: Olurode however enjoined government to ensure that other moribund institutions rise to performance.
ibo: Olurode otu ọ dị gwara gọọmenti ka ha gba mbọ hụ na ewumewu ndị ọzọ n' anaghịzị arụ ọrụ bidoro rụwa ọrụ.

en: 'At the UNILAG Muslim Community, we congratulate them for their being specially recognised by the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.
ibo: Anyị kelere ndị Muslim nọ na UNILAG makana onyeisi ala nke obodo Naijiria chetara ha n' ụzọ pụrụ iche.

en: We urge them to keep up the good job and begin to mentor others for institutional effectiveness so that their exit would not usher a reversal of successes that had been attained.
ibo: Anyị na-agba ha ume ka ha jidesie ezi ọrụ ha ike ma bido ịzụlite ndị ọzọ maka arụmọrụ ewumewu nke ga-eme na ọpụpụ agaghị eweta ntụgharị ọganihu ha nweta

en: Individuals cannot travel far but institutions can,' he said.
ibo: 'Ndị mmadụ agaghị emeto njem aka mana ewumewu ga-emenwu ya,' o kwuru.

en: He said that measures were installed to address challenges by ensuring efficiency and cost effectiveness in the industry, as well as the privatisation of the port.
ibo: Ọ sịrị na a tụpụtala atụmatụ ga-agbazi ịma aka site n' ịhụ maka arụmọrụ na inwe ọnụ ahịa dị írè n' ụlọ ọrụ, nakwa inyefe ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri n' aka ndị nnọrọ onwe.

en: Although it has been temporarily suspended by the Federal Government, there are, however, several underlining factors that still surround the operations of the Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD).
ibo: Ọ bụ ezie na gọọmenti etiti kwụsịrị ya nwa oge, e nwere, otu ọ di, ọtụtụ ihe na-egbochi arụmọrụ 'Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD).

en: 'We shall develop and enhance safety enforcement, minimise environmental damage and provide clear framework to enable investors to participate in maritime projects to improve growth and competiveness within the subsector,' Moghalu said.
ibo: 'Anyị ga-emepe ma welie mmanye nchekwa, beleta mmebi gburugburu ebe obibi ma weta amụma doro anya ga-eme ka ndị ntinye ego sonye n' ọrụ ngo mmiri ga-abawanye otito na asọmpi na ngalaba ahụ, ' Mọghalụ kwuru.'

en: Mr Ezenwa Nwagwu, Chairman , Partners for Electoral Reforms (PEF) says the jailing of former Gov. Orji Kalu of Abia was a proof that joining the ruling party with criminal case was not a guarantee against justice.
ibo: Maazị Ezenwa Nwagwụ, onyeisi, ndị otu nhazigharị ọnọdụ nhọpụta nke bekee kpọrọ 'Partners for Electoral Reforms' (PEF) kwuru na ịtụ nga onye chịburu Abia state, Gov. Ọjị Kalụ, gosiri na ibu ikpe a na-enyo enyo ohi banye otu pati ọchịchị dị n' aka agaghị eme ka e megide ike nkwụmọtọ.

en: Nwagwu in an interview with the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) on Thursday in Abuja said that the jailing has faulted the notion that once people with criminal record join the ruling party they were covered.
ibo: Nwagwụ kwuru n' ajụjụ ọnụ 'News Agency of Nigeria' gbara ya n' Abuja n' ụbọchị Tọzdee sị na ịtụ nga a emebiela nkwenye ahụ bụ na ngwa ngwa onye a na-enyo enyo banyere pati ọchịchị dị n' aka ná ha nwerela onwe ha.

en: NAN reports that Kalu was on Thursday convicted of corruption and sentenced to 12 years in prison by a Federal High Court in Lagos after he was found guilty of N7.2 billion fraud and money laundering.
ibo: 'NAN' kọwapụtara na ụlọikpeukwu dị na Legosi nọrọ n' ụbọchị Tọzdee maa Kalụ ikpe maka nrụrụaka ma tụọ ya nga afọ iri na abụọ ka ha chọpụtachara na o bu ijeri nara asaa na nde naịra abụọ (N7. 2 billion).

en: 'The judgment is a good boost for the anti-corruption fight, especially against the background of all the noise about once somebody is in the All Progressives Congress (APC) the person cannot be brought to justice.
ibo: Mkpebi a bụ ihe agbamume nyere agha megidere nrụrụaka, ọkachasị ebe o megidere mkpọtụ a na-eme na ngwa ngwa mmadụ banyere All Progressive Congress (APC) na agaghị amanwu ya ikpe.

en: READ ALSO: Orji Kalu's conviction shows Magu fears no one — Anti Corruption group
ibo: Gụ kwuo banyere: Amamikpe Ọjị Kalụ gosiri na Magu anaghị atụ egwu onye ọbụla - Anyị Corruption Group.

en: 'It is a good signal that even if you join the ruling party you will not clog the will of justice.
ibo: Ọ bụ ezigbo akara na obunagodu na l banyere pati na-achị ị gaghị emechu ikpe nkwụmọtọ ihu.

en: 'It also signals the fact that no matter how long it last, once there is the determination by the court to bring justice, justice would be done.
ibo: Ọ na-egosikwa na n' agbanyeghi oge ọ gburu, ikpe nkwụmọtọ ga-apụta ìhè ma ọ bụrụ na ụlọikpe ekpebie inye ikpe nkwụmọtọ.

en: 'We are excited about the judgment and we hope that it is also brought to bear on the Babachir Lawal's case and other cases of people with a criminal record who think that being in the ruling party is a guarantee against justice,' he said
ibo: 'Obi dị anyị ụtọ banyere mkpebi a ebe anyị na-atụ anya na ọ ga-apụtakwa ihe n' ikpe gbasara Babachir Lawal na ndị ọzọ a na-enyo enyo ohi nọ bụ ndị na-eche na ị nọ na pati nọ n' ọchịchị ga-eme ka ikpe nkwụmọtọ ghara ịpụta ihe, ' o kwuru.

en: Lassa fever kills two, infects 10 in five states
ibo: Ọrịa lassa gburu mmadụ abụọ, jide mmadụ iri na steeti ise.

en: Lassa fever has claimed two more lives in Abia and Edo states as the country approaches the peak season for outbreaks of the deadly disease.
ibo: Ọrịa lassa anapụla mmadụ abụọ ọzọ ndụ na steeti Abia na Edo dịka obodo anyị na-abanye oge nje a ji akpa ike.

en: According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Nigeria with the peak season anticipated from December through June.
ibo: N' okwu 'World Health Organisation' (WHO), a mara ọrịa lassa ka ọrịa na-apụta ihe na Naijiria ọ kacha bido Disemba ruo Juun.

en: Latest figures from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), confirmed 10 new cases of the disease in five states: five in Ondo, two in Edo, one each in Ebonyi, Bauchi and Abia. In those new cases, one person each died in Edo and Abia states.
ibo: Ọnụ Ọgụgụ e nwetara na 'Nigeria Centre for Diseased Control (NCDC) na nso a gbara aka ebe na e nwere ndị butere ọrịa a ọhụrụ na steeti ise: ise n' Ondo, abụọ n' Edo, otu n' Ebonyi, Bauchi na kwa Abia. N' ime ihe a niile otu mmadụ otu mmadụ nwụrụ na steeti Edo na Abịa.

en: Man, 26, drowns at National Stadium, Surulere
ibo: Mmiri gbagburu otu nwoke, 26, n' ama egwuregwu 'National Stadium', Surulere.

en: One Sodiq Yusuf, 26, of No. 26, Horgan Bassey Street, Surulere, has said to have drowned at National Stadium, Surulere.
ibo: Otu onye a na-akpọ Sadiq Yusuf, 26, nke bi na 26, Horgan Bassey Street, Surulere, ka e kwurur na mmiri agbagbuola n' ama egwuregwu National Stadium, Surulere.

en: The police in Lagos on Sunday said that a 26-year-old man, Sodiq Yusuf, had drowned inside the National Stadium swimming pool, Surulere.
ibo: Ndi uweojii Legosi nọrọ n' ụbọchị ụka kwuo na otu nwoke gbara afọ iri abụọ na isii, Sadiq Yusuf, ka mmiri gbagburula n' ime ọdọ mmiri a na-egwu egwu 'National Stadium', Surulere.

en: Lagos Police Public Relations Officer (PPRO), DSP Bala Elkana, said in a statement that a team of policemen was immediately mobilised to the scene.
ibo: Onye uwe ojii ntụsa ozi dị n' aka ná Legosi, DSP Bala Elkana, kwuru n' okwu ya na e zigara òtù ndị uwe ojii ebe ya bụ ihe mere n' egbughi oge ọbụla.

en: Man caught raping little girl inside bush in Abia (photos)
ibo: Nwoke e jidere ka ọ na-awakpo nwata nwaanyị n' ike n' ime ọhịa n' Abịa steeti (ihe onyonyo)

en: A man was on Wednesday caught raping little girl in a bush in Abia state, around Hightaste Road by Ibere Street of Ngwa Road. According to a Facebook user, David Osinachi Nwankwo, who shared photos from the scene of the incident, the suspect lured the girl into a nearby bush and covered her mouth with his hand to stop her from shouting for help.
ibo: Otu nwoke ka e jidere ụbọchị Wenzidee ebe ọ na-awakpo nwata nwaanyị n' ike n' ime ọhịa na mpaghara ụzọ si 'Hightaste Road' banye Ibere 'Street' nke Ngwa 'Road ' n' Abịa steeti. Dị ka otu onye ji 'Facebook' agbasa ozi, David Osinachi Nwankwo, onye tụsara foto ihe a merenụ siri kwuo, nwoke a a na-enyo enyo tụrụ nwata nwaanyị a banye n' ọhịa dị ya nso ma were aka ya mechie ya ọnụ ka ọ ghara iti mkpu enyemaka.

en: READ ALSO: Rape victim dies after being set alight on her way to court hearing
ibo: Gukwuazị: onye a wakporo n' ike nwụrụ ka a gbachara ọkụ n' ụzọ dị ka ọ na-aga ịnụ ikpe.

en: David wrote 'He was caught having carnal knowledge/raping the little girl on the picture after luring her into a nearby bush with his hand on her mouth to stop her from shouting somewhere around Hightaste Rd. by Ibere Street of Ngwa Road in Aba, Abia State today'.
ibo: David dere 'E jidere ya ka ọ na-awakpo nwata nwaanyị nọ n' ihe onyonyo ahụ n' ike ka ọ tụbachara ya n' ime ọhịa dị ya ebe o ji aka ya kpuchie ya ọnụ ka ọ ghara iti mkpu na mpaghara ebe si 'Hightaste Road' banye Ibere Street nke ụzọ Ngwa n' Abịa steeti.'

en: Nasarawa Assembly to enact law to protect women, children against violence
ibo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu nke Nasarawa ga-eme iwu ga-echekwaba ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' ihe mmekpa ahụ.

en: The Nasarawa State House of Assembly says it will enact a law that will protect women and children against violence in the interest of development of the state and the country.
ibo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu nke Nasarawa steeti sị na ya ga-eme iwu ga-echekwaba ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' ihe mmekpa ahụ maka ọdịmma nke mmepe nke steeti ahụ nakwa nke obodo anyị.

en: Alhaji Ibrahim Balarabe-Abdullahi, the Speaker of the House, stated this on Tuesday when the state women led by the State Commissioner for Women Affairs, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, led the campaign rally on violence against women to the House.
ibo: Alhaji Balarabe-Abdullahi, okwuchite ọnụ ụlọ ọmebe iwu ahụ, kwuru nke a n' ụbọchị Tuzdee mgbe ụmụnwaanyị steeti ahụ nwere nnukwu ọgbakọ banyere mmekpa ahụ nye ụmụnwaanyị nke onye du ha gaa n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu bụ Cọmishọna na-ahụ maka ụmụnwaanyị na steeti ahụ, Hajiya Halima Jabiru.

en: He said that the law if enacted would protect, respect and promote the rights of women and children in order to improve their health and their standard of living.
ibo: O kwuru na ọ bụrụ na e mebe iwu ahụ na ọ ga-echekwa, sopụrụ ma kwalite ikike dịịrị ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka iji bulite ahụ ike ha nakwa obibi ndụ ha.

en: READ ALSO: Abia Assembly moves to pass law prohibiting violence against all Persons
ibo: Gụkwuazị: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu Abịa na-eme ka ha hibe iwu megidere mmekpa ahụ nye onye ọbụla.

en: 'We will enact any relevant law that will put to end violence against women and children in the state.
ibo: 'Anyị ga-eme iwu ziri ezi nke ga-eweta mmekpa ahụ nye ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' isi njedebe na steeti a.'

en: 'We believe that the law if enacted will also protect the rights of women and children for the overall development of the state,' he said.
ibo: 'Anyị kwenyere na ọ bụrụ na e hibe iwu a na ọ gakwa echekwaba ikike nke ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka maka ezi mmepe nke steeti a,' o kwuru.

en: Abdullahi called on all Nigerians to protect women and children from all forms of violence for development to thrive in the state and the country.
ibo: Abdullahi kpọkuru ndị Naịjirịa ka ha chekwaa ikike ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka n' ụdị mmekpa ahụ ọbụla iji mee ka mmepe nwere ọnọdụ na steeti ahụ nakwa obodo anyị.

en: 'Every Nigerian should ensure that women and children are protected and are not put under unnecessary violence,' he said.
ibo: 'Onye Naijiria ọbụla kwesiri ịhụ na e chekwabara ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka ma wezụga ha n' ihe mmekpa ahụ ọbụla n'ezighị ezi,' o kwuru.

en: Earlier, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, the state Commissioner for Women Affairs, said that they were in the assembly to seek for the legislature's support on crusade on violence against women.
ibo: Na mbụ, Hajiya Halima Jabiru, Cọmishọna na-ahụ maka ụmụnwaanyị nke steeti ahụ, sịrị na ha nọ n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu ahụ iji rịọ nkwado ndị ọmebe iwu n' ibu agha megide mmekpa ahụ nyere ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka.

en: 'As you can see that our women carried different placards with inscriptions such as say no to rape , no to violence against women.
ibo: 'Dịka ị ga-ahụ na ụmụnwaanyị anyị bu akwụkwọ ịkpọ ganigani e dere ihe dị iche iche dị ka jụ mwakpo n' ike, jụ mmekpa ahụ ụmụnwaanyị na ụmụaka.'

en: NASS inauguration: Dozie Nwankwo unifies citizens as he returns
ibo: Mwube nke NASS: Dozie Nwankwọ jikọtara ụmụ amaala ka ọ lọtara.

en: Anambra state citizens, especially those of the Njikoka, Dunukofia and Anaocha councils have been reassured of abundant democracy dividends by Chief Dozie Nwankwo, who took oath of office last Thursday as he was formally inaugurated by the leadership of the Federal House of Representatives, Abuja.
ibo: Ụmụ afọ Anambra Steeti, ọ kachasị ndị nọ n' okpuru ọchịchị Njikoka, Dunukọfịa na Anaọcha, ka Chifu Dozie Nwankwọ, onye ñuru iyi ọrụ ka ndị ndu ụlọrụ ọmebe iwu 'Federal House of Representatives' guzobere ya ụbọchị Tọzdee, kwegoro nkwa ịrite ihe nketa ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya n' uju.

en: Nwankwo was sworn in after successfully reclaiming his mandate at the Court of Appeal Elections Petitions tribunal, Enugu Division on Nov 1,2019.
ibo: E duru Nwankwọ n' iyi ọrụ ka ọ nwetachara mmeri n' ụlọikpe ekpecha ekpegharịa ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị (Court of Appeal Elections Petitions Tribunal), ngalaba Enugu na November 1, 2019.

en: The inauguration which was witnessed by all and sundry, including the Minister of Transportation, Chibike Amechi, Anambra deputy Governor Nkem Okeke, Senators Victor Umeh and Rochas Okorocha, Obiora Okonkwo, national and state assemblies members, ended with a dinner.
ibo: Nguzobe a nke ndị ukwu na ndị nta gụnyere Minista njem, Chibike Amechi, osote gọvanọ Anambra Steeti Nkem Okeke, ndị sinetọ Victor Umeh na Rochas Okorocha, Obiora Okonkwọ, ndị ọmebe iwu nke gọọmenti etiti nakwa nke steeti biara bụ nke e ji oriri abalị mechie.

en: Nigeria may miss SDG on healthcare, says Soludo
ibo: Naijiria nwere ike enwetaghị SDG nleta ahụ ike, Soludo na-ekwu

en: Former governor, Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), Prof. Chukwuma Soludo, has said that if the Federal Government does not initiate good reforms, the country may miss out on the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) on healthcare.
ibo: Onye jibu ọkwa gọvanọ ụlọ akụ nke etiti n' ala anyị nke bekee kpọrọ Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), Ọkammụta Chukwuma Soludo, ekwuola na ọ bụrụ na gọọmenti etiti ewebataghi ezigbo atụmatụ nhazigharị, ala anyị nwere ike ghara inweta nlekọta ahụ ike nke 'Sustainable Development Galeshia (SDG).'

en: Soludo spoke at the 26th Annual Lift Above Poverty Organisation (LAPO) Development Forum themed 'The Nigerian Healthcare Situation: The Way Forward' in Abuja.
ibo: Soludo kwuru okwu na ọgbakọ nke iri abụọ na isii ọgbakọ na-abịa kwa afọ nke otu a kpọrọ 'Lift Above Poverty Organisation' nke isiokwu ya bụ 'Ọnọdụ nlekọta ahụ ike na Naijiria: Ụzọ Agamniihu' nke e mere n' Abuja.

en: According to him, tackling healthcare challenges in the country requires decisive and comprehensive war on poverty, inequality, illiteracy or poor public health education, nutrition, water and sanitation, as well as provision of adequate and accessible public health facilities and insurance schemes.
ibo: N' okwu ya, ibuso agha nye ihe iche aka mgba nlekọta ahụ ike n'ala anyị kwesiri ezi mkpebi na ibuso agha zuru okè nye ụbịam, aghaghị nhatanha (inequality), amaghị ede na amaghị asụ ma ọ bụ enweghị ezi nkụzi na ọmụmụ ahụ ike ndị mmadụ, ihe oriri na-edozi ahụ, mmiri na adịmọcha tinyekwara inye na ime ka ndị mmadụ nweta ezigbo ngwa ahụ ike na usoro ikike.

en: 'The United Nations SDG 3 envisions that by 2030 all countries should ensure healthy lives and promote wellbeing for all at all ages.'There are about 13 specific targets to meet.
ibo: Ebumnuche SDG 3 nke 'United Nations' bụ na n' afọ 2030 obodo ọ bụla kwesiri ịhụ na enwere ezi ahụ ike ma kwalite obibi ndụ nye onye ọ bụla. E nwere ihe dịka iri na atọ e bu n' uche ịmepụta.

en: From all indications, Nigeria is set to miss the targets and the SDG on health except some dramatic and systematic reforms are initiated and sustained from now until 2030,' he said.
ibo: 'Site n' ihe niile a na-ahụ, Naijiria dị nkwadebe enwetaghị ebumnuche a nakwa SDG nke ahụ ike beeresọ ma a malitere ma jigidekwa nhazigharị dị egwu n' usoro e si eme ihe bido ugbua ruo 2030,' o kwuru.

en: Government's expenditure on health (like other sectors) needs to be ratcheted up and its facilitation and regulatory functions strengthened, he said, adding that serious attention at fora like that, should also focus on maximising the latent potential of the 'other hand' (individuals and non-state actors) in reversing what LAPO identifies as the 'progressive decline' of healthcare delivery in Nigeria.
ibo: Gọọmenti kwesiri iwelite aka n' ego ọ na-emefu n' ahụ ike (dị ka ngalaba ndị ọzọ) ma mekwuazi ka nkwalite na ọrụ igbazi ya siwanye ike.

en: He noted that the country's healthcare statistics was as scary as its poverty and unemployment statistics, using the average life expectancy as summary indicator.
ibo: O kwuputara na nchịkọta ọnụ Ọgụgụ ahụ ike obodo anyị na-eyi egwu dịka nchịkọta ọnụ Ọgụgụ ụbịam na enweghi ọrụ ya, site n' iji ụdị ndụ a tụrụanya ya dị ka ihe mgba ama.

en: The former governorship aspirant in Anambra State identified a strong correlation between poverty/inequality and health.He explained that the 1999 Constitution (as amended) provided for free and compulsory primary education, as well as free secondary education.
ibo: Ya bụ onye zọburu ọkwa gọvanọ Anambra Steeti gosiri nnukwu ihe Njikota dị n' etiti ụbịam/aghaghị nhatanha na ahụ ike. Ọ kọwara na iwu ala anyị nke 1999 (dị ka esi megharị ya) nyere ohere maka agụmakwụkwọ praịmarị n' akwụghị ụgwọ ma bụrụkwa iwu nakwa agụmakwụkwọ sekondrị n' akwụghị ụgwọ

en: In his opening remarks, chairman, LAPO Board of Directors, Dr. Osarenren Emokpae, called on the federal and state governments to increase budgetary allocation for the health sector.He said the increment would help reduce medical tourism, as some of the elite would begin to patronise local health facilities rather than go abroad.
ibo: N' okwu o ji meghe emume, onyeisi, 'LAPO Board of Directors', Osarenren Emokpae, kpọkuru gọọmenti etiti na nke steeti ka ha welite aka n' ego ha na-amapụta iji rụọ ọrụ na ngalaba ahụ ike. O kwuru na iwelite aka a ga-enye aka belata ije mba ofesi maka ihe gbasara ahụ ike n' ihi na ụfọdụ ndị e ji okwu ha agba izu ga-ebido iji ngwa ahụ ike anyị nwere kpọrọ ihe kama ijewe mba ofesi.

en: In 2018, Nigeria was ranked 187 out of 191 countries in the world that are not complying with the Universal Health Coverage (UCH), he noted, adding that LAPO, in its inclusive services to its clients and the general public, made healthcare a very important component of its services.The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of LAPO, Godwin Ehigiamusoe, said the country's health sector required urgent and collective attention and action, adding that the healthcare statistics in some cases were very depressing.
ibo: N' afọ 2018, Naijiria gbara ndị nke 187 n' ime mba 191 na anaghị esonyecha n' atụmatụ 'Universal Health Coverage (UCH)' n' ụwa niile, o kwuru, ma gbakwunye na LAPO, n' akaghị ọkè n' ọrụ ya nye ndị ọ na-arụ ọrụ nakwa ọha niile, mere ahụ ike akụkụ dị nnukwu mkpa n' ọrụ ya. Onyeisi ọrụ ((Chief Executive Officer (CEO)) nke LAPO, Godwin Ehigiamusoe, sịrị na ngalaba ahụ ike ala anyị kwesiri ezi nleta na mkpaso agwa nke mmadụ niile n' egbughi oge, o tinyere na nchịkọta ọnụ Ọgụgụ ahụ ike n' Ọnọdụ ụfọdụ na-ewute nke ukwuu.

en: Nnamdi Kanu's lawyer declared wanted
ibo: A kowaputara ọka ikpe Nnamdị Kanụ dị ka onye ndị uweojii na-achọ achọ.

en: The police in Anambra State have declared Ifeanyi Ejiofor, a lawyer to leader of the Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB) Nnamdi Kanu wanted.
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii Anambra Steeti emeela Ifeanyị Ejiofor, ọka ikpe nyere onye ndu 'Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB) Nnamdị Kanụ, onye ha na-achọ achọ.

en: 'I will like to let Nigerians to know that as we speak, Barrister Ejiofor, an IPOB member and his cohorts have been declared wanted by the command,' Anambra police commissioner in the state, John Abang, said on Tuesday.
ibo: 'Achọrọ m ime ka ndị Naịjirịa mara na dị ka anyị na-ekwu ugbua, Ọka ikpe Ejiofor, onye otu IPOB na ndị otu ya abụrụla ndị ndị uwe ojii nke mpaghara Anambra Steeti na-achọ achọ,' Cọmishọna uweojii nke Anambra Steeti, John Abang, kwuru n' ụbọchị Tuzdee.

en: 'And I will seek the cooperation of law-abiding Nigerians from North, South, East and West, wherever they find this individual, they should report to the nearest police station or any other security agency for possible arrest and prosecution.'
ibo: Anakwa m arịọ mmekọrịta ndị Naịjirịa na-edobe iwu na mgbago ugwu ugwu, mgbada ugwu, ọwụwa anyanwụ na ọdịda anyanwụ, ebe ọbụla ha hụrụ onye a, ha gaa nye mkpesa n' ụlọ ọrụ ndị uweojii ọbụla dị nso ma ọ bụ n' ụlọ ọrụ ndị nchekwa ọzọ maka ijide ma taa ya ahụhụ kwesiri ya.

en: One dead, two injured in road crash on Lagos-Abeokuta expressway
ibo: Otu anwụọla, abụọ meruru ahụ n' ihe mberede okporo ụzọ mere n' ụzọ awara awara Legosi-Abeokuta.

en: The Ogun Traffic Compliance and Enforcement Corps (TRACE), on Sunday, said that one person died, while two others sustained injuries in a road accident that occurred at Onihale area, near Owode-Ijako, on the Lagos-Abeokuta expressway.
ibo: 'Traffic Compliance and Enforcement Corps (TRACE) nke Ogun, n' ụbọchị ụka, kwuru na otu onye nwụrụ ebe mmadụ abụọ ndị ọzọ nwetara ihe mmeru ahụ n' ihe mberede okporo ụzọ nke mere na mpaghara Onihale, nke dị nso na Owode-Ijako, n' ụzọ awara awara Legosi-Abeokuta.

en: Mrs Temitope Oseni, the TRACE Unit Commander, Owode-Ijako, told the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) in Ota, Ogun, that the accident occurred at about 6.15 am. on Sunday.
ibo: Odoziakụ Temitope Oseni, onyeisi TRACE mpaghara Owode-Ijako, gwara ụlọ ọrụ nta akụkọ nke Naijiria, 'News Agency of Nigeria (NAN),' n' Ọta, Ogun steeti, na ihe mberede okporo ụzọ a mere n' ebe 6.15 nke ụtụtụ ụbọchị ụka.

en: She explained that a truck, with no registration number, heading to Sango-Ota from Abeokuta, lost control due to tyre burst.
ibo: Ọ kọwara na otu ụgbọ ala trọkụ, n' enweghị akara e ji mara ya, si Abeokuta na-eje Sango-Ota, ekweghi nkwụsị n' ihi na taya ya gbawara.

en: Oseni said that the vehicle somersaulted twice, resulting in the death of the motor boy, while the driver and one other sustained injuries.
ibo: Oseni kwuru na ụgbọala ahụ tụgharịrị ugboro abụọ nke butere ọnwụ nwa ikorobịa na-eso ụgbọala ahụ, ebe onye na-anya na onye ọzọ meruru ahụ.

en: READ ALSO: Auto Accident: One died, nine injured in Anambra
ibo: Gụkwuazị: Ihe mberede ụgbọala: otu nwụrụ, itoolu meruru ahụ n' Anambra (

en: Oseni explained that the motor boy was trying to jump out of the vehicle when he hit his head on the road, which resulted in his death.
ibo: Oseni kọwapụtara na nwa ikorobịa ahụ na-eso ụgbọala ahụ na-achọ isi ụgbọala ahụ mapụta mgbe ọ kụrụ isi n' ala nke butere ọnwụ ya.

en: 'The corpse of the victim has been taken for burial by the family members, while the survivors are receiving treatment in a disclosed hospital in Ifo, Ogun,' 'she said.
ibo: 'Ndị ezinụlọ ya eburula ozu ya maka ili ya, ebe ndị nke dị ndụ na-anara ọgwụgwọ n' ụlọ ọgwụ a kpọghị aha dị n' Ifo, Ogun steeti, ' o kwuru.

en: The TRACE unit commander said that the vehicle had been towed to Ifo police station to ease traffic flow in the area.
ibo: Onyeisi 'TRACE' mpaghara a kwuru na a kpụrụla ụgbọala ahụ kpụga ụlọ ọrụ ndị uweojii dị n' Ifo iji ka ọgịga ụgbọala n' ụzọ dị mfe.

en: She advised motorists to ensure that their vehicles were properly maintained and desist from the use of used tyres to avoid unnecessary loss of lives and property.
ibo: Ọ dụrụ ndị ọkwọ ụgbọala ọdụ ka ha kawa ahụ hụ na ha n' akpachapụrụ ụgbọala ha anya nke ọma ma wepu aka n' itinye taya a nyagoro anya n' ụgbọala ha iji gbochie itufu ndụ na akụnụba n' ụzọ n' ezighi ezi.

en: Ooni, Eze, Nwodo preach unity at World Eri Festival
ibo: Ooni, Eze, Nwodo kwusara ozi maka udo n' oriri Eri nke ụwa niile.

en: Nwodo excited as African-Americans 'return' home
ibo: Obi bụ Nwodo sọ añụrị dị ka ndị Afrika-Amerika lọtara ụlọ.

en: Obi of Onitsha, others grace occasion
ibo: Obi Ọnịcha, ndị ọzọ bịara mmemme ahụ.

en: It was the real handshake across the Niger—royal fathers from Igbo land and their counterparts from Yoruba land charging Nigerians on national unity as a path to peaceful coexistence among ethnic nationalities regardless of religious backgrounds.
ibo: Ọ bụ nnọọ nzukọ nke ndị mmadụ si ebe dị iche iche-- ndị Igwe ala Igbo nakwa ndị ogbo ha si ala Yoruba na-agwa ndị Naịjirịa ka ha nabata ịdịkọnotu dị ka ihe ga-eweta mbikọrịta n' udo n' etiti agbụrụ dị iche iche n' agbanyeghi ndabere okpukperechi dị iche iche.

en: At the historical Eri Festival in Aguleri, Anambra State, and in separate speeches, HRM Eze Chukwuemeka Eri, Eze Eri Kingdom in Enugwu Aguleri and HRM, Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi, Ooni of Ife, royal fathers from ancient stools of authority, showed the way forward and identified national unity as the key that will accelerate the pace of peace, development and progress of the country in all areas.
ibo: N' oriri akụkọ ihe mere eme Eri a n' Agụleri, Anambra Steeti, nakwa n' okwu dị iche iche, HRM Eze Chukwuemeka Eri, Eze obodo Eri n' Agụleri na HRM, Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi, Ooni nke Ife, ndị eze ọdịnala dị iche iche, gosiri ebe ụzọ agamniihu dị ma kọwa na ịdịnotu nke ala anyị bụ igodo ga-akpọghe ụzọ udo, mmepe na agamniihu nke ala anyị n' akụkụ ọbụla.

en: It is certainly auspicious that such occasion was witnessed at the World Eri Festival, held at Enugwu Aguleri in Anambra State, where Eze Eri hosted the Ooni of Ife, Obi of Onitsha, HRM Igwe Nnaemeka Achebe, President-General of Ohanaeze Ndigbo, Chief Nnia Nwodo, and other dignitaries.
ibo: Ọ bụ ihe ịtụnanya n' ezie na ụdị emume a pụtara ihe n' oriri Eri nke ụwa niile, nke a chịkọbara n' Enugwu Agụleri, Anambra Steeti, ebe Eze Eri kpọrọ Ooni nke Ife, Obi nke Ọnịcha, HRM Igwe Nnaemeka Achebe, onyeisi Ọhanaeze ndị Igbo gburugburu, Chief Nna Nwodo, nakwa ndị ọzọ a mara aha ha oriri.

en: Other dignitaries at the occasion were Igwe of Mbaukwu HRM Igwe Peter Anugwu, HRM, an industrialist Igwe Patrick Okolo of Nsukka Urban, Dr Chile Obidigbo, Chairman of Anambra East Local Government Area Hon Obi Nweke, The chairman of Ogbaru LGA Hon Arinze Awogu, Member Representing Anambra East in the Anambra State House of Assembly Hon Obinna Emenaka among others.
ibo: Ndị ọzọ a mara aha ha n' emume a bụ Igwe Mbaukwu HRM Igwe Peter Anugwu, omeputa ihe Igwe Patrick Okolo nke Nsukka obodo mepere emepe, Dr Chike Obidigbo, onye isioche nke okpuru ọchịchị Anambra East Hon Obi Nweke, onye isioche okpuru ọchịchị Ogbaru Hon Arinze Awogu, onye nnọchiteanya Anambra East n' ọmebe iwu Anambra Steeti Hon Obinna Emenaka nakwa ndị ọzọ.

en: The chief celebrator, Eze Chukwuemeka Eri, the Ezeora 34th and Aka Ji Ovo Igbo, described the Festival as a time when the Igbo world-wide gathered to remember their progenitor Eri, who is believed to have migrated from Israel and settled at Aguleri.
ibo: Onye kpọrọ oriri, Eze Chukwuemeka Eri, Eze ọrịa nke 34 na Aka ji Ọvọ Igbo, kọwara oriri ahụ dị ka mgbe ndị Igbo n' ụwa niile gbakọọ iji cheta isi mmalite ha bụ Eri, onye e kwenyere na o si Israel bịa biri n', Agụleri.

en: 'Today, we commemorate and celebrate an African and global historical figure Nna Anyi (our father) Eri.
ibo: 'Taa, anyị na-echeta ma na-eme emume onye isi ojii nakwa onye akụkọ ihe mere eme nke mba ụwa dum nna anyị Eri.

en: Today I welcome my brother and friend from our brotherly land of Yoruba, the Ooni of Ife, HRM Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi, Ojaja 11, the 51st Ooni of Ife.
ibo: Taa ana m anabata nwanne m nakwa enyi m si ala ụmụnne anyị Yoruba, Ooni nke Ife, HRM Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi, Ojaja nke 11, Ooni nke Ife nke 53.

en: I use this opportunity to call for peace and unity among the Yoruba and the Igbo and the rest of Nigerians,' he said.
ibo: E ji m ohere a arịọ maka udo na ịdịnotu n' etiti Igbo na Yoruba nakwa ndị Naịjirịa ndị ọzọ,' o kwuru.

en: Pillars, Abia Warriors resolve feud over Enaholo
ibo: Otu bọọlụ 'Pillars,' 'Abịa Warriors' emeziela ihu mgbarụ dị n' etiti ha maka Enaholo.

en: Nigeria Professional Football League (NPFL) side, Kano Pillars have confirmed that they have resolved the heated transfer feud with Abia Warriors over former Flying Eagles goalkeeper, Joshua Enaholo, Completesports.com reports.
ibo: Akụkụ 'Nigeria Professional Football League (NPFL)', 'Kano Pillars' ekwuputala na ha ekpeziela nnukwu ihu mgbarụ dị n' etiti ha na 'Abịa Warriors' banyere ndị onye cheburu 'Flying Eagles' goolu, Jọshụa Enaholo, ga-echere goolu, 'Completesports.com' kwuru.

en: Enaholo had joined the four-time League winners, Pillars during the summer transfer window, but Abia Warriors claimed the move breached all normal transfer procedures and twice, petitioned league organisers, LMC.
ibo: Enaholo esonyerela ndị bugoro iko egwuregwu a ugboro anọ, 'Kano Pillars' n' ohere ngafe n' oge ekpomoku (summer transfer window), mana Abịa Warriors kwuru na omume a erubeghiri ezi usoro ngafe isi ma gbaa ndị na-ahazi egwuregwu ahụ akwụkwọ ugboro abụọ.

en: The club had then said they were not opposed to the player's desire to move but stressed that though he still had one season left on his existing contract, due process should be followed.
ibo: Otu egwuregwu bọọlụ a kwuru na ha anaghị ekwugide ebumnuche Ọgba bọọlụ a ịpụ mana ha na-ekwusi ike na n' agbanyeghi na ọ ka nwere otu oge egwuregwu fọrọ afọ na nkwekọrịta ọrụ ha nyere, e kwesiri iso ezigbo usoro.

en: But the executive chairman of Kano Pillars board, Surajo Shuaibu Yahaya, has now revealed that the transfer feud has been amicably resolved, heaping plaudits on Abia Warriors chairman, Pastor Emeka Inyama, for his understanding, cooperation, and maturity in ensuring that the issue was amicably resolved.
ibo: Mana onye isioche ọrụ otu Kano Pillars, Surajo Shuaibu Yahaya, egosila ugbua na ihu mgbarụ nke ngafe abụrụla ihe e jiri nwayọọ wee dozie, buruzie ukpa ekele bugara onye isioche Abịa Warriors, Pastor Emeka I ya ma, maka nghọta ọ nwere, nkwekọrịta nakwa ntozu okè ya n' ime ka okwu ahụ bụrụ nke e ji nwayọọ dozie.

en: Police gun down notorious armed robbery suspect in Abia
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii gbaturu ekperima a ma ama a na-enyo enyo n' Abịa.

en: Police
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii

en: The Police in Abia on Tuesday gunned down a suspected notorious armed robber identified as Sampson Nwokocha, aka 'Grave' who has been terrorizing residents of Umuahia and its environs.
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii n' Abịa n' ụbọchị Tuzdee gbaturu onye ekperima a na-enyo enyo a mara dị ka Sampson Nwokocha, 'aka Grave' onye na-ebutere ndị bi n' Ụmụahia na obodo ndị gbara gburugburu ihe ụjọ .

en: The Commissioner of Police in the state, Mr Ene Okon, who made this known to newsmen in Umuahia, said that he was shot dead after a gun battle with his men following a tip off.
ibo: Kọmishọna uweojii n' Abịa steeti, Maazị Ene Okon, onye mere ka ndị nta akụkọ mara nke a n' Ụmụahia, kwuru na a gbagburu ya ka ya na ndị otu ya (ndị uwe ojii) gbakọrịtachara egbe ka e suru ya imi.

en: He said that Nwokocha, who was recently released from prison, had been on the watch list of the command following his alleged numerous criminal activities.
ibo: O kwuru na Nwokocha, onye e si na nga kpọpụta n' oge n' etoghi aka, noburịị n' akwụkwọ ndị ndị uwe ojii mpaghara ahụ na-achọ n' ihi mkpamkpa dị iche iche a sịrị na ọ na-akpa.

en: He said, 'It would be recalled that on Nov. 6 and 10, 2019, Nwokocha and his gang invaded a hotel and robbed staff and guests.
ibo: Ọ sịrị, 'A ga-echeta na November 6 na 10, 2019, Nwokocha na ndị otu ya wakporo họteelu ma zuo ndị ọrụ na ndị ọbịa nọ ebe ahụ ohi.

en: 'During the operation, one policeman on duty was shot dead and his rifle carted away.
ibo: N' oge mwakpo a a gbagburu otu onye uwe ojii n' ọrụ ma were egbe ya gbalaga.

en: 'Also on November 10, 2019, Nwokocha and his gang robbed attendants and customers of a filling station on Bank Road, Umuahia.
ibo: Ọzọkwa na November 10, 2019, Nwokocha na ndị otu ya zuru ndị na-ere ahịa na ndị na-azụ rụrụ ahịa na 'filling station' dị na Banki Rodu, Ụmụahia.

en: READ ALSO: Police arrest woman for poisoning stepdaughter in Katsina
ibo: Gụkwuazị: Ndị uwe ojii jidere nwaanyị maka inye nwa nwunye di ya nsị.

en: 'On different occasions, he led a gang that snatched vehicles from their owners within and outside of the capital city at gunpoint.
ibo: N' Ọnọdụ dị iche iche, o duru ndị otu jiri egbe napụ ụgbọala n' aka ndị nwe ha n' ime isi obodo a nakwa ebe ndị ọzọ.

en: 'He also robbed other locations and planned to attack the Correctional Service Centre (Prison) in Umuahia to liberate his mother and other inmates.'
ibo: O zukwara ohi n' ebe ndị ọzọ ma kpaa nkata iwakpo ụlọ nga dị n' Ụmụahia iji duputa nne ya na ndị mkpọrọ ndị ọzọ.

en: Okon warned criminals to desist from their nefarious activities or relocate as the command would not spare them.
ibo: Okon dọrọ ndị ekperima aka ná ntị ka ha hapụ ajọ omume ma ọ bụ kwapụ makana ndị uwe ojii mpaghara ahụ agaghị ahapụ ha.

en: Police kill notorious armed robbery suspect in Abia
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii gburu ekperima a ma ama a na-enyo enyo n' Abịa.

en: The Police in Abia on Tuesday gunned down a suspected notorious armed robber identified as Sampson Nwokocha, aka 'Grave' who has been terrorizing residents of Umuahia and its environs.
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii n' Abịa n' ụbọchị Tuzdee gbaturu onye ekperima a na-enyo enyo a mara dị ka Sampson Nwokocha, 'aka Grave' onye na-ebutere ndị bi n' Ụmụahia na obodo ndị gbara gburugburu ihe ụjọ .

en: The Commissioner of Police in the state, Mr Ene Okon, who made this known to newsmen in Umuahia, said that he was shot dead after a gun battle with his men following a tip off.
ibo: Cọmishọna uweojii n' Abịa steeti, Maazị Ene Okon, onye mere ka ndị nta akụkọ mara nke a n' Ụmụahia, kwuru na a gbagburu ya ka ya na ndị otu ya (ndị uwe ojii) gbakọrịtachara egbe ka e suru ya imi.

en: He said that Nwokocha, who was recently released from prison, had been on the watch list of the command following his alleged numerous criminal activities.
ibo: O kwuru na Nwokocha, onye e si na nga kpọpụta n' oge n' etoghi aka, noburịị n' akwụkwọ ndị ndị uwe ojii mpaghara ahụ na-achọ n' ihi mkpamkpa dị iche iche a sịrị na ọ na-akpa.

en: Reps seek details of Nigeria-Russia agreement on Ajaokuta Steel Company
ibo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu chọrọ nkọwa nkwekọrịta nke Naijiria - Russia banyere Ajaokuta 'steeti company'

en: The House of Representatives has mandated its relevant committees to get details of the agreement between Nigeria and Russia on the completion of the Ajaokuta Steel Company.
ibo: Ụlọ ọmebe iwu enyela Kọmitii ha họpụtara iwu ka ha nweta nkọwa nkwekọrịta dị n' etiti Naijiria na Russia banyere ịrụcha Ajaokuta 'steeti company.'

en: The committees which include Steel as well as Treaties, Protocols and Agreements are to interface with the Minister of Mines and Steel Development.
ibo: Ndị Kọmitii nke gụnyere 'steel' nakwa 'Treaties, ' 'Protocols' na 'Agreement' na Minista ihe ngwuputa na mmepe ga-arụkọ ọrụ ọnụ.

en: This was sequel to a unanimous adoption of a motion by Rep. Nkem Abonta (PDP-Abia) at the plenary on Tuesday.
ibo: Nke a bịara ka jicha otu olu nabata iwu nke ọmebe iwu Nkem Abonta (PDP Abịa) wetara na nzukọ ụlọ ọmebe iwu n' ụbọchị Tuzdee.

en: Moving the motion earlier, Abonta said that it was in order to ensure a seamless ratification of such an agreement in line with the provisions of relevant laws.
ibo: N' iweputa iwu na mbụ, Abọnta sịrị n' ọ bụ iji hụ na enweghi ihe ga-egbochi nnabata nkwekọrịta ahụ n' usoro iwu.

en: Residents flee town of Kanu's lawyer after policemen's death
ibo: Ndị bi n' obodo ọka ikpe Nnamdị Kanụ gbapụrụ ka ndị uwe ojii nwụchara.

en: A siege allegedly laid to Oraifite in Ekwusigo Local Government of Anambra State by a combined team of soldiers and policemen forced residents to flee the community yesterday.
ibo: Nnọchibido e mere n' Ọraifite n' Okpuru ọchịchị Ekwusigo nke Anambra Steeti nke si njikọ ndị agha na ndị uwe ojii manyere ndị bi n' obodo ahụ ịgbapụ na ya ụnyaahụ.

en: The desertion of the community came on the heels of declaration of Ifeanyi Ejiofor, the lawyer to the Supreme Leader of the Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB), Nnamdi Kanu, wanted by the state police command over an alleged killing of Oliver Innoma Abbey, the Oraifite Area Commander and the SARS Commander, Ichi Sector, Patrick Agbazue.
ibo: Nhapụ obodo ahụ pụtara ihe mgbe ndị uwe ojii mpaghara ahụ mere Ifeanyị Ejiofor, ọka ikpe onye ndu ndị 'Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB), Nnamdi Kanu, onye ha na-achọ achọ maka ebubo ogbugbu Oliver Innoma Abbey, Ọchịagha Mpaghara Ọraifite na Ọchịagha SARS, Mpaghara Ichi, Patrick Agbazue.

en: The two officers led a police patrol team to the compound of Ejiofor in Oraifite, where the police allegedly shot at three persons and wounded scores of others suspected to belong to IPOB.
ibo: Ndị ọrụ nche abụọ duru otu mkpagharị ndị uwe ojii jee nguru be Ejiofor n' Ọraifite, ebe ndị e kwuru na ndị uwe ojii gbara mmadụ atọ egbe ma meruo ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ a na-eche na ha bụ ndị IPOB ahụ.

en: It was learnt that the seeming police invasion of the house of the counsel to Kanu, who had three days earlier buried one of his elder brothers, irked some youths in the area who allegedly launched a reprisal attack, which is believed to have resulted in the death of Abbey and Agbazue whose remains were burnt and buried near a village market.
ibo: A chọpụtara na ihe dịka mwakpo ndị uwe ojii wakporo ụlọ ọka ikpe Nnamdị Kanụ, onye kwara ozu otu nwanne ya nwoke tọrọ ya na mkpụrụ ụbọchị atọ gara aga, kpasuru ụfọdụ ndị ntorobịa nọ na gburugburu ahụ iwe ndị a na-eche na ha bughachiri agha megide ndị uwe ojii, nke butere ọnwụ Abbey na Agbazue ndị a gbara ozu ha ọkụ ma lie ha n' ahịa obodo dị nso.

en: The police and IPOB have given differing accounts of the incident in which not less than 20 houses and shops have been razed.
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii na ndị IPOB nwere akụkọ dị iche iche banyere ihe a merenụ nke ọkụ gbapịrị opekata mpe ụlọ na ọdụ ahịa iri abụọ maka ya.

en: Revving critical national issues as Madueke launches autography
ibo: Ịkpalite okwu ndị dị oke mkpa nye ala anyị dị ka Madueke buputere akwụkwọ o dere banyere onwe ya.

en: Admiral Allison MaduekeNo doubt, the story of the 30-month Nigerian Civil War of 1967 would remain a critical point for discussion anytime Nigeria is being examined in history to project for a better future.
ibo: Admiral Allison Madueke, n' enweghị mgbagha, akụkọ agha ọnwa iri atọ nke ndị na abụghị ndị agha Naijiria nke 1967 ka bụ mgbe dị oke mkpa na mkparịta ụka oge ọ bụla a na-eleba anya n' akụkọ Naijiria iji kwụ maka ọdịmma Naijiria n' ọdịnihu.

en: So also the agitation for restructuring and June 12, 1993, presidential election, acclaimed to have been won by the late business mogul, Chief M.K.O Abiola but annulled by the then military Head of State, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.
ibo: Otu ahụ ka ọ dịkwa ibu agha maka nhazigharị na ntụli aka onyeisi ala Juun 12, 1993, nke e kwuru na ọ bụ nnukwu oji ego achụ ego nwụrụ anwụ, Chief M.K.O. Abiola meriri, mana onyeisi ndị agha na-achị mgbe ahụ, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, kagburu ya.

en: These issues seem recurring and cannot be overlooked as they impact on national discourse.
ibo: Okwu ndị a niile na-apụta ihe ugboro ugboro ma agaghị elegharanwu ha anya n' ihi na ha nwere mmetụta n' okwu gbasara ala anyị.

en: Twenty-one years since Nigeria returned to civil rule, those factors that led to the civil war, the unending agitations for restructuring and the perceived domination of governance system by a particular section of the country are still visible markers that still haunt the country and continue to stifle its development.
ibo: Afọ iri abụọ na otu ka mgbe Naijiria lọghachiri n' ọchịchị ndị nkịtị, ihe ahụ niile butere agha ndị abụghị ndị agha, ibu agha maka nhazigharị akwụsị akwụsị na otu agbụrụ ala anyị ijichi usoro ọchịchị nke a na-ahụ ka bụ ihe ndị pụtara ihe ka na-akụda obodo anyị ma na-egbochi mmepe.

en: As a matter of fact, most of the issues have not been adequately tackled many leas put in proper perspectives in a manner that could have helped in reshaping the nation's growth and development.
ibo: Ka o sila dị, e gbochibeghi ọtụtụ ihe ndị a dịka o kwesiri nke a na-etinye ha n' ụzọ ziri ezi ga-enye aka n' ịhazigharị otito nakwa mmepe nke ala anyị.

en: These factors were part of issues that were publicly deliberated upon, when former Chief of Naval Staff and one-time Military Administrator of Anambra and the Imo State, Admiral Allison Madueke (rtd), launched his autobiography last week.
ibo: Ihe ndị a bụ ụfọdụ n' ime ihe ndị a gbara maka ha n' ihu ọha ka onye bụbu 'Chief of Naval Staff' nakwa onye agha lekọtaburu Anambra na Imo steeti n' otu oge, Admiral Allison Madueke (lagoro ezumike nká) buputere akwụkwọ o dere banyere onwe ya n' izu ụka gara aga.

en: It is entitled Riding the Storms, with God in My Sails at MUSON Centre, Onikan, Lagos.
ibo: A kpọrọ ya 'Riding the Storms, with God in my Sails' na MUSON Centre, Onikan, Legosi.

en: Seeking inclusiveness through regional development commissions
ibo: Ịchọ nnabata mmadụ niile site na otu ọrụ mmepe mpaghara.

en: Oduah
ibo: Oduah

en: The quest for the establishment of development commissions for the remaining geo-political zones in the country apart from the South-south and Northeast gained momentum recently with the introduction of three bills to that effect in the Senate.
ibo: Ọchịchọ iguzobe otu ọrụ mmepe maka mpaghara ọchịchị ndị fọrọ afọ n' obodo anyị ma e wepụ South - south na Northeast nwetara ịnụ ọkụ na nso a site n' iwebata iwu atọ banyere n' ụlọ ọmebe iwu sineti.

en: Onyedika Agbedo looks at the genesis of the move, the gimmicks around it and its likely outcome in this report.
ibo: Onyedịka Agbedo lebara anya na mbido nzọ ukwu a, ụzọ aghụghọ dị na ya na ihe ọ nwere ike ịpụta n' nkọwa a.

en: There is a cool 'war' in the Senate among the geo-political zones in the country following penultimate Wednesday's reintroduction of a bill seeking to establish the South East Development Commission.
ibo: E nwere agha zoro ezo na sineti n'etiti mpaghara ọchịchị nke ala anyị nke sitere n' iwebatagharị iwu na-achọ ka ewube ọrụ mmepe mpaghara South East n' Wenzidee abụọ gara aga.

en: The 8th Senate had passed the bill, sponsored by Senator Stella Oduah (PDP, Anambra North) on December 12, 2018, but it did not get President Muhammadu Buhari's assent.
ibo: Sineti nke asatọ anabatala iwu a, Sinetọ Stella Oduah (PDP, Anambra North) kwadoro ya na Disemba 12, 2018, mana ọ nweta gị nkwado onyeisi ala Muhammadu Buhari.

en: Should the bill secure the nod of the lawmakers again and possibly receive presidential assent this time around, it would give birth to a commission charged with the responsibility of receiving and managing funds specially allocated by the Federal Government for the rehabilitation, reconstruction and reparation for lost houses and businesses of victims of the Nigerian civil war.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na iwu a nweta nkwekọrịta ndị ọmebe iwu ọzọ ma nwekwa ike nata nkwado onyeisi ala n' oge a, ọ ga - amụta otu ọrụ a ga-etinye n' aka ya ịnata na ijikwa ego gọọmenti etiti mapụtara n' ụzọ pụrụ iche maka idozigharị, ịrụgharị na iti aka n' obi nye ndị tụfuru ụlọ ha na azụmahịa ha n' oge agha ndị abụghị ndị agha Naijiria.

en: The commission would also address any other environmental or developmental challenges confronting the zone.
ibo: Otu ọrụ a ga-elebakwa anya n' ihe ndị ọzọ na-chere gburugburu ebe obibi na mmepe mpaghara aka mgba.

en: Clause 15 (2a) of the bill, which identifies source of funding for the commission, stipulates that the equivalent of 10 per cent of the total monthly statutory allocation due to the member states of the commission shall be from the Federation Account.
ibo: Nkebi 15 (2a) nke iwu a, kọwara ụzọ a ga-esi enweta ego maka otu ọrụ a, kwuru na ihe dịka pa senti 10 mgbakọta ego e kwesiri ịmapụtara steeti ọbụla so n' otu ọrụ a kwa ọnwa ga-esi n' akpa gọọmenti etiti.

en: It also seeks the establishment of a governing board for the commission, which shall include one person each from the other five geopolitical zones of the country.
ibo: Ọ chọkwazịrị nguzobe otu ga-achị otu ọrụ a, nke gụnyere otu onye kwa mpaghara ọchịchị ise ndị ọzọ nke ala anyị.

en: South-East NYSC coordinator inaugurates entrepreneurship centre in Aba
ibo: Onye na-achịkọta NYSC na South-East guzobere 'entrepreneurship Centre' n' Aba.

en: Alhaji Ahmed Ikaka, the South East Zonal Coordinator, National Youth Service Corp (NYSC), on Tuesday inaugurated a new Skills Acquisition and Entrepreneurship Department (SAED) Centre built by corps members serving in Osisioma, near Aba.
ibo: Alhaji Ahmed Ikaka, onye na-achịkọta mpaghara South-East, 'National Youth Service Corp (NYSC)' n' ụbọchị guzobere 'Skills Acquisition and Entrepreneurship Department (SAED) Centre' ọhụrụ nke ndị lụrụ ya bụ ndị ntorobịa ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha n' Osisiọma, dị nso n' Aba.

en: Speaking at the event, Ikaka lauded the efforts of the corps members, saying that NYSC was leading the economic revolution in Nigeria with the skill acquisition training given to corps members.
ibo: N' okwu ya na mmemme a, Ikaka toro mbọ ndị ntorobịa a gbara, na-asị na NYSC bu ụzọ mgbanwe nke akụnụba n' Naijiria site n' ọzụzụ mmụta nkà a na-enye ndị ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha.

en: He assured Nigerians of better economy with the series of training given to corps members to make them self-reliant.
ibo: O gwara ndị Naịjirịa na akụnụba ga-aka mma maka ọtụtụ ọzụzụ a na-enye ndị ntorobịa ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha iji mee ka kwụrụ onwe ha.

en: He said that Nigeria had no reason to be patronising foreign goods when its youths creatively produce such goods.
ibo: O kwuru na o nweghị ihe ga-eme ka Naijiria na-azụta ngwa ahịa e mere na mba ọzọ ebe ndị ntorobịa ya na-emepụta ngwa ahịa ahụ.

en: READ ALSO: The NYSC uniform controversy
ibo: Gụkwuazị: Ọ gba aghara maka uwe NYSC.

en: The NYSC boss, therefore, urged Nigerians to patronise local manufacturers and assist them to strengthen their economy.
ibo: Onyeisi NYSC, ya mere, rịọrọ ndị Naịjirịa ka ha na-atụnyere ndị na-emepụta ihe n' ụlọ ma nyere ha aka iji ka akụnụba gbasie ike.

en: 'We should produce what we consume. We have the best skills in the world. You have seen from the exhibition we had here the production of shoes, hats, clothings and other things.
ibo: 'Anyị kwesiri iji na-emepụta ihe anyị na-eri. Anyị nwere nkà kasị mma n' ụwa niile. Site n' anyị gosirila Ị hụla mmepụta akpụkpọ ụkwụ, okpu, ákwà na ihe ndị ọzọ.

en: 'We have seen also those in agro-allied, food production and processing.
ibo: 'Anyị ahụkwala ihe ndị ahụ gbasara ọrụ ugbo, mmepụta nri na nhazi.

en: 'We cannot be deceiving ourselves, no nation develops on importation.
ibo: 'Anyị agaghị na-aghọrị onwe anyị, onweghi obodo na-emepe site ịtụbata ihe.

en: The life of a nation depends on the skills of its citizens and none develops beyond the citizens' skills.
ibo: Ndụ obodo dị n' aka nkà ụmụ amaala ya ma onweghi nke na-emepe karịa nkà ụmụ amaala ya.

en: 'So NYSC is changing Nigeria's narrative by developing the skills of these corps members and they are becoming job creators, instead of job seekers.
ibo: 'Ya bụ NYSC na-agbanwe akụkọ Naijiria site n' imepe nkà ndị ntorobịa ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha ma ha bụzi ndị na-eke ọrụ kama ndị na-achọ ọrụ.

en: 'A lot of NYSC members are contributing to the economic development of our nation.
ibo: 'Ọtụtụ n' ime ndị ntorobịa ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha na-atunye ụtụ na mmepe nke akụnụba ala anyị.

en: 'This is the only way we can move forward, we cannot continue to deceive ourselves,' Ikaka said.
ibo: 'Nke a bụ sọ ụzọ anyị nwere ike iji gaa n' ihu, anyị agaghị anọgide n' ịghọrị onwe anyị,' Ikaka kwuru.

en: He said that corps members had learnt to write business proposals, given loan windows with Bank of Industry offering N2 billon, Central Bank providing N400 million, Heritage Bank fund, NYSC Foundation fund and Credit Direct fund.
ibo: O kwuru na ndị so ná ndi ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha amụtala ka e si ede am ụma azụmahịa, nyere ohere mbite ego ụlọaku nke mmepụta na-enye ijeri N2, ụlọaku etiti na-enye nde N400, ego ụlọaku 'Heritage', 'NYSC Foundation Fund' na 'Credit Direct Fund. '

en: He said with about N10 million available for corps members to access, it will be easy for them to succeed outside the service and improve Nigeria's economy.
ibo: Ọ sịrị na ijide ihe dịka nde N10 n' aka maka ndị ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha, ọ ga-adị mfe ha ịganihu ma ha fecha ala nna ha ma kwalite akụnụba Naijiria.

en: The state NYSC Coordinator, Lady Bona Fasakin, said that Osisioma Local Government Area (LGA) had been partners in progress with NYSC.
ibo: Onye nchịkọta NYSC nke steeti ahụ, Lady Bona Fasakin , sịrị na Okpuru ọchịchị Osisiọma bụrịị ndị ha na NYSC na-emekọ n' ọganihu.

en: Fasakin said that the council provided the land, where the centre was built, adding that by that act the council had keyed into the vision of the scheme in its fight against unemployment.
ibo: Fasakin sịrị na Okpuru ọchịchị ahụ nweputara ala, ebe a rụrụ ebe ọmụmụ ihe, ọ gbakwunyere na site n' omume a okpuru ọchịchị a azọnyela ụkwụ n' ebumnuche atụmatụ a n' imegide enweghi ọrụ.

en: She urged other councils and stakeholders in Abia to emulate Osisioma's example by providing skills training equipment to sustain the vision and ensure that corps members become job providers.
ibo: Ọ gwara okpuru ọchịchị ndị ọzọ na ndị niile o metụtara n' Abịa ka ha ñomie ụkpụrụ Osisiọma site iweta ngwa ọmụmụ nkà iji kwado ebumnuche a ma hụ na ndị ji otu afọ efe ala nna ha bụ ndị na-ekeputa ọrụ.

en: She further called for support for NYSC Health Initiative for Rural Dwellers so that rural dwellers would benefit from the programme.
ibo: Ọ gara n' ihu rịọ enyemaka atụmatụ ahụ ike NYSC maka ndị bi n' ime obodo iji mee ka ndị bi n' ime obodo wee rite uru amụma ahụ.

en: The Transition Chairman of Osisioma LGA, Mr Ugochukwu Nwaogu, said the council would continue to assist in making life better for the corps members serving in the area.
