ibo: Federa resav si kọwaa na mgbe akwụmụgwọ dị ụkọ na ọmụrụ nwa dị elu, ọ nwere ike zụta nchekwa gọọmentị site na ụlọ akụ iji bulie oke mmiri na belata ọnụego ndị ahụ.

en: By extension the reverse was also true – when there was too much money in circulation and interest rates were too low, it could sell government securities to banks.
ibo: Site na ndọtị, mgbanwe a bụkwa eziokwu - mgbe enwere nnukwu ego na mgbasa ma na ọmụrụ nwa dị ntakịrị, ọ nwere ike renye nchedo gọọmentị n'ụlọ akụ.

en: By May 1922, the Federal Reserve decided to formalize this process and create what was called the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to coordinate how this new powerful tool was to be used and when.
ibo: Tupu Mee 1922, Federa resav kpebiri imepụta usoro a wee mepụta ihe akpọrọ Kọmitii ahịa mepere nke isi ala (FOMC) iji hazie otu a ga-esi rụọ ngwá ọrụ ọhụrụ a dị egwu na mgbe.

en: These days Open Market Operations (OMO) is nothing new of course but in 1922 one can only imagine how innovative they were.
ibo: mmepe ahịa nke ụbọchị ndị a (OMO) na-arụ ọrụ n'ahịa ọhụrụ (OMO) abụghị ihe ọhụụ mana ọ bụ na 1922 mmadụ nwere ike iche n'echiche etu ha si arụ ọrụ.

en: All of a sudden there was a market tool which could be used as a lever to control interest rates without having to use any other crude methods.
ibo: Na mberede, enwere ngwa ahịa nke enwere ike iji dị ka onye na-achịkwa iji belata ọnụego ọmụrụ nwa na-ejighị ụzọ ọjọọ ndị ọzọ.

en: Over the last 100 years since the invention of this tool, Central Banks across the world have borrowed and deployed it in their own countries to achieve the same goal of managing the supply of credit in the economy and interest rates in general.
ibo: N'ime otu narị afọ gara aga kemgbe mmalite nke ngwa a, ụlọ akụ ala n'ofe ụwa agbaziri ma bufee ya na mba nke ha iji nweta otu ebumnuche nke ijikwa kredit nke akụ na ụba na ọmụrụ nwa n'ozuzu ya.

en: Until the coming of the Great Godwin Emefiele, Nigeria's Central Bank governor, that is.
ibo: Ruo mgbe ọbịbịa onye dị ike Godwin Emefiele, gọvanọ ụlọ akụ nke ala Naịjirịa, bụ ya.

en: In the last 2 or so years in Nigeria, the meaning of OMO has been completely redefined.
ibo: N'ime afọ abụọ gara aga ma ọ bụ karịa na Naịjirịa, a kọwapụtara nkọwa nke OMO kpamkpam.

en: The name remains the same and in the Central Bank's annual activity report, it still says that the purpose of its OMO activity is 'to moderate the excess banking system liquidity'.
ibo: Aha a ka bụ otu ihe si kwa na akụkọ nke ụlọ akụ isi ala kwa ụbọchị, o ka na ekwu na ebumnuche nke ọrụ OMO bụ 'ime ka usoro ụlọ akụ dị nma'.

en: On the face of it, that sounds like the same thing the US Fed discovered almost 100 years ago.
ibo: N'akụkụ ya, nke ahụ na-ada ka otu ihe ahụ US Fed chọpụtara n'ihe dị ka otu narị afọ gara aga.

en: But when you dig deeper into what is going on in Nigeria, you see something totally different.
ibo: Mana mgbe imubanye n'ime ihe ndị na-eme na Naịjirịa, ị na-ahụ ihe dị iche.

en: The first thing is to ask a simple question – how come CBN's OMO involves foreign investors? Much of the securities being sold by the CBN to 'mop up' excess liquidity in the banking system is being bought by foreign investors.
ibo: Ihe mbu bu iju ajuju - kedu ihe CBN si OMO si tinye ndị nnochita ala ozo? Ọtụtụ ndị nchekwa nke ndị CBN na-ere iji 'dozie oke mmiri dị na usoro nchekwa ụlọ akụ na-azụta n'aka ndị si mba ofesi.

en: Has the CBN finished mopping up the liquidity in Nigeria that it is now mopping up foreign liquidity as well? As anyone who has been following events knows, what happens is that the CBN sells securities to foreign investors at 'mouthwatering rates' that they cannot obtain elsewhere.
ibo: Ndi CBN emechaala mmiri dị na ala Naịjirịa na - emeziwanye mmiri si mba ọzọ? Dị ka onye ọ bụla nke na-eme ihe omume maara, ihe na-eme bụ na CBN na-eresị ndị nchekwa ala ọzọ nchekwa ego na 'ọnụ ọnụ' ha enweghị ike inweta ebe ọzọ.

en: Since these foreign investors only have dollars and the CBN's securities are denominated in naira, the CBN takes their dollars and exchanges it to naira for them.
ibo: Ebe ọ bụ na ndị ọchụnta ego ndị a si mba ọzọ nwere naanị dollar na ego mkpuchi nke CBN na naira, CBN na-ewere dollar ha ma gbanwere ya nye naira maka ha.

en: At the same time, it gives them a cast iron guarantee that when they need their dollars back in 1 years' time, it will sell it to them at an agreed rate no matter what the actual rate at that time is.
ibo: N'otu oge ahụ, ọ na-ekwe ha nkwa nke ihe nkedo na mgbe ha chọrọ dọla ha n'ime afọ 1, ọ ga-erere ha ya na ọnụego ekwenyere na agbanyeghị etu ọnụego ahụ n'oge ahụ dị.

en: These investors then take their naira and buy securities from the CBN and count their interest for one year.
ibo: Ndị a na - etinye ego na - ewere naira ha ma zụta nchekwa site na CBN ma gụpụta mmasị ha otu afọ.

en: In 2018 alone, CBN sold a total of N22.4trn ($62bn) worth of OMO securities ostensibly to 'mop up' excess liquidity.
ibo: Na 2018 naanị, CBN rere ọnụego N22.4trn ($ 62bn) nke nchekwa ego OMO ka ọ ga - eme ka ọ 'wụfuo mmiri.

en: Anambra State before the advent of All Progressives Grand Alliance (APGA) was marred by chaos, armed robbery attacks, kidnapping, threat to life and, property as well as looting of public funds.
ibo: Steeti Anambra tupu mmalite nke All Progressives Grand Alliance (APGA) bịara nwee ọgba aghara site na, mwakpo ndị oji egbe, nwantakịrị, egwu na ndụ, akụ na ịwe ụba nke ọha.

en: Was there really that much money sloshing around the Nigerian banking system that needed mopping up? At any rate, there was hardly any movement in interest rates during the year since the CBN itself needed to keep them high to keep attracting foreign investors to buy the securities.
ibo: Enwere nnukwu nsogbu ego na usoro ụlọ akụ na Naịjirịa chọrọ ịkwado? Ka o sina dị, enwebeghị mmegharị ọ bụla na ọnụego ọmụrụ nwa n'afọ ahụ n'ihi na CBN n'onwe ya kwesịrị idebe ha ka ọ dị elu iji nọgide na-adọta ndị na-etinye ego si mba ọzọ ịzụta nchekwa.

en: Herein is the final evidence that if the inventors of OMO were to reincarnate in Nigeria today, they would not recognise their own creation.
ibo: Nke a bụ akaebe ikpeazụ na-egosi na ọ bụrụ na ndị chepụtara OMO ga-alọ ụwa na Naịjirịa taa, ha agaghị anabata okike nke ha.

en: Nigeria's OMO does not mop up excess liquidity and does not have any effect on interest rates.
ibo: OMO nke Naịjirịa anaghị achịkwa oke mmiri ma ọ nweghị mmetụta ọ bụla na ọnụego ọmụrụ nwa.

en: So what is the best thing to call this redefined OMO? Nigeria owes the foreign investors who buy the OMO securities and it owes them in dollars.
ibo: Yabụ kedu ihe kacha mma ịkpọ OMO a akọwapụtara? Naijirịa ji ndị mbịarambịa si mba ọzọ ụgwọ zụrụ nchekwa OMO ma ji ya na dọla.

en: The CBN has merely found a way to increase Nigeria's external debt using what Diezani Alison-Madueke famously called 'non transparent opacity'.
ibo: CBN achọtala ụzọ iji bulie ụgwọ mpụga nke Naịjirịa site na iji Diezani Alison-Madueke a ma ama akpọrọ 'non transperent opesity'.

en: When you go to the Debt Management Office (DMO) website, what you see on the front page is FG's share of Nigeria's foreign debt that currently stands at $21bn.
ibo: Mgbe ị gara na webụsaịtị ụlọ ọrụ nhazi ụgwọ (DMO), ihe ị na-ahụ na peeji ihu bụ òkè FG nke ụgwọ mba ofesi na Naịjirịa nke dị ugbu a na $ 21bn.

en: As the CBN's OMO is mostly short term for 1 year, it is hard to tell how much the outstanding balance is.
ibo: Dịka OMO nke CBN na-abụkarị obere oge maka afọ 1, ọ bụ ihe siri ike ịkọ ego ole pụtara ìhè.

en: But whenever the CBN decides to make this figure public, we should be honest enough to treat it as what it really is by adding it to the figure of Nigeria's external debt.
ibo: Mana mgbe ọ bụla CBN kpebiri ime ka ọnụ ọgụgụ a pụta n'ihu ọha, anyị kwesịrị ịkwụwa aka ọtọ iji were ya dị ka ọ bụ n'ezie site na itinye ya na ọnụ ọgụgụ nke mpụga ụgwọ nke Naịjirịa.

en: The Administration 1999-2003 was handcuffed, emasculated and strangulated to make way for celebrated looting of the Treasury, through the instrumentality of Irrevocable Payment Standing Order'.
ibo: Edebere gọọmentị 1999-2003 n'aka, ikeọbụ, mmechi iji mee emume ịkwakọrọ Akụ nke Ego, site na ngwa nke 'Irrevocable Payment Standing Order'.

en: Mr. Michael Akinwale is the General Manager of Rally Trade, an international online broker.
ibo: Maazị Michael Akinwale bụ onye njikwa ọhụụ na Rally Trade, onye na-ere ahịa ntanetị mba ofesi.

en: This paved the way for Government activities to be hijacked, and the state legislature attacked on the orders of Political Godfathers'. Salaries could not be paid. Ecological funds were not left out by the ravaging Political Godfathers.
ibo: Nke a meghere ụzọ maka izochi ihe ndị gọọmentị na-eme, ndị omeiwu steeti wakporo iwu nke ' Ndokwa Ọchịchị ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị '. A gaghị akwụ ụgwọ ọnwa. Ndị nna nna ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na-emebi ihe ahapụghị ego ebe obibi.

en: In this interview with BENJAMIN ALADE, he speaks on opportunities in brokerage business, the need for Nigerians to have multiple streams of income and a regulatory environment for online brokers.
ibo: N'ajụjụ ọnụ ha na BENJAMINE ALADE, ọ na-ekwu okwu banyere ohere dị na azụmaahịa, mkpa ọ dị maka ndị Naịjirịa inwe ọtụtụ iyi ego ha na-enweta na usoro nchịkwa maka ndị na-ere ahịa n'ịntanetị.

en: What is Rally Trade all about?.
ibo: Kedu ihe ahịa Rally pụtara?

en: Rally Trade is a financial service brokerage company.
ibo: Rally Trade bụ ụlọ ọrụ na-akpata mmefu ego.

en: We have a platform where people can trade in global financial markets.
ibo: Anyị nwere usoro ebe ndị mmadụ nwere ike ịre ahịa n'ahịa ego ụwa.

en: It means looking at the global stock market- New York Stock Exchange, London Stock Exchange, French exchange, German exchange and other platforms where you can trade directly from Nigeria.
ibo: Ọ pụtara ire ahịa ụwa ọnụ- mgbanwe ahịa New York , mgbanwe ahịa London, mgbanwe French, mgbanwe Germany na usoro ndị ọzọ ebe ị nwere ike zụọ ahịa na Naịjirịa.

en: You can trade currencies, euro, pounds, and dollar.
ibo: Nwere ike gbanwere ego, uro, pawnd na dọla.

en: We all know that prices from each country are always fluctuating, which means you can trade them against themselves to make money.
ibo: Anyị niile maara na ọnụahịa nke mba ọ bụla na-agbanwe mgbe niile, nke pụtara na ị nwere ike zụọ ha megide onwe ha iji nweta ego.

en: Lastly, commodities- gold, cocoa, aluminium, rubber, not in their physical form, but virtual form, are all on the market platform.
ibo: Nke ikpe azu, ahia- gold, koko, alumini, roba, ọbụghị n'udi aru ha, kama udiri ihe, ha nile di n'elu ahia.

en: What do you see in Nigeria's economy at the moment?.
ibo: Kedu ihe ị hụrụ na akụnụba Naịjiria ugbu a ?.

en: Well, based on our own business, it is a good time to be in Nigeria and the reason is that we are going through a transition period.
ibo: Ọ dị mma, dabere na azụmahịa anyị, ọ bụ oge dị mma ịnọ na Naịjirịa na ihe kpatara ya bụ na anyị na-agafe oge mgbanwe.

en: We are in a serious problem now.
ibo: Anyị nọ n'oké nsogbu ugbu a.

en: First, people that have one job will find that the job alone can't help them again.
ibo: Na mbu, ndị nwere otu ọrụ ga-achọpụta na naanị ọrụ ahụ agaghị enyere ha aka ọzọ.

en: Secondly, there's no job, even for young and old alike.
ibo: Nke abuo, odighi oru, ọbụna dị ma ndị ntorobia ma ndị okenye.

en: We are in a time where we should be creating opportunities to solve the problems.
ibo: Anyị nọ n'oge anyị kwesịrị iwepụta ohere iji dozie nsogbu ndị ahụ.

en: This will mean creating several other sources of income that people never know about.
ibo: Nke a ga - apụta ịmepụta ụzọ ọzọ esi enweta ihe mmadụ na - amaghị.

en: It is a good time to be in business because we are now helping people now to start making money from a source they never thought existed.
ibo: Ọ bụ oge dị mma iji nọrọ n'azụmahịa n'ihi na anyị na-enyere ndị mmadụ aka ugbu a ịmalite ịkpata ego n'ebe ha na-echeghị na ọ dị.

en: While I was in school, I didn't know anything called trading, though it was existing, but because at that time, there was no technology to bring it here.
ibo: Mgbe m nọ n'ụlọ akwụkwọ, amaghị m ihe ọ bụla akpọrọ azụmaahịa, n'agbanyeghị na ọ dị adị, mana n'ihi na n'oge ahụ, enweghị teknọlọji wetara ya ebe a.

en: There was no Internet and mobile phone, so the trading could not come to Nigeria.
ibo: Enweghị intanetị na ekwentị mkpanaka, ya mere azụmaahịa ahụ abịaghị na Naịjirịa.

en: But now that the technology is here and everyone has a mobile phone, it's a good time to be in the business.
ibo: Mana ugbu a teknọlọji dị ebe a ma onye ọ bụla nwere ekwentị, ọ bụ oge dị mma ịnọ na azụmahịa ahụ.

en: Is the business related to foreign exchange trading?.
ibo: Azụmaahịa metụtara azụmahịa mgbanwe mba ọzọ?

en: That word foreign exchange (forex) is just one part of the market.
ibo: Mkpụrụ ego mba ọzọ gbanwere (forex) bụ naanị otu akụkụ nke ahịa ahụ.

en: If I say currency, I mean forex.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na m kwuo mkpụrụ ego, m na-ekwu Forex.

en: But somebody can be trading indices, that is not trading financial currency.
ibo: Mana mmadụ nwere ike na-azụ ahịa ihe, nke ahụ abụghị azụmaahịa ego.

en: So, foreign currency is just a part of the market and the business we do, not the whole market.
ibo: Yabụ, ego mba ofesi bụ naanị otu akụkụ nke ahịa na azụmaahịa anyị na-eme, ọ bụghị n'ahịa niile.

en: What opportunities for this business exist in Nigeria?.
ibo: Kedu ohere ndị dị na azụmahịa a na Naịjirịa?

en: There is great potential.
ibo: Enwere ikike dị ukwuu.

en: For any young person, I see the business as a career.
ibo: Maka ndị na-eto eto ọ bụla, m na-ahụ azụmaahịa dịka ọrụ.

en: There's something about making money, but the other side is the career, something that you can be proud of and would want others to be part of.
ibo: Onwere ihe gbasara inweta ego, mana akụkụ ọzọ bụ ọrụ aka, ihe inwere ike inya isi na ichoro ka ndị ọzọ soro na ya.

en: What is the role of technology in business operations?.
ibo: Kedu ọrụ teknọlọji dị na arụmọrụ azụmahịa ?.

en: Without mincing words, technology now is the bedrock of businesses.
ibo: Na-enweghị okwu ntinye, teknọlọji bụzi nnukwu azụmahịa.

en: Any company that is not technology-driven is headed for disaster.
ibo: ụlọ ọrụ ọ bụla na-ejighị nkà na ụzụ na-aga na-ebute mbibi.

en: Whenever we do our seminars, we always show people the fact that in the last 10 years, companies like Exxon Mobil, Shell, China Petroleum, were the biggest in the world then.
ibo: Mgbe ọ bụla anyị na-eme nzukọ ọmụmụ ihe anyị, anyị na-egosi ndị mmadụ eziokwu mgbe niile na afọ iri gara aga, ụlọ ọrụ dịka Exxon Mobil, Shell, China Petroleum, bụ ndị kasị ibu n'ụwa mgbe ahụ.

en: The biggest companies in the world now are Google, Microsoft, Apple.
ibo: ụlọ ọrụ kachasị ukwuu n'ụwa ugbu a bụ Google, Microsoft, na Apple.

en: Former classmates of President Muhammadu Buhari visited him in Daura, on Friday.
ibo: Onye ya na onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari gụkọrọ akwụkwọ bịara leta ya na Daura ụbọchị fraịde.

en: President Muhammadu Buhari played host to various groups, while in his hometown, Daura, in Katsina State, on Friday.
ibo: Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari kpụrụ ndị ọbịa otu dị iche iche n'obodo ya na Daura, Kastina steeti ụbọchị fraịde

en: The President was in his hometown during the week for the Sallah celebration.
ibo: Onye isi ala nọ n'obodo ya n'izu ahụ maka emume ekpere alakụba.

en: Among those who visited him were his former classmates; Chief Felix Idiga, Chairman of Good Governance Ambassadors of Nigeria (GOGAN); Chairmen of Association for Local Governments in Nigeria (ALGON), Katsina State; Members of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), Katsina State chapter; representatives of the Kano Traders Association, and representatives of five local governments in Daura Emirate.
ibo: Ndị so bịa nleta gunyere ndị ya na ha gụkọrọ akwụkwọ Felix Idiga, onye isi oche maka ọchịchị ọma ndị n'anọchị obodo Naijiria n'mba ọzọ. ndị isi oche otu jikọrọ ndị ime obodo dị na Nijiria, Katsina Steeti; ndị otu jikọrọ ndị otu Kraist na Naijiria (CAN), nke Katsina Steeti; ndị nnọchị anya ndị na-azu ahịa nke Kano na ndị nnọchị anya ime obodo ise dị na Daura.

en: Photographs of the visit were tweeted by Garba Shehu, the President's Senior Special Adviser on Media and Publicity. President Buhari received different Groups in Daura Katsina State earlier today, 24th Aug 2018*President Buhari with Former Classmates — Garba Shehu (@GarShehu) August 24, 2018
ibo: Garba Shehu bụ onye ndụmọdụ onye isi ala maka mgbasa ozi na mgbasa ozi twita gosiri foto nlete a. Onye isi ala Buhari nabatara ndị otu dị iche iche na Daura Katsina Steeti na mbido taa, 24 Ọgọst, 2018. Onye isi ala bụ Buhari na ndị ya na ha so gaa akwụkwọ.

en: President Buhari received different Groups in Daura Katsina State earlier today, 24th Aug 2018*President Buhari with Former Classmates
ibo: Onye isi ala Buhari nabatara ndị otu dị iche iche na Daura Katsina steeti na mbido taa, 24 Ọgọst,2018. Onye isi ala na ndị ya na ha gụkọrọ akwụkwọ

en: He left Daura for Abuja on Saturday morning.
ibo: Ọ hapụrụ Daura gawa Abuja n'ututu Satọde

en: Buhari Not Bothered About Criticisms By US, UK -Femi Adesina
ibo: Buhari enweghi nkụja gbasara nkatọ ndị US, UK -Femi Adesina

en: He also said the Nigerian Government would pay no concern to the ultimatum issued by a group of civil societies.
ibo: O kwukwara na gọọmentị Naịjirịa agaghị ege ntị na iwu nke ndị otu nkịtị nyere

en: Femi Adesina, Special Adviser to President Muhamadu Buhari on Media and Publicity, has said the Nigerian Government was not bothered by criticisms from the United States, United Kingdom and European Union over human rights violations in Nigeria.
ibo: Femi Adesina onye ndụmọdụ pụrụ iche nye onye isi ala Muhamadu Buhari na mgbasa ozi, ekwuola na gọọmentị Naịjirịa atụghị ụjọ banyere nkatọ ndị mba Unaited steeti, Unaited Kindom na Uropian Uniọn gbasara mmegide iwu banyere mmadụ na Naịjirịa.

en: Speaking on Channels Television, Adesina said, 'We are not answerable to the US, UK or EU.
ibo: N'ikwu okwu na onyonyo nke Chanel, Adesina kwuru 'Anyị anaghị aza ajụjụ US, UK ma ọ bụ EU'.

en: We are Nigeria, a sovereign country.
ibo: Anyị bụ ndị obodo Naịjirịa, mba kwụrụ onwe ya.

en: Those countries and entities have issues of their own.
ibo: Obodo na otu ndị ahụ nwere nsogbu nke ha.

en: Let them deal with their issues.
ibo: Ka ha mezie nsogbu nke ha

en: Let Nigeria also deal with her internal issues.
ibo: Ka mba Naịjirịa meziekwa nke ha.

en: We are not answerable to them.
ibo: Anyị agaghị aza ha ajụjụ.

en: He also said the Nigerian Government would pay no concern to the ultimatum issued by a group of civil societies.
ibo: O kwukwara na gọọmentị Naịjirịa agaghị ege ntị na iwu ndị otu nkịtị nyere.

en: He said that genuine issues will be looked into.
ibo: O kwuru na a ga-eleba anya na nsogbu ndị dị mkpa.

en: We have had instances in which the government had to reverse itself because there were concerns raised.
ibo: Anyi enwego oge gọọmentị gbanwere mkpebi ya makana enwere nsogbu.

en: It shows that the government is responsive but you cannot listen to a babble .
ibo: O gosiri na gọọmentị na-azahachi ngwangwa mana ịgaghị ege ntị na ihe na-enweghị isi.

en: It will distract you from what you are doing .
ibo: Ọ ga emegharị gị anya n'ihe ị na-eme.

en: Adesina also said that Prof Wole Soyinka, who had been a vocal critic of the lawlessness of the administration, was entitled to his opinion.
ibo: Adesina kwukwara na Ọka mmụta Wole Soyinka, onye bụbu onye na-ekwusi ike na mmebi iwu nke ọchịchị ahụ nwere ike ịnwe uche nke ya.

en: He added, We respect Prof Soyinka .
ibo: Ọ gbakwunyere, 'anyị na-asọpụrụ ọka mmụta Soyinka.

en: You don't have too many of them in the country or even on the continent.
ibo: E nweghị ọtụtụ n'ime ha n'obodo ma ọ bụ na kọnịnentị.

en: He is an avatar and he is well respected but his opinion will remains his opinion.
ibo: Ọ bụ odogwu na onye a na-akwanyere ugwu nke ukwuu ma uche ya ga abụgide uche ya.

en: It will be considered and if there are things to act on, we will act on them .
ibo: A ga-atụle ya ma ọ bụrụ na enwere ihe anyị ga-eme, anyị ga-eme ya.

en: Buhari sets aside Nigeria's problems, celebrates 30 years of marriage with wife, Aisha .
ibo: Buhari wezugara nsogbu Naịjirịa wee mee emume afọ 30 nke alụmdi na nwunye ya bụ Aisha.

en: On Monday, President Muhammadu Buhari 'temporarily set aside' Nigeria's many problems to celebrate 30 years of marriage with his wife, Aisha .
ibo: N'ụbọchị Mọnde, onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari wezugara nsogbu Naịjirịa wee mee emume afọ 30 alụmdi ya na nwunye ya bụ Aisha.

en: In a tweet on the President's verified Twitter handle, Buhari posted a photograph of himself and the First Lady of Nigeria during their younger days together .
ibo: Na akara twita nke onye isi ala, Buhari gosiri foto ya na nwunye onye isi ala Aisha mgbe ha bidoro dịka okoro na agbọghọ

en: In reference to the photo in the tweet, Buhari said, 'Today, on our 30th wedding anniversary, I pray for Allah's continued peace and blessings in our home and family.' Today, on our 30th Wedding Anniversary, I pray for Allah's continued peace and blessings in our home and family. — Muhammadu Buhari (@MBuhari) December 2, 2019
ibo: N'ihe banyere foto ahụ na twit, Buhari kwuru 'Taa, alụmdi na nwunye anyị gbara afọ 30, a na m ekpe ka udo na ngọzi nke Chukwu ga n'ihu na ezinụlọ anyị .'

en: Today, on our 30th Wedding Anniversary, I pray for Allahâs continued peace and blessings in our home and family.
ibo: Taa, alụmdi na nwunye anyị gbara afọ 30, a na m ekpe ka udo na ngọzi nke Chukwu ga n'ihu na ezinụlọ anyị .

en: Aisha, who has sometimes criticised her husband's government, also pushed those hard feelings aside to celebrate the milestone on her Twitter handle by posting a short video captioned '30 years of togetherness .
ibo: Aisha onye na-akatọ gọọmentị di ya mgbe ụfọdụ kwapụrụ obi ụfụ ndị ahụ iji mee emume ije a na akara twita ya site n'itinye ihe nkiri dị mkpirimkpi isi okwu ya bụ 'Njịkọ ọnụ 30'.

en: Buhari Slowing Down Nigeria's Progress – Ondo Cleric
ibo: Buhari n'egbochi agamn'ihu Naijiria - Ụkọchukwu Ondo

en: Speaking at a programme on Thursday in Akure, Giwa said the ruling All Progressives Congress government led by Buhari had made Nigerians regret voting them into power in 2015 due to its unfriendly polices.
ibo: Mgbe ọ na-ekwu okwu na mmemme ụbọchị Tọzdee na Akure, Giwa kwuru na mkpebi ndị gọọmentị All Progressive Congress n'okwu bekee nke Buhari na-edu mere ka ndị Naịjirịa kwaa ụta maka ịtụnyere ha vootu n'ọchịchị na 2015 n'ihi ụkpụrụ adighị mma.

en: Senior Pastor of Awaiting The Second Coming Of Jesus Christ, a church based in Akure, Ondo State, Adewale Giwa, has said President Muhammadu Buhari was slowing down Nigeria's wheel of progress of Nigeria following his continued silence on human rights abuses and violation of court orders under his watch.
ibo: Onye isi nchụ-aja nke ndị na-eche ọbịbịa nke abụọ nke Jizọs Kraịst, otu ụka dị na Akure. O kwuru na ya na-agbagha usoro ọganihu nke Naijiria na-esochi ịgbachi nkịtị banyere mpụ ndị ruuru mmadụ na imebi iwu ụlọikpe n'okpuru nche ya .

en: Speaking at a programme on Thursday in Akure, Giwa said the ruling All Progressives Congress government led by Buhari had made Nigerians regret voting them into power in 2015 due to its unfriendly polices.
ibo: Mgbe ọ na-ekwu okwu na mmemme ụbọchị Tọzdee na Akure, Giwa kwuru na mkpebi ndị gọọmentị All Progressive Congress n'okwu bekee nke Buhari na-edu mere ka ndị Naịjirịa kwaa ụta maka ịtụnyere ha vootu n'ọchịchị na 2015 n'ihi ụkpụrụ adighị mma.

en: He said, Nigeria is a blessed country but the leaders have failed to walk on God's paths.
ibo: O kwuru na 'Naịjirịa bụ obodo agọziri agọzi mana ndị ndu ajụ iso ụzọ nke Chukwu.

en: If you are not a wicked leader, you would not have been watching your tribe killing another tribe without bringing them to justice.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ị bụghị ajọ onye ndu, ịgaghị na-eleli ebo gị n'emeghị ka ikpe ruo ha

en: If you are a good leader, you would not have jailed innocent people and allowed killers to move freely in the country .
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ị bụ ezigbo onye ndu, ịgahị atụ ndị aka ha dị ọcha nga na-ekwu ka ndị na-egbu mmadụ na-aga n'enweghi mgbochi obula n'obodo .

en: If you are a God-fearing man, you would have fulfilled all the promises you made during the electioneering campaigns .
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ị bụ nwoke na-atụ egwu Chukwu, ị ga-emezu nkwa niile I kwere n'oge mgbasa ozi nhọpụta gị .

en: This style of leadership is slowing down Nigeria's progress .
ibo: Udi ọchịchị a n' egbochi agamnihu Naijiria .

en: Buhari's Fight Against Corruption Profoundly Disappointing - Ex-Presidential Adviser
ibo: Agha Buhari na-ebu megide mpụ bụ nke na emechu iru - Onye bụbu Onye ndụmọdụ Onye-Isi Ala

en: A former political adviser in the Presidency, Dr Usman Bugaje, has described President Muhammadu Buhari's fight against corruption as one that is profoundly disappointing.
ibo: Onye bụbu onye ndụmọdụ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na Onye isi ala, Dr Usman Bugaje akọwaala ọgụ Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari megide mpụ bụ nke na-emechu iru nke ukwu .

en: Bugaje said this while speaking at the 25th anniversary of the Serikin Fulani of Lagos State, Dr Mohammad Bambado II.
ibo: Bugaje kwuru nke a mgbe ọ na-ekwu okwu na ncheta afọ iri abụọ na ise nke Serikin Fulani nke Lagos State, Dr Mohammad Bambado II .

en: Bugaje also condemned the incessant attacks by Boko Haram sect in the country, incompetent politicians whose only way of winning is through manipulation of religion and ethnicity .
ibo: Bugaje katọrọ mwakpo ọjọọ nke ndị otu Boko Haram na-eme na mba ahụ, ndị ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na-enweghị isi nke otu ụzọ ha ga-esi merie bụ site na iji nkewa nke okpukpe na agbụrụ.

en: He said every Nigerian must be worried that the fight against corruption was being lost .
ibo: O kwuru na onye Naijiria ọ bụla ga-enwe mgbaka arụ na ọgụ a na-alụ megide mpụ bụ na-efu.

en: He stated, The fight against corruption is, to say the least profoundly disappointing .
ibo: O kwuru, ọgụ a na-alụ megide mpụ, n' ikwu ya n' obere, na emechu ihu .

en: He urged the government to find a lasting solution to rising unemployment in the country, saying if not arrested, it poses a big threat to the country, Daily Trust reports.
ibo: Ọ gbara gọọmentị ume ka ọ chọta ihe usoro ga-adịgide maka enweghị ọrụ na-arịwanye elu na mba ahụ, na-ekwu na ọ bụrụ na ejideghị ya, ọ bụ nnukwu ihe iyi egwu na mba ahụ, Daily Trust na-akọ.

en: Buhari's Secret Emissaries To Sowore Proved Mission Impossible By Bayo Oluwasanmi
ibo: Ndị ozi-nzuzo nke Buhari zigaara Sowore gosịrị na ọ bụ ozi agaghị aga - site n'aka Bayo Oluwasanmi

en: President Buhari's emissaries to Sowore proved mission impossible because the history of tyranny is also the history of its eventual defeat.
ibo: Ndị ozi President Buhari na Sowore gosipụtara na ọ gaghị ekwe omume n'ihi na akụkọ ntanetị nke ọchịchị aka ike bụkwa akụkọ banyere mmeri ya mechara mezuo .

en: The Great King of Persia was checked at Marathon and Salamis.
ibo: Egochiri Eze Ukwu Pesia na Marathon na Salamis .

en: Napoleon was checked at Waterloo.
ibo: Egbochinwuru Napoleon na Waterloo .

en: Hitler was checked on D-Day.
ibo: Egbochiri Hitler na D-Day .

en: The Soviet Empire collapsed .
ibo: Ọchịchị Soviet dara .

en: The tyrant dies and his rule is over, the martyr dies and his rule begins . - Soren Kierkegaard
ibo: Onye ọchịchị aka ike nwụrụ, ọchịchị ya adaa, onye nwụrụ n'ihi okwukwe ya nwụrụ, ọchịchị ya amalite - Asiren Kierkegaard

en: Last week, Premium Times reported that President Muhammadu Buhari on two separate occasions sent secret emissaries to Omoyele Sowore in the Department of State Services ' gulag 'to extract a commitment from him to back down on the 'revolution now' protest as a precondition for his release ' .
ibo: Na ngwụcha izu, Premium Times kọrọ na Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari zigaara ndị ozi-nzuzo na Ọrụ 'gulag' iji wepụta nkwa sitere n'aka ya ịkwado ngagharị iwe 'ugbu a' dịka ihe mgbochi maka ya hapụ ' .

en: Similarly, those who engage in the sale of these items are also warned to desist from such business as buyers, users and sellers are culpable under the law.
ibo: N' otu aka ahụ a na-adọ ndị na-etinye aka na ire ihe ndị a aka na ntị ka ha zere azụmaahịa dịka ndị na-azụ ahịa, ndị na-eji ya eme ihe, ndị na-ere ahịa dị n'okpuru iwu.

en: He added that the police was ready to secure the lives and properties of citizens and residents of the state during Yuletide.
ibo: Ọ gbakwụnyere na ndị uwe ojii adịla njikere maka nchekwa ndụ na ihe onwunwe nke ụmụ amaala na ndị bi n'steeti n'oge ekeresimesi.

en: Climate Change: Ministry Of Environment, Eko Carbon Exchange Partner To Reduce Emission In Nigeria
ibo: Mgbanwe ihu igwe: ulo oru na ahu makagburugburu ebe obibi, onye otu ga agbanwe ikuku kabọ belata na Naịjirịa

en: The initiative, which was announced during the 2019 United Nations Climate Change Conference of Parties in Madrid, Spain, also aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2030.
ibo: Ebumnuche nke ekwuputara n'afọ 2019, oge ogbako mgbanwe ihu igwe nke otu mba ụwa na ndị òtù na Madrid, Spain, na-ezube iji nweta nhichapụ ikuku site na 2030.

en: In a bid to reduce the effects of climate change in Nigeria and indeed the entire African continent, the Federal Ministry of Environment and other government agencies have partnered with Eko Carbon Exchange to achieve the target.
ibo: Na nkwenye iji belata nsonaazụ mgbanwe ihu igwe na Naịjirịa na mba Afrika dum, ụlọ ọrụ gọọmentị etiti na-ahu maka gburugburu ebe obibi na ụlọ ọrụ gọọmentị ndị ọzọ na mgba Eko kabon jikoro iji mezuo ebumnuche.

en: The initiative, which was announced during the 2019 United Nations Climate Change Conference of Parties in Madrid, Spain, also aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2030.
ibo: Ebumnuche nke ekwuputara n'afọ 2019, oge ogbako mgbanwe ihu igwe nke otu mba ụwa na ndị òtù na Madrid, Spain, na-ezube iji nweta nhichapụ ikuku site na 2030.

en: The UN Conference in Spain attracted African and international experts and sustainability actors including from Nigeria, who all discussed how to protect the continent from the harsh effects of climate change.
ibo: Mgbakọ otu mba ụwa na Spain dọtara ndị ọkachamara n' Afrika na mba ụwa na ndị na-eme ihe nkwado gụnyere ndị si Naijirịa tụlere otu esi echekwa kọntinent na mmetụta ọjọọ nke mgbanwe ihu igwe.

en: Managing Director of Eko Carbon Exchange, Mr Innocent Azih, disclosed that the initiative, being the first in West Africa, was mobilising to harness the opportunities in low-carbon development across all economic sectors in Nigeria, starting with solid waste and transport sectors.
ibo: Onye na-ahụ maka nhazi mgbanwe kabon Eko, mazị Innocent Azih kpughere na atụmatụ a bụ nke mbụ na ọdịda Afrika , na-achịkọta onwe ya iji jigide ohere dị na mmepe nke obere kabon gafere mpaghara akụ na ụba na Naijiria, na-amalite site na mkpofu siri ike na mpaghara njem.

en: He said this will also serve as a regional vehicle for mobilising finance for low-carbon economic development for West African economies through the Clean Development Mechanism.
ibo: O kwuru na nke a ga-adịkwa ka ụgbọ mpaghara a maka ịkpọkọta ego maka nkwalite ego obere-kabon maka ọdịda anyanwu site na nkwalite usoro ịdị ọcha.

en: Azih stated, 'The objective is to mobilise the necessary resource pool and low-carbon finance required for greening all economic sectors.'
ibo: Azih kwupụtara 'ebumnuche bụ ịchịkọta akụ dị mkpa yana ego obere kabon a chọrọ iji dozie ngalaba akụ niile.

en: Head of Climate Change Mitigation in the Ministry of Environment, Hajia Aisha Jibril, revealed the readiness of the ministry to work with the Exchange to enable Nigeria achieve the nationally determined contributions through projects implementation that are fully mainstreamed.
ibo: Onye isi nke mbelata onodu mgbanwe ihu igwe n'ụlọ ọrụ na-ahụ maka gburugburu ebe obibi oriaku Aisha Jibril, kpughere njikere nke ngalaba ahụ iji rụọ ọrụ iji mee ka Naijiria nweta mmezu ụtụ obodo dị iche iche na-atụ site na mmejuputa ọrụ e ji n'aka.

en: She described efforts made by the ministry to include policy incentives, education and awareness of actors through climate change desks at state levels, to development of the Nigerian carbon emission registry.
ibo: Ọ kọwara mbọ niile ụlọ ọrụ ahụ gbara iji tinye akwụkwọ amụma, mmụta na ịmara ndị na-eme ihe site na okpokoro mgbanwe ihu igwe na ọkwa steeti, na mmepe ndekọ kabon nke Naijiria.

en: She urged stakeholders to follow Eko Carbon Exchange's lead and partner with the ministry to ensure early realisation of the registry.
ibo: Ọ gbara ndị isi obodo ume ka ha gbasoo ụzọ ntụgharị kabon Eko ma soro ụlọ ọrụ ha jịkọọ aka iji hụ na oge ndekọ malitere n'oge.

en: Also speaking at the UN meeting, Chief Executive Officer of Natural Eco Capital, Dr Eugene Itua, in his submission noted that tremendous emission reduction programmes have been on in Lagos State through the replacement of outdated mass transport vehicles with more modern and energy-efficient buses.
ibo: N'ikwu okwu na nzukọ UN, onye isi ndị isi ala obodo Eko, Dkt. Eugene Itua, na ntinye ya kwuru na mmemme mbelata dị rii na Legos steeti site n'iji ụgbọ ọhụrụ dochie ụgbọ njem ndị ochie

en: Stakeholders noted that finance remained a major challenge to scaling green investments but suggested that the best approach was non-monetary strategy in which financing packages for low-carbon consumption comes with credit and insurance.
ibo: Ndị new obodo kwuru na ego kabụ nnukwu nsogbu iji bido ọrụ mana ha tụrụ alo na ụzọ kacha mma bụ atụmatụ enweghị ego eji etinye maka oriri kabon na-abịa na ịzụ n'aka na mkpuchi

en: Closure Of Border Cannot End Smuggling, ECOWAS Tells Nigeria
ibo: Mmechi oke ala agaghị akwụsi ịzụbata ihe ECOWAS na-agwa Naịjirịa.

en: Disagreeing with President Buhari, ECOWAS stated that the border closure would also affect the implementation of the Africa Continental Free Trade Area Act signed by the country.
ibo: N'ekweteghi na onye isi ala Buhari, ECOWAS kwupụtara na mmechi oke a ga-emetụta iwu mmejupụta azụmahịa anaghị ego nke kọntịnentị Afrika nke obodo ahụ binyere aka.

en: Nigeria Cameroon border
ibo: Oke Naijiria na Kemeron

en: The Economic Community Of West African States has told the Nigerian Government that closing its border with other neighbouring countries cannot prevent the smuggling of goods and products into Nigeria.
ibo: Otu jịkọrọ akụ mba ọwụwa anyanwụ nke Afrika agwala gọọmentị Naịjirịa na Mmechi oke ala agaghị akwụsi ịzụbata ihe na Naịjirịa.

en: President Muhammadu Buhari had announced the closure of the border, saying that it would prevent bringing products into the country illegally and also help boost the patronage of locally made products.
ibo: Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari ekwupụtala mmechi okeala na-ekwu na ọ ga-egbochi ibubata ngwaahịa na obodo na-ezighi ezi ma nyekwa aka ịkwalite ngwaahịa nke obodo.

en: Disagreeing with President Buhari, ECOWAS stated that the border closure would also affect the implementation of the Africa Continental Free Trade Area Act signed by the country.
ibo: N'ekweteghi na onye isi ala Buhari, ECOWAS kwupụtara na mmechi oke a ga-emetụta iwu mmejupụta azụmahịa anaghị ego nke kọntịnentị Afrika nke obodo ahụ binyere aka.

en: In a statement on Tuesday, the bloc said,'The ECOWAS Parliament calls for compliance with community provisions and the reopening of borders and a coordinated fight against smuggling in the region.
ibo: Na nkwupụta na Tuzdee, òtù a kwuru na 'ọgbakọ omebe iwu ECOWAS kpọrọ oku ka ekwenye na usoro obodo yana imepe okeala na njikwa ọgụ megide ndị na-ezubata ihe na mpaghara obodo.

en: The root causes of this recurrent situation must be studied with a view to finding a permanent solution.
ibo: A ga-amụrịrị ihe na-akpata onodu a mgbe niile iji chọpụta ndozi ga adigide.

en: Comparing Omoyele Sowore's #RevolutionNow To Boko Haram Insurgency, A Needless Escalation By Kayode Ogundamisi
ibo: Itule 'mgbanwe ugbua Omoyele Sowore na nsogbu ndị Boko Haram, mkparịta na-enweghị isi - site na Kayode Ogundamisi

en: Now is the time for the government to stop the disobedience of court orders, no one is above the law including activists and people in government .
ibo: Ugbua bụ oge gọọmentị ga akwụsị ịnụpụrụ iwu ụlọ ikpe isi, enweghi onye ka iwu nkea gunyere ndị na-akwado ọrụ na ndị nọ na gọọmentị.

en: if you must prosecute Sowore and others then let it be open, free and transparent.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na a ga akpọgide Sowore na ndị ọzọ, aga eme ya n' ụzọ ghee anya oghe ma kwurukwa ọtọ, ma ziekwa ezie

en: Otherwise, thus far the state has made a mess of the case, this is looking more like persecution than prosecution.
ibo: Ewezuga nke a, ruo ugbua, steeti emebiela okwu a, nke a dizi ka mkpagbụ karịa ịnwụcha.

en: If the government has a thinking cap on, it will #FreeSoworeNow or at the least let the case in court continue without infractions .
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị nwere ikike iche echiche, ọ ga # atọpụ Sowore ugbu a ma ọ bụ opeka mpe hapụ ụlọ ikpe ka ha gaa n'ihu n'enweghi mmebi iwu obula .

en: I read the statement by the Presidency on the Sowore-Bakare treason trial.
ibo: A gụrụ m nkwupụta onye isi ala gbasara ikpe Sowore-Bakare .

en: This statement is a needless escalation, particularly the comparison with Boko Haram insurgency.
ibo: Okwu a bụ mmụba na-enweghị isi, ọkachasị ma e jiri ya tụnyere nsogbu ndị Boko Haram.

en: If the allegations are completely true, why is the Department of State Services disobeying court orders?
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ebubo ahụ bụ eziokwu, gịnị kpatara na ngalaba nke ọrụ gọọmentị ji enupụrụ iwu ụlọ ikpe isi?

en: One would think the state will be eager to bring its evidence to the open.
ibo: Mmadụ ga-eche na steeti ga-achọsi ike iweta ihe akaebe ya niile.

en: If the Presidency and the DSS are confident of Omoyele Sowore's ability and capabilities to 'violently overthrow the government', why can't the state simply let the judicial process proceed without interference as seen in the agency's disobedience of two court orders and the recent show of force by carrying out an arrest when you could have easily invited Sowore or picked him up at his residence in Abuja with a court warrant?
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na onyeisi ala na ndị DSS kwenyesiri ike na Omoyele Sowore nwere ike 'ịchụda gọọmentị steeti n'ike', gịnị mere na steeti enweghị ike ikwe ka usoro ikpe gaa n'ihu n'enweghị nsogbu ọ bụla dịka egosiri na nnupu isi nke otu a nke iwu ụlọ ikpe abụọ na ihe ike egosiri site na ijide ya mgbe ị nwere ike ịkpọ Sowore oku ma ọ bụ bulie ya n'ụlọ ya na Abuja site na ikike ụlọ ikpe.

en: The President Muhammadu Buhari government is making a grave mistake, attracting negative local and international commentaries, a distraction the government does not need at any time, particularly now.
ibo: Ọchịchị onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari na emehie nke ukwuu, na-adọta ndị na-ekwu okwu na adighị mma na mpaghara na mba ọzọ, ihe ndọpụ uche gọọmentị adighị mkpa n'oge maka gọọmentị ịkwụsị ige ntị n'olu ọgbahara ma malite igere olu amamihe ntị.

en: Now is the time for the government to stop listening to the The Attorney-General of the Federation and Minister of Justice, Abubakar Malami (SAN), should review the Sowore and Bakare's case file and do the needful (drop the treason charges) and if the state is confident of its case, then let the case proceed in a transparent and open manner.
ibo: Onye isi ndị ọka ikpe na mịnịsta nke ikpe ziri ezi Abubakar Malami kwesịrị ịtule okwu ikpe nke Sowore na Bakare ma mee ihe ekwesiri ime (tụfụọ ebubo aghụghọ) ma ọ bụrụ na steeti kwenyesiri ike na okwu ya, ya hapụzie okwu ikpe ahụ gaa n'ụzọ doro anya

en: When Sowore committed what was an obvious infraction such as defacing a public property in Lagos, an offence that could get an easy conviction in a Lagos environmental court, the government looked the other way
ibo: Mgbe Sowore mehiere bụ mgbe o mebiri ihe oha na Legọs, mmejọ nke nwere ike inweta nkwupụta dị mfe n'ụlọ ikpe n'ahụ maka gburugburu Legọs, gọọmentị lere anya n'ụzọ nke ọzọ.

en: A sign the state isn't interested in enforcing our laws but to bring up charges with stringent conditions that can drag on for long and keep alleged offenders in jail awaiting trial for a long period.
ibo: Ihe ngosi na steeti enweghị mmasị na ịmanye iwu anyị kama iji bulie ebubo na ọnọdụ siri ike nke nwere ịdọrọ ogologo oge ma debe ndị a na-ebo ebubo na mkpesa n'ụlọ mkọrọ na-eche oge ikpe.

en: The treason charges the state is now relying on is unlikely to stand in an open trial, thus the request for a secret trial and anonymous witnesses.
ibo: Eleghi anya, ebubo nke steeti na-adabere na agaghị eguzonwu ikpe, yabụ arịrịọ maka ikpe nzuzo na onye akaebe na-enweghi aha

en: Sowore's followership on social media run into millions of people who find it easy to 'comment' 'like' 'follow' his broadcasts, but no evidence the millions have translated into a mass movement.
ibo: Ndị na-eso Sowore na igwe mgbasa ozi na-agbaba nde mmadụ ndị ọ dịrị mfe ịtụnye okwu, ihu na anya na iso mgbasa ozi ya, mana enweghi akaebe na nde mmadụ ahụ tụgharịrị bụrụ otu nghagharị

en: Nigerians are disappointed, angry and have always wanted a change but not reckless enough to follow an unplanned idealistic 'revolution' with no road map, even the DSS should have known this.
ibo: Ndị Naịjirịa na-enwe nkụda mmụọ, na-ewe iwe ma na-achọ mgbanwe mgbe niile mana ha adịghị nzuzu nke isoro mgbanwe ebummuche na-enweghị atụmatụ na ụzọ ọbụna ndị DSS kwesiri ịma nke a.

en: The danger to Nigeria isn't the Sowore and his group, the government should review how the intelligent agencies arrive at largely fictitious 'security reports'.
ibo: Ihe egwu dị na Naịjirịa abụghị Sowore na ndị otu ya, gọọmentị kwesiri ịtụle ka ụlọ ndị ọgụgụ isi si erute na akụkọ nchebe zuru oke.

en: Now it is the Nigerian Government and the DSS that are promoting #RevolutionNow by aiming to kill a fly with a nuclear bomb with attendant negative impact. It is the government now ascribing some imaginary powers to Omoyele Sowore and his armless group, a sign of insecurity on the part of the government.
ibo: Ugbu a, ọ bụ gọọmentị Naịjirịa na ndị DSS na-akwalite mgbanwe ugbu a site na ịchọ iji ogbunigwe gbuo ijiji. ọ bụ gọọmentị na-ebuputa ike ụfọdụ n'echiche nye Sowore na ndị otu ya, ihe na-egosi enweghị ntụkwasị obi nke gọọmentị.

en: Each infraction by the government will attract more sympathy.
ibo: Mmebi ọ bụla nke gọọmentị ga-eme ka e nwekuo ọmịiko.

en: It is the case of David against Goliath.
ibo: Ọ bụ ikpe Devid na Goloyat.

en: Give this group a designated space to protest and a platform to vent and you will see not all Nigerians agree with some of the solutions being proffered by the group.
ibo: Nye ndị otu a ohere iji mee ngagharị iwe na oghere ịkpọ okwu aha, ị ga-ahụ na ọ bụghị ndị Naịjirịa niile kwenyere na ụzọ ụfọdụ ndị otu ahụ kwenyere.

en: Omoyele Sowore and his group are being lionised by the state.
ibo: Steeti na-esogbu Omoyele Sowore na ndị out ya.

en: Nigeria's elite security is now acting like a gangster enforcer.
ibo: Nchebe oke nke Naịjirịa na-eme ugbu a dịka nke ndị moekome.

en: The government should review its so-called counter-insurgency strategy and stop applying failed tactics.
ibo: Gọọmentị kwesịrị ịtụle atụmatụ a sị na ọ bụ oke ọgụ ma kwụsị itinye atụmatụ ndị dara ada.

en: The irony is that the government already had half of what it wants legally by securing one of the harshest bail conditions against a suspect.
ibo: Ihe nzuzu bụ na gọọmentị enwegolarị ọkara nke ihe ọ chọrọ n'ụzọ iwu site na ichebe otu n'ime ọnọdụ mgbapụta kachasị sie ike megide onye na-enyo enyo.

en: The judge had in a ruling on October 4 granted Sowore bail in the sum of N100m and two sureties in the same amount and barred him from travelling out of Abuja.
ibo: Onye ọka ikpe ahụ kpebiri na Ọktoba 4, nyere Sowore ịgbazinye ego puku nde naira na ndị ga ekwechitere ya nkwa abụọ kwụọkwa ụgwọ a wee gbochie ya ịpụ Abuja.

en: Why rearrest Sowore when he's already restricted to Abuja ?
ibo: Gịnị mere a ga-eji tuarịa Sowore nga ebe egbochiela ya ịpụ Abuja ?

en: Is the DSS saying it does not have the capability to mount surveillance on one man in Abuja ?
ibo: Ndị DSS ha na-akọwa na ha enweghị ike ilegide otu onye nọ n'Abuja anya .

en: For the record, I am no supporter of #RevolutionNow.
ibo: Maka ndekọ, abụghị m onye na-akwado #RevolutionNow .

en: I have seen how recklessness can destabilise fragile states but evidence of alleged infractions is better presented in court without the state acting as if it is insecure and desperate to keep a
ibo: Ahụtalam etu enweghị uche si emebi steeti ndị na-adighị ike mana igosi nke ọma ebubo mpụ n'ụlọ ikpe karịa steeti ịdị na-eme ka egwu ọnatụ ya bia na-emekwa ihe niile nke gunyere igbanya iwu iji tụọ olu obula kwuliterenu nga .

en: Now is the time for the government to stop the disobedience of court orders, no one is above the law including activists and people in government.

en: But if you must prosecute Sowore and others then let it be open, free and transparent. Otherwise, thus far the state has made a mess of the case, this is looking more like persecution than prosecution.

en: Dammy Krane Granted N50,000 Bail By Court

en: Hip-hop artiste, Johnson Oyindamola widely known as Dammy Krane, has been granted bail in the sum of N50,000 with one surety in like sum.

en: He was arraigned at the Igbosere Magistrate Court in Lagos over a three-count allegation bothering on breach of public peace.
ibo: Akpọrọ ya n'ụlọ ikpe ọkaikpe Igbosere dị na Legọs maka ebubo atọ nke bụ imebi udo nke oha.

en: The musician was accused of making statements capable of breaching public peace and threatening the lives of staff of Merrybet Gold Limited on July 25.
ibo: Eboro onye na-agụ egwu ahụ maka ikwu okwu nwere ike imebi udo oha nakwa ịyị ndụ ndị ọrụ Merrybet Gold limited egwu na 25 Julai.

en: According to the prosecutor, the offence contravened sections 301, 412 and 168 of the Criminal Law of Lagos State of Nigeria, 2015.
ibo: Dika onye ọka ikpe siri kwuo, mmehe ahụ megidere akụkụ 301, 412 na 168 nke iwu mpụ nke Steeti Legos nke Naịjirịa, afọ 2015.

en: He pleaded not guilty to the charges preferred against him by the police.
ibo: O kwereghị na ebubo ndị uwe ojii boro ya.

en: His lawyer, Adebayo Oniyelu, while applying for his bail, said the defendant was 'a well-known musician who had not been convicted of any crime in the past'.
ibo: Onye ọka ikpe ya bụ Adebayo Oniyelu mgbe ọ na-achọ ịgbapụta ya kwuru na onye ọ na-agbachịtere bụ ' onye egwu a ma ama nke na-enwebeghi ikpe ọbụla maka mpụ akpọrọ ya n'oge gara aga'.

en: He also said that the defendant would not interfere with the prosecution of the matter if granted bail, noting that Dami Krane had been in prison custody since Friday.
ibo: ọ sịkwara na onye o na-agbachịtere agaghị egbochi ndị ka iwu ikpe okwu a ma ọ bụrụ na enye ya ohere mgbapụta, na-ekwupụta na Dami Krane anọrọla n'ụlọ mkpọrọ kemgbe Fraịde.

en: Opposing the application for bail, prosecuting counsel J. I Enang, said he ordinarily would not have objected to the application for bail if it were not a national issue.
ibo: N'imegide akwụkwọ mgbapụta ya, kansul na-ekpechite ọnụ bụ J. I. Enang kwuru na ọ karaghị imegide mgbapụta ya ma ọ bụrụ na ọ bụghị okwu obodo.

en: But when asked how the case was a national issue, Enang said it would be revealed at the right time.
ibo: Mana mgbe a juru ya out o si bụrụ okwu obodo, Enang siri na aga-ekughe ya mgbe oge ruru.

en: He said, 'Your Honour, while coming to court today, I already heard it on the radio that a musician was to be arraigned today, it is even an international issue.'
ibo: O kwuru 'Nsọpụrụ gị, mgbe m na-abịa ụlọ ikpe taa, anụburum ya na redio na aga-awuchị onye na-agụ egwu taa, ọ bụ okwu mba ụwa'.

en: Interjecting, Oniyelu informed the court that the case was one of breach of contract.
ibo: N'isukwunye okwu, Oniyelu gwara ụlọ ikpe na ikpe ahụ bụ okwu imebi nkwekọrịta.

en: 'The musician performed for the complainant and they are owing to him N1m.
ibo: Onye na-akpọ egwu ahụ kpọrọ ndị kpọpụrụ ya ikpe egwu, ha ji ya otu nde naira.

en: 'He reached out to them to request for his money but they refused to listen to him, forcing him to go on air to say that they were owing to him. The next thing that happened was his arrest.'
ibo: ' ọ gakwuru ha ịrịọ maka ego ya mana ha juru ige ya nti, nke manyere ya ịga n'ikuku kwuo na ha ji ya ụgwọ. Ihe mere ọzọ bụ nwuchi ya.

en: The magistrate, A. F. O Botoku, adjourned the matter until October 11 for the commencement of trial .
ibo: Onye ọka ikpe bụ A. F. O. Botoku yigharịrị okwu ahụ ruo Oktoba 11, maka ịmalite ikpe.

en: October 1, 1960 - The day Nigeria gained independence from Britain
ibo: Oktoba 1, 1960 - Ụbọchị Naịjirịa nwetere nwere onwe ha n'aka Britain

en: January 15, 1966 - When the first of what would become a tradition of military coups occurred
ibo: Jenuwarị 15, 1966 - Mbido nnara ọchịchị ndị agha

en: July 6, 1967 - The official start of the 30-month Nigeria-Biafra war .
ibo: Julaị 6, 1967, - Mgbe agha ọnwa iri atọ Nigeria-Biafra bidoro

en: January 15, 1970 - The official end of the civil war .
ibo: Jenuwarị 15, 1970, - Mgbe agha obodo kwusiri .

en: On May 27, 50 years ago, Yakubu Gowon, who served as head of state of Nigeria from 1966 to 1975, perhaps in anticipation of the audacious move by the Military Governor of the Eastern Region of Nigeria, Lt. Col. Emeka Ojukwu, announced the division of Nigeria into 12 states from four regions.
ibo: Na Mee 27, afọ iri ise gara aga, Yakubu Gowon, onye chịrị dịka onye isi ala Naịjirịa site n'afọ 1966 ruo 1975, ikekwa n'atụ anya mmegharị ahu nke gọvanọ ndị agha mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu nke Naịjirịa, Lt. Col. Emeka Ojukwu, kwuputara nkewa Naịjirịa n'ime steeti iri na abụọ na mpaghara anọ.

en: The division of Nigeria into 12 states and Ojukwu's declaration of Biafra were decisions that would change the country forever.
ibo: Nkewa Naịjirịa n'ime steeti iri na abụọ na nkwupụta Ojukwu maka Biafra bụ mkpebi ga-agbanwe mba ahụ ruo mgbe ebighi ebi.

en: Gowon's action did not only alter the structure of Nigeria, it led to the reconstruction of the nascent nation through the lenses of the so-called Nigerian military; a military that was provincial in outlook as it was ill-equipped for leadership.
ibo: Omume Gowon agbanweghị naani ọdịdị Naịjirịa, ọ dabere na nruzigharị nke ala ahụ site na oghere ndị a kpọrọ ndị agha Naịjirịa, ndị agha bụ ndị lepuru anya mgbe ndị Naịjirịa enweghi ike idu onwe ha.

en: The military centralized economic and political power and moved Nigeria from a federal republic to a unitary state.
ibo: Ndị agha jịkọrọ ikike akụ na ụba na nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ma mee ka Naịjirịa si na Federal Repọblik gaa na nchịkọ steeti ala.

en: In many ways, we can conveniently say May 27, 1967, was the day Nigeria began to unravel and any attempt to understand the current crises and our inability to make progress as a nation must necessarily return to the action of the military junta on May 27, 1967.
ibo: N'ọtụtụ ụzọ, anyị nwere ike ịsị na Mee 27, 1967 bụ ụbọchị Naịjirịa malitere ịkpughe onwe ya na mbọ ọ bụla iji ghọta nsogbu ndị dị oge ugbua na adịghị ike anyị inweta agamnihu dịka mba dị oke mkpa ilaghachị omume ndị ọchịagha na Mee 27, 1967.

en: Three days later, May 30, 1967, Lt. Col Ojukwu, a Nigerian soldier of Igbo extraction declared an 'independent sovereign state of the name and title of the Republic of Biafra .
ibo: Mgbe ụbọchị atọ gachara, May 30, 1967 Lt. Col. Ojukwu, onye agha Naịjirịa nke mpaghara ndị Igbo kwupụtara 'Nnwere onwe mba kwuru onwe ya akpọrọ Repọblik nke Biafra.

en: Officially excising the Eastern Region from Nigeria .
ibo: Ọ bụrụla ihe amaama na ekewapụtala mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu na Naịjirịa.

en: Ojukwu based his action on the resolution, four days earlier, on May 26, 1967, of a joint conference of the Eastern consultative assembly and leaders of thought that asked him to declare the Eastern region as a separate republic at an 'early practicable date .
ibo: Ojukwu dabere ihe o mere na mkpebi, abali anọ gara aga na Mee 26, 1967 nke ọgbakọ nzukọ ndị isi mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu na ndị isi nke gwara ya ka ọ kpọọ mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu dịka mba ọzọ na mbido ụbọchị.

en: The declaration of Biafra was the culmination of a series of tragic events .
ibo: Nkwupụta nke Biafra bụ ngwụcha nke ọtụtụ ọdachi.

en: First was the bloodletting that started with the January 15, 1966, military coup .
ibo: Nke mbụ bụ nkwafu ọbara nke bidoro na Jenụwarị 15, 1966, mgbagha ndị agha

en: That coup led to the assassination of Alhaji Abubakar Tafawa Belewa, the country's first and only prime minister and Sir Ahmadu Bello, the Premier of the Northern Region, among other high-profile casualties .
ibo: Ya bu mgbagha butere ogbugbu nke Alhaji Abubakar, Tafawa Belewa, onye isi ala mbụ na naanị Prime Minister enwere na Mazi Ahmadu Bello, onye isi mpaghara ugwu, n'etiti ndị ọzọ nwere nnukwu nwakpo.

en: Some recollections by Edwin Madunagu in 'Settling account with Biafra (The Guardian, May 4, 2000) are apposite here:
ibo: Ncheta ụfọdụ nke Edwin Madunagu na 'imezi akaụntụ nke Biafra' ( Guardian Mee 4, 2000) tughariri nke a :

en: One: the politics of the First Republic (1960-1965) was heavily characterized by ethnicity, especially towards the end of that tragic period .
ibo: Otu: ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke Republik nke mbụ (1960 - 1965) eji agbụrụ mara ya nke ukwuu, ọkachasị njedebe nke oge ọdachị.

en: Two: Of the five army majors that are more frequently mentioned as leading the coup attempt, only one, Major Adewale Ademoyega, was non-Igbo by ethnic origin .
ibo: Abụọ: n'ime ndị agha ise akpụ n'ọnụ na-edu nwapụ ndị agha, naanị otu onye agha bụ Adewale Ademoyega bụ onye na-abụghị onye si n'agbụrụ Igbo pụta.

en: Three: No Igbo political leader died and the only Igbo military casualty occurred not because he was a target but because he was considered a 'nuisance' .
ibo: Nke atọ: onweghi onye ndu ọchịchị ala Igbo nwụrụ na nanị ihe kpatara ogbugbu ndị agha Igbo abụghị n'ihi na ọ bụ onye Igbo, kama, ọ bụ n'ihi na e lere ya anya dịka nsogbu.

en: Four: The attempted coup was the culmination of a long period of political crisis in Nigeria .
ibo: Anọ: Mgbagha ahụ bụ njedebe nke ogologo oge ọgbahara ndọrọ ndọrọ na Naịjirịa.

en: A crisis whose centre of gravity was Western Region where, before the military intervention, the crisis had become an armed popular uprising .
ibo: Nsogbu nke ike ya si na mpaghara ọdịda anyanwu tupu ntinye aka ndị agha, nsogbu ahụ bụ ọgbaghara amaama eji alụ agha.

en: On July 29, 1966, there was another military coup led by officers from Northern Nigeria and Lt. Col Yakubu Gowon became head of state.
ibo: Na Julai 29, 1966, enwere mbuso agha ọzọ nke ndị agha si n'mpaghara ugwu nke Naịjirịa duuru na Lt. Col. Yakubu Gowon bụ onye isi ala.

en: According to Madunagu, the coupists 'first made a move to pull the Northern Region out Nigeria, but when they were advised that they were now in a military situation to rule the whole country, instead of a part of it, they dropped the idea of secession and became champions of 'One Nigeria'.
ibo: Site n'akụkọ Magunagu, ndị a kpara ike a na mbu chọbuuru ikewa mpaghara ugwu na Naịjirịa, mana mgbe a duru ha ọdụ na ha bụzi ndị agha na achị mba niile kama ịchị so akụkụ nke ha, ha tufuru echiche ikewa obodo wee bụrụzie ndị agbachitere Otu Naịjirịa.

en: Lt. Col Ojukwu refused to recognize Lt. Col Gowon as head of state.'
ibo: Lt. Col. Ojukwu juru ịnabata Lt. Col. Gowon dịka onye isi ala.

en: The second coup led to the assassination, among other high-profile casualties, of the country's first military head of state, Gen. Aguiyi Ironsi, an Igbo, as well as the military governor of the Western Region, Lt. Col. Adekunle Fajuyi.
ibo: Nchịkwa nke abụọ butere ogbugbu ahụ, na ndị ọzọ nwụrụ bụ onye isi agha ala mbu, Gen. Aguiyi Ironsi, onye Igbo, yana onye ndu ndị agha mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu, Lt. Col. Adekunle Fajuyi.

en: This was followed by, as Madunagu notes, 'mass killings not only in the North but all over the country, except the Eastern Region.
ibo: Nke a sochiri ka Madunagu kwuru, ' ogbugbu mmadụ abụghị naani na mpaghara ugwu kamakwa na mba niile, sọsọ mpaghara ọdịda anyanwu.

en: Now, multiply the May 1966 tragedy by a factor of 50, add to it the fact that the killings were now led by armed soldiers whose commanders were now in power and add to this the fact that the killings did not abate for at least five months and you begin to have an idea of what happened.'
ibo: Ugbua, jiri ọnụọgụ iri ise gbakọ ihe mgberede Mee 1966, tinye ya na ogbugbu ahụ bụ ndị agha na-eduga n'ike nke ndị ọchịagha ha nọ ugbu a ma gbakwunye na nke a na ogbugbu ahụ akwụsịghị, tụpụ ọnwa ise, ị malite ịghọta ihe mere

en: The criminal indifference of the Nigerian state to the manifest pogrom against people from Eastern Nigeria, particularly Igbos, the repudiation by the Nigerian contingent (and the 'unilateral implementation' by the Eastern regional government) of the agreement on decentralization of power reached at a meeting in Aburi, Ghana, involving the main protagonists, Yakubu Gowon and Emeka Ojukwu, at the instance of Gen. Ankrah of Ghana, finally paved the road to Biafra.
ibo: Eleghị anya na mpụ nke steeti Naịjirịa na ihe pụtara ìhè megide ndị si ọwụwa anyanwu Naịjirịa, ọkachasị ndị Igbo, ndị nnọchị anya ndị Naịjirịa (na idi n'otu gọọmentị nke ndị mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwu mejupụtara) nke nkwekọrịta maka ikewa ike ọchịchị ekwekọrịta na nzukọ e enwere na Aburi, Ghana, nke gụnyere ndị isi, Yakubu Gowon na Emeka Ojukwu, na onye aka ebe Gen. Ankrah nke Ghana, mechara wara Biafra ụzọ.

en: The accounts of what took place in those turbulent days are as varied as there are ethnic groups in Nigeria.
ibo: Ihe ndekọ ndị mere n'ụbọchị ọgbaghara ahụ dịgasị iche iche dịka esi nwee agbụrụ dị iche iche na Naịjirịa.

en: But one thing is certain:
ibo: Mana otu ihe doro anya:

en: The effects of those events, particularly the actions of May 27 and 30, 1967, are still being felt today .
ibo: Nsonaazụ nke ihe omume ndị ahụ, ọkachasị na ihe omume Mee 27 na 30,1967 ka ana-ahụ ruo taa.

en: In one fell swoop, the military unilaterally restructured Nigeria according to its dictates.
ibo: N'otu ọsụsọ, ndị agha rụzigharịrị Naịjirịa dịka iwu ya siri dị.

en: While Ojukwu drafted 'unwilling' minorities in the Eastern Region to create a Biafran state where Igbos were in the majority, the Nigerian military which was nothing but the armed wing of a reactionary feudal class that had power thrust on it at independence began the implementation of an agenda of conquest.
ibo: Mgbe Ojukwu wepụtara ndị 'achọghị' obere agburu na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ iji mepụta ala Biafra ebe ndị Igbo ka n'ọnụ ọgụgụ, ndị agha Naịjirịa nke abụghị ihe ọbụla karịa ogwe aka nke ndị agha na-akpata esemokwu nke ndị enyere ike ọchịchị nnwere onwe malitere mmejupụta atụmatụ nke mmeri.

en: Interestingly, barely a year earlier, the section of the military that seized power after the January 15, 1966 coup had attempted to reconstruct Nigeria as a unitary state with the promulgation of the unification decree 34 of 1966.
ibo: N'ụzọ na-akpali mmasị, na-erughị otu afọ tupu mgbe ahụ, ngalaba nke ndị agha weghara ike mgbagha ahụ mere na Jenuwarị 15, 1966 nwughari iweghachi Naịjirịa dị ka ala jikọrọ ọnụ nke iwu nke njikọta 34 nke 1966 jikọrọ.

en: That attempt was opposed fiercely by those (including a section of the military) who felt they had lost out in the power equation. The rest is history.
ibo: Ndị gbahara atụmatụ ahụ bụ ndị (nke gunyere ngalaba ndị agha) chere na ha afụọla n'ike ọchịchị. Nke fọdụrụ ziri bụ akụkọ.

en: When history repeats itself
ibo: Mgbe akụkọ mere ọzọ

en: Unfortunately, Nigeria is on the cusp of that tragic history repeating itself.
ibo: Ọ bụ ihe nwute na Naịjirịa nọ na njedebe nke akụkọ ihe mere eme ahụ na-emegharị onwe ya.

en: Regrettably, 50 years after the declaration of Biafra many young Nigerians of Igbo descent are trying to recreate Biafra.
ibo: Ọ dị nwute na afọ iri ise gasịrị mgbe e kwupụtachara Biafra, ọtụtụ ndị ntorobịa ndị Naịjirịa sitere n'agburu Igbo na-anwa ime ka Biafra dịghachị mma.

en: In a few days, there will be events in Nigeria and around the world to mark the 50th anniversary of the declaration of Biafra on May 30, 1967.
ibo: N'ụbọchị ole na ole, a ga-enwe ihe omume na Naịjirịa na ụwa niile iji mee ncheta afọ iri ise e kwupụtara Biafra na Mee 30, 1967.

en: Forty-seven years after the end of the Nigeria-Biafra War, Biafra still resonates with individuals and groups within and outside the country; perhaps, a testament to the fact that the war hasn't ended in the minds of the protagonists and victims .
ibo: Afọ iri anọ na asaa ka agha obodo Naịjirịa-Biafra gwụsịrị, Biafra ka na-emegharị n'etiti ndị mmadu n'otu n'otu na ndị nọ ná mpụga; ikekwa, ọgbụgba akaebe nke eziokwu ahụ akwụsịbeghị n'uche ndị meriri na ndị emeriri.

en: The reality is that many of the issues that propelled the civil war are still with us today.
ibo: N'eziokwu, ọtụtụ ihe kpatara agha obodo ahụ ka dị ugbu a.

en: So, how do we deal with this conundrum ?
ibo: Yabụ kedu out anyị ga-esi mee ihe nnọkọ ọnụ a ?

en: Is Biafra the solution ?
ibo: Biafra ọ bụ ọsịsa ya ?

en: In other words, can we solve the problems of 2017 Nigeria using the tragic solution of 50 years ago ?
ibo: N'aka nke ọzọ, anyị ga-edozinwu nsogbu nke 2017 Naịjirịa site na iji oke nsogbu nke afọ iri ise gara aga ?

en: As S.M. Sigerson noted in The Assassination of Michael Collins:
ibo: Dị ka S. M. Sigerson kwuru na ogbugbu nke Michael Collins:

en: What Happened at Béal na mBláth ?
ibo: Gịnị mere na Beal na mBlath ?

en: A nation which fails to adequately remember salient points of its own history is like a person with Alzheimer's.
ibo: Mba nke daramba na-icheta nke ọma banyere akụkọ dị oke mkpa na ihe mere eme na ụbọchị ya ndị gara aga dị ka onye nwere ọrịa Alzheimer.

en: And that can be a social disease of a most destructive nature .
ibo: Nke nwere ike ịbụ ọrịa nwere ike imebi ihe.

en: Seventeen years ago, Edwin Madunagu, in the piece referenced above, admonished
ibo: Afọ iri na asaa gara aga, Edwin Madunagu na mpempe a kpọtụrụ aha n'ele dụrụ ọdụ

en: The young Nigerians now threatening to actualize Biafra (to) forget or shelve the plan.
ibo: Ụmụ Naịjirịa na-eyi egwu ugbu a na ha ga-eme ka Biafra bịa (na ha) chefuo ma ọ bụ kpachie atụmatụ ahụ.

en: In place of 'actualisation', they should, through research and study, reconstruct the Biafran story in its fullness and complexity and try to answer the unanswered questions and supply the missing links in the story.
ibo: Ha kwesiri iji ụzọ nchọpụta na agụmakwụkwọ degharịa akụkọ banyere Biafra n'uju ya na ihe dịkwa mgbagwoju anya ma gbalịa zaa ajụjụ a na-edeghị ma chọtakwa ihe na-apụtaghị n'akụkọ a .

en: This is a primary responsibility you owe yourselves:
ibo: Nke a bụ ibu ọrụ dịịrị ụnụ:

en: You should at least understand what you want to actualise .
ibo: ịkwesiri ịghọta opekata mpe mata ihe ịchọrọ ime.

en: If 30 years after Biafra, you want to produce its second edition, you need to benefit from the criticism of the first.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ n'afọ iri atọ gafere, ịchọọ iwepụta mbịpụta ya nke abụọ, ịkwesiri irite uru site na nkatọ nke mbụ.

en: History teaches that a second edition of a tragic event could easily become a farce—in spite of the heroism of its human agencies .
ibo: Akụkọ ihe mere eme na-akụzị na mbipụta nke abụọ nke ihe ọdachị nwere ike ịghọ ihe dị njọ - n'agbanyeghị ike ọrụ nke ndị mmadụ na-achọ ya.

en: On the other hand, those who enjoy ridiculing Biafra—instead of studying it—are politically shortsighted.
ibo: N'aka nke ọzọ, ndị na-enwe mmasị ịkwa Biafra emo - kama ịmụ ya - anaghị elezi anya na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị.

en: My own attitude to Biafra is neither 'actualisation' nor ridicule .
ibo: Omume m maka Biafra abụghị imepụta ya ma ọ bụ ịkwa ya emo.

en: I propose that accounts should be settled with Biafra .
ibo: M na-atụ alo na ekwesiri idozi akaụntụ dị na Biafra.

en: Madunagu's admonition needs no elaboration .
ibo: Ndụmọdụ Madunagu enweghị nkọwa.

en: It is clear enough for the young people pushing for the actualization of Biafra, many of whom were born after the end of the Biafra war 47 years ago .
ibo: O doro anya nyere ndị na-eto eto n-akwado ikewapụta Biafra, nke ọtụtụ n'ime ha bụ ndị amụrụ mgbe agha Biafra biara na njedebe afọ iri anọ na asaa gara aga.

en: The aspect of his position on Biafra that I want to focus on is the aspect that warns of the 'political shortsightedness of ridiculing Biafra' .
ibo: Akụkọ nke ọnọdụ ya na Biafra nke m chọrọ ilekwasị anya bụ akụkọ nke na-adọ aka na ntị banyere elerughi anya ala nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke ịkwa Biafra emo

en: Balkanizing the nation
ibo: imebe isi ala nke mba

en: When the military regime headed by Gowon divided Nigeria into 12 states, it sought to weaken the prospect of the different groups in the Eastern Region uniting against the Nigerian state .
ibo: Mgbe ndị agha nke Gowon na-achị kewara Naịjirịa n'ime steeti iri abụọ, ọ chọrọ imebi atụmatụ nke ndị otu dị iche iche na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ ijikọ aka megide Naịjirịa .

en: Of course, that action was music to the ears of minority groups, particularly those in the Eastern Region, who had long demanded their own state .
ibo: N'ezie, ihe ahụ emere dịka egwu na ntị ndị otu pere mpe, ọkachasị ndị nọ n'ọwụwa anyanwụ, ndị chọgoro steeti nke ha ogologo oge .

en: With the creation of states, however, the military not only unilaterally abrogated the geo-political structure that existed then, it went a step further to destroy the principle of federalism on which Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and which had sustained and kept the country together.
ibo: Site na okike nke steeti, ọbụghị naanị na ndị agha kagburu usoro ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke dị n'oge ahụ, ọ gara n'ihu mebie ụkpụrụ nke gọọmentị etiti nke Naịjirịa nke eji nwete nwere onwe na 1960 nke jigidere ma gbazie mba ọnụ .

en: We need to understand that this principle was adopted not only to assuage the fear of domination by a single group in the country but as recognition of the differences (multi-ethnic and multi-lingual) of the various 'ethnic nationalities' that were brought together to create Nigeria.
ibo: Anyị kwesịrị ịghọta na nnabata ụkpụrụ a abụghị naanị maka ụjọ otu òtù ịkagide ndị ọzọ na mba ahụ, kamakwa, dị ka mmata ndịiche (agbụrụ dị iche iche na ọtụtụ asụsụ) nke 'agbụrụ dị iche iche' a kpọkọtara ọnụ iji mebe Naịjirịa.

en: Part of Gowon's broadcast on May 27, 1967, signaling the breakup of Nigeria into 12 states is pertinent here:
ibo: Ihe so n'akụkọ nke mgbasa ozi Gowon na Mee 27, 1967, na-egosi nkewa Naịjirịa n'ime steeti iri na abụọ bụ ihe dị oke mkpa ebe a:

en: The main obstacle to future stability in this country is the present structural imbalance in the Nigerian Federation .
ibo: Ihe mgbochi kacha njọ maka nkwụsị ike ọdịnihu na mba a bụ enweghị nhazi nke ugbu a na njịkọ mba.

en: Even Decree No.8 or Confederation or 'loose association' will never survive if any one section of the country is in a position to hold the others to ransom.
ibo: Ọbụla iwu nke asatọ ma ọ bụ njịkọ ma ọ bụ 'mkpakọrịta na-adịghị ọcha' agaghị adị ndụ ma ọ bụrụ na mpaghara ọ bụla nke mba ahụ nwere ike ijide ndị ọzọ n'nkwe.

en: This is why the first item in the political and administrative program adopted by the Supreme Military Council last month is the creation of states for stability .
ibo: Ọ bụ ya mere ihe mbu dị na mmemme ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na nhazi nke ọchịchị ndị agha nabatara n'ọnwa gara aga bụ ịmepụta steeti maka nkwụsị ike .

en: This must be done first so as to remove the fear of domination.
ibo: A ga-ebu ụzọ mee nke a iji wepu egwu nke nnara ike .

en: Representatives drawn from the new states will be more able to work out the future constitution for this country which can contain provisions to protect the powers of the states to the fullest extent desired by the Nigerian people.
ibo: Ndị nnọchị anya sitere na steeti ndị ọhụrụ ga-enwe ike hazie iwu obodo maka ọdịnihu a nke nwere ike ịnwe atụmatụ ichebe ike nke steeti ruo n'ọsọ ndị Naịjirịa chọrọ.

en: As soon as these are established, a new revenue allocation commission consisting of international experts will be appointed to recommend an equitable formula for revenue allocation taking into account the desires of the states .
ibo: Ozugbo emepụtara ihe ndị a, a ga-ahọpụta kọmitii ọhụrụ na-enweta ego nke mejupụtara ndị ọkachamara nke mba ụwa ịkwado usoro ziri ezi maka ịke oke ego ma buru n'uche ọchịchọ nke steeti.

en: I propose to act faithfully within the political and administrative program adopted by the Supreme Military Council and published last month.
ibo: A na m atụ alo ijiri ntụkwasị obi rụọ ọrụ na ihe omume ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na nchịkwa nke nzụkọ ọchịchị ndị agha nabatara ma bipụta n'ọnwa gara aga.

en: The world will recognize in these proposals our desire for justice and fair play for all sections of this country and to accommodate all genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country.
ibo: Ụwa ga-amata site n'usoro ndị a chọrọ ka anyị jiri ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu dị mma nabata mpaghara niile nke mba a ma nabata ezi ebumnuche nke ndị dị iche iche nke mba a.

en: I have ordered the re-imposition of the economic measures designed to safeguard federal interests until such time as the Eastern Military Governor abrogates his illegal edicts on revenue collection and the administration of the federal statutory corporations based in the East.
ibo: Enyela m iwu iwezighachị usoro akụ na ụba emebere iji chekwaa ọdịmma onye niile ruo oge dị ka Gọvanọ ndị agha nke ọwụwa anyanwụ na-ekpochapụ iwu na-akwadoghị ya na nnakọta ego yana nchịkwa nke ụlọ ọrụ gọọmentị etiti na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ.

en: The country has a long history of well-articulated demands for states .
ibo: Mba a nwere ogologo akụkọ ihe mere eme maka ndị chọrọ steeti .

en: The fears of minorities were explained in great detail and set out in the report of the Willink Commission appointed by the British in 1958 .
ibo: A kọwara nke ọma ihe ịtụ egwu nke ndị mpaghara pere mpe ma wepụta na akụkọ nke akwụkwọ akụkọ Willink nke ndị Britain họpụtara n'afọ 1958 .

en: More recently, there have been extensive discussions in Regional Consultative Committees and leaders-of-thought conferences .
ibo: N'adịbeghị anya, enwere mkparịta ụka miri emi na kọmitii na-ahụ maka mpaghara na nnọkọ ndị isi-echiche .

en: Resolutions have been adopted demanding the creation of states in the North and in Lagos .
ibo: Emeela mkpebi maka ịmepụta steeti na mpaghara Ugwu na Legos.

en: Petitions from minority areas in the East which have been subjected to violent intimidation by the Eastern Military Government have been publicized .
ibo: A kọsara arịrịọ ndị mpaghara pere mpe na ọwụwa anyanwụ maka ịmepụta steeti nke gọọmentị ndị agha ọwụwa anyanwụ na-eyi egwu .

en: While the present circumstances regrettably do not allow for consultations through plebiscites, I am satisfied that the creation of new states as the only possible basis for stability and equality is the overwhelming desire of the vast majority of Nigerians .
ibo: N'agbanyeghị ọnọdụ ndị dị ugbu a na-akwa ụta na ha ekweghị ka a jụọ ajụjụ site na arịrịọ, enwere m afọ ojuju na ịmepụta steeti ọhụrụ dịka naanị ihe ndabere maka nkwụsị ike na nhatanha bụ nnukwu ọchịchọ nke ọtụtụ ndị Naịjirịa .

en: To ensure justice, these states are being created simultaneously .
ibo: Iji hụ n'ikpe ziri ezi, a na-ekepụta steeti ndị a n'otu oge .

en: To this end, therefore, I am promulgating a decree which will divide the Federal Republic into 12 states .
ibo: N'ihi nke a, ana m ekwupụta iwu ga-ekewa obodo niile na steeti iri abụọ .

en: The 12 states will be six in the present Northern Region, three in the present Eastern Region, the Mid-Western will remain as it is, the Colony Province of the Western Region and Lagos will form a new Lagos State and the Western Region will otherwise remain as it is .
ibo: Steeti iri na abụọ ahụ ga-adị isii na mpaghara Ugwu nke ugbu a, atọ dị na mpaghara ọwụwa anyanwụ ugbu a, mpaghara nke etiti ga-adị ka ọ dị ugbu a, mpaghara ogbè ndị ọdịda anyanwụ na Legos ga-emepụta steeti Legos ọhụrụ na mpaghara ọdịda anyanwụ ga-anọrọ otu ọ dị.

en: What the military regime of Gowon gave with one hand it took with the other .
ibo: Ihe ndị agha ọchịchị Gowon nyere n'otu aka, o were ya n'aka nke ọzọ .

en: And that would become the hallmark of subsequent military regimes in Nigeria .
ibo: Nke ahụ ga-abụkwa ihe eji amara ọchịchị ndị agha na-achị na Naịjirịa .

en: Gowon failed to realize, or deliberately ignored the reality that the issue wasn't the division of the country but the reluctance or inability of the military to keep its promise
ibo: Gowon amataghị, ma ọ bụ ọ kpachara anya leghaara eziokwu ahụ anya na okwu ahụ abụghị nkewa nke obodo mana enweghị mmasị ma ọ bụ enweghị ike nke ndị agha iji mezuo nkwa ya

en: This must be done first so as to remove the fear of domination .
ibo: A ga-ebu ụzọ mee nke a iji wepu egwu nke mkpagbu .

en: Representatives drawn from the new states will be more able to work out the future constitution for this country which can contain provisions to protect the powers of the states to the fullest extent desired by the Nigerian people .
ibo: Ndị nnọchị anya si na steeti ndị ọhụrụ ga-enwe ike ịmebe iwu obodo n'ọdịnihu nke nwere ike ịnwe ihe iji chebe ikike nke steeti ruo n'okè ndị Naịjirịa chọrọ .

en: Unfortunately, that never happened .
ibo: Ọ dị nwute, nke ahụ emeghị .

en: It couldn't have, considering the rapacious and parasitic nature of the Nigerian military so-called and the interest it represented and still represents .
ibo: O nweghị ike ịme, na-atule ụdị mmadụ ndị agha Naịjirịa bụ na mmasị ọ nọchịrị anya ma ka na-anọchị anya ya .

en: Once the military couldn't deliver on that promise, it also meant that the second part of its declaration that:
ibo: Ozugbo ndị agha enweghị ike imejupụta nkwa ahụ, ọ pụtakwara na akụkụ nke abụọ nke nkwupụta ya na:

en: 'The world will recognise in these proposals our desire for justice and fair play for all sections of this country' and
ibo: 'Ụwa ga-amata site n'usoro ndị a na ọchịchọ anyị bụ maka ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu ziri ezi maka ngalaba niile nke mba a' na

en: 'To accommodate all genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country,' was nothing but meaningless soundbite by a rampaging military sub-class in desperate search for legitimacy.
ibo: 'Ịnabata ebumnuche dị mma niile nke ndị dị iche iche nke nnukwu obodo a' abụghị ihe efu ma oli nke na-enweghị isi site na ndị agha na-ebuso agha n'ịchọsị i ike iwu.

en: Since then, there has neither been 'justice nor fair play for all sections' of Nigeria.
ibo: Kemgbe ahụ, enwebeghị 'ikpe ziri ezi ma ọ bụ egwuregwu ziri ezi nyere mpaghara niile' nke Naịjirịa.

en: There hasn't been any serious attempt to 'accommodate all genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country .
ibo: Enwebeghị mgbalị siri ike iji 'nabata ebumnuche niile dị mma nke ndị dị iche iche nke nnukwu mba a' .

en: The sham of a federation that the military created has evolved into a Frankenstein's monster. Fast forward 50 years.
ibo: Ihe ihere nyere mba nke otu ndị agha mebere abanyela na nnukwu anụ Frankenstein. Ngwa ngwa n'ihu afọ iri ise .

en: Cleary, it is the nebulous federal government that is holding the country to ransom. The moment the military government took economic powers from the states, there was no way we could ensure justice and fair play.
ibo: N'ụzọ doro anya, ọ bụ gọọmentị etiti na-ejide mba a n'mgbapụta .

en: And once you can't ensure justice and fair play, there is no way you can stop the concomitant disquiet.
ibo: Ozugbo oge ndị ọchịchị weghara ikike akụ na ụba nke steeti, ọ nweghị ụzọ anyị ga-esi hụ na ekpere ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu ziri ezi, ọ nweghị ụzọ ị ga-esi kwụsị ọgbahara .

en: The politics of state creation
ibo: Ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke okike steeti

en: When Gen Murtala Muhammed created additional seven states—three in the 'South' and four in the 'North'—bringing the total to 19 states, and a new federal capital territory, Abuja, on February 3, 1976, ten days before his assassination on February 13, he left no one in doubt that the conquest was real.
ibo: Mgbe Gen. Muhammed mepụtara steeti asaa ọzọ - atọ na mpaghara ọdịda na anọ na mpaghara Ugwu- na-enweta mkpọkọta nke steeti ruo iri na itoolu, yana ogbè ọhụrụ gọọmentị etiti, Abuja na Febuwarị 3, 1976, ụbọchị iri tupu egbuo ya na Febuwarị 13, enyeghị onye ọbụla obi abụọ na mmeri a dị.

en: While Gowon showed an inclination to balance Nigeria geo-politically, Muhammed ensured that the 'North' had ten states while the 'South' had nine .
ibo: Oge Gowon gosipụtara na ọ nwere ike imezu nhazi usoro ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị Naịjirịa, Muhammed gbara mbọ hu na mpaghara Ugwu nwere steeti iri ebe mpaghara ọdịda nwere itoolu.

en: It has been alleged that the decision was to create four new states in the 'North' and four new states in the 'South', but when Muhammed announced the creation of states, instead of creating two states (Cross River and Akwa Ibom States) out of the old South-Eastern State, he simply announced the transformation of South-Eastern State into Cross River State.
ibo: Ekwuru na mkpebi ahụ bụ ịmepụta steeti ọhụrụ anọ na mpaghara Ugwu na steeti ọhụrụ anọ na ọdịda, mana mgbe Muhammed kwupụtara okike steeti, kama ịmepụta steeti abụọ, (steeti Cross River na Akwa Ibom) site na nke ochie ọdịda anyanwụ nke steeti ọwụwa anyanwụ, ọ kpọrọ mgbanwe nke ọdịda anyanwụ nke steeti ọwụwa anyanwụ gaa steeti Cross River.

en: Subsequent military regimes continued the conquest, not just on the political front, but on the economic front as well .
ibo: Usọrọ ọchịchị ndị sochirinu gara n'ihu na-emeri, ọ bụghị naanị n'ihu ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, kamakwa n'ihu akụ na ụba.

en: Ten years later, in 1986, when the self-professed evil genius, Gen Ibrahim Babangida, set up a Political Bureau to review the country's political and democratic system, one of its recommendations was the creation of an additional state (Akwa Ibom State) in 'South' to create a geo-political balance of ten states each between the 'North' and 'South' .
ibo: Afọ iri ka nke ahụ gasịrị,na 1986, mgbe onye kwupụtara onwe ya ka ọkachamara maka ajọ ihe, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, guzobere ụlọ ọrụ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị iji nyochaa ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche nke obodo, otu n'ime ndụmọdụ ya bụ ịmepụta steeti ọzọ (Akwa Ibom) na mpaghara ọdịda anyanwụ iji mepụta ndozi ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị nke steeti iri ọbụla n'etiti mpaghara Ugwu na ndida .

en: Babangida spurned that recommendation .
ibo: Babangida jụrụ ịkwado ndụmọdụ ahụ .

en: He did create Akwa Ibom State, but he added another state (Katsina State) in the 'North' to maintain the imbalance .
ibo: O mepụtara steeti Akwa Ibom mana o mepụtarakwara steeti ọzọ (Katsina steeti) na Ugwu iji nọgịde na-adighị n'otu .

en: It was the same pattern that was adopted in subsequent state creation in 1991 (under Gen Babangida) and 1996 (under Gen Sani Abacha) .
ibo: Ọ bụ otu ukporo ahụ ka atọrọ na mmepụta steeti na-esote na 1991 (n'okpuru Gen. Babangida) na 1996 (n'okpuru Gen. Sani Abacha).

en: Geo-politically, today, Nigeria is composed of 36 states: 19 states in the 'North' and 17 states in the 'South' .
ibo: Na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, taa, Naịjirịa nwere steeti iri atọ na isii: Steeti iri na itoolu si na mpaghara Ugwu ebe steeti iri na asaa si na mpaghara ndida .

en: Ordinarily, this should not matter .
ibo: N'ihe ịga n'anya ya, nke a ekwesịghị ịdị mkpa .

en: After all, in a federation, the federating units (states) are supposed to manage their affairs substantially and contribute to the sustenance of the Federation.
