ibo: N'ihe niile, na ngalaba, gọọmentị etiti, ngalaba ndị a na-achị (steeti) kwesịrị ijikwa ihe omume ha nke ọma ma na-enye aka na nkwalite nke gọọmentị .

en: Therefore, only those who feel their states can sustain themselves would clamor for the creation of such states .
ibo: Ya mere, ọ bụ naanị ndị chere na steeti ha nwere ike ịkwagide onwe ha ga-ekwupụta maka ịmepụta steeti ndị a .

en: Of course, more self-sustaining states would mean more opportunities for the national government to benefit from the exploration and exploitation of resources in every state.
ibo: N'ezie, steeti ndị ga-ejigidenwu onwe ha ga-enwekwu ohere maka gọọmentị mba iji rite uru na nrigbu na nrigbu akụrụngwa na steeti ọ bụla .

en: Unfortunately, that is not the case with Nigeria.
ibo: Ọ bụ ihe nwute na osighị otua dịrị na Naịjirịa .

en: In a country where the military had hijacked and centralized the control of economic resources and political power by, for example, arrogating to itself the authority to create local governments as well as placing itself in the position of chief dispenser of funds based on its own criteria, including population, land mass, number of local governments, derivation principle, etc.
ibo: N'obodo ebe ndị agha weghaara ma tinye isi na ikike nchịkwa akụ na ụba na ike ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị site, n'ọmụmatụ, inye onwe ya ikike imepụta ọchịchị gọọmentị ime obodo yana itinye onwe ya n'ọnọdụ onye isi na-ekesa ego site na njirisi nke ya, gụnyere ọnụ ọgụgụ nke gọọmentị mpaghara inweta ụkpụrụ, ọnụ ọgụgụ nke ọchịchị ime obodo dgz.

en: The dog eat dog demand for states was inevitable.
ibo: A kwusinwughị usoro nkịta riri nkịta chọrọ steeti.

en: Thanks to the military—the armed wing of Nigeria's dominant power bloc—Nigeria has a weird federation where states can't create their own local governments; where local governments are listed in constitutions that have been nothing but military decrees writ large.
ibo: Ekele dịrị ndị agha- ogwe aka ike nke Naịjirịa- Naịjirịa nwere ọgbakọ ọchịchị dị egwu ebe steeti enweghị ike ịmepụta gọọmentị ime obodo; ebe edepụtara ọchịchị ime obodo na usoro iwu ndị agha na enweghị ihe ọzọ na-abụghị iwu ndị agha.

en: Thanks to the military, Nigeria has spurned justice and fair play and disregarded the genuine aspirations of the diverse people of this great country.
ibo: Ekele dịrị ndị agha, Naịjirịa emebiela ikpe ziri ezi na egwuregwu ziri ezi ma leghaara ezi ebumnuche nke ndị dị iche iche nke nnukwu obodo a anya.

en: It is not for nothing that Nigeria is described as a federal republic.
ibo: Ọ bụghị n'efu ka a kọwara Naịjirịa dịka otu obodo .

en: It was a choice made by the three regions in Nigeria preceding independence.
ibo: Ọ bụ mmasị nke mpaghara atọ ndị dị na Naịjirịa mere tupu nnwere onwe .

en: Both the Eastern and Western regions obtained internal self-government (independence) in 1957, while the North got same in 1959.
ibo: Mpaghara ọwụwa na ọdịda anyanwụ nwetara ọchịchị nke ịchị onwe ha (nnwere onwe) na 1957, ebe mpaghara Ugwu nwetara na 1959 .

en: Each region could have opted to go its own way in 1960.
ibo: Mpaghara ọbụla gaara ahọrọ ịga n'ụzọ nke aka ha na 1960 .

en: We could have had three countries as opposed to one at independence.
ibo: Anyị kaara inwe mba atọ na-abụghị otu na mgbe nnwere onwe .

en: The decision by the regions to be part of a shared territory called Nigeria came with some obligation and expectation.
ibo: Mkpebi mpaghara ịbụ akụkụ nke ala a na-akpọ Naịjirịa biara na ụfọdụ oke na ọrụ .

en: There is little to suggest that the federating region were willing to jettison the greater part of their economic and political independence for the sake of 'one Nigeria' .
ibo: E nweghị ihe na-atụ alo na mpaghara ndị a na-achị dị njikere iwere akụkụ ka ukwuu nke akụ na ụba na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ha maka 'otu Nịjirịa' .

en: In 1963, the regions (the precursor of our current states) controlled 50 percent of the revenues accruing from their region
ibo: N'afọ 1963, (ihe anyị na-elebara anya na steeti anyị ugbu a) na-achịkwa pesent iri ise nke ego ha na-enweta site n'obodo ha

en: Today we are quibbling whether the states have right to as little as 13 percent.
ibo: Taa anyị na-ajụ ma steeti o nwere ikike ọbụladị pesent iri na atọ .

en: In a sense, this manifest heist by the federal government has perpetuated injustice in some sections of the country while condoning indolence in others .
ibo: N'otu echiche, gọọmentị etiti enwebatala ikpe ikpe a, na-ezighị ezi na mpaghara ụfọdụ ma na-anabata ndị ọzọ .

en: It is this quest for control or lack of, that is at the heart of the Nigerian crisis .
ibo: Ọ bụ n'ọchịchọ nchịkwaa ma ọ bụ enweghị, bụ isi nsogbu nke Naịjirịa.

en: Biafra of the mind vs Biafra of the field
ibo: Biafra nke uche na Biafra nke ubi

en: What is Biafra ?
ibo: Gịnị bụ Biafra ?

en: If that question was tough to answer in 1967, it is even more difficult today, fifty years after .
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ajụjụ a siri ike ịza na 1967, ọ ka sie ike taa, afọ iri ise ka nke ahụ gasịrị .

en: As a nation, Biafra was going to be difficult to sustain even if it had been actualized .
ibo: Dị ka otu mba, Biafra ga-esi ike ịnagide ọ bụrụgodị na e keputara ya .

en: Was Biafra a nation made up of ethnic nationalities ?
ibo: Ndị Biafra ha buru mba mejupụtara agbụrụ ha?

en: In other words, was Biafra a microcosm of Nigeria ?
ibo: N'aka nke ọzọ, Biafra ọ bụ obere Naịjirịa ?

en: One of the things those who are agitating for Biafra have not been able to define or communicate effectively is an answer to the question: What is Biafra ?
ibo: Otu n'ime ihe ndị ahụ na achọ Biafra enwebeghị ike ịkọwa ma ọ bụ ikwukọrịta okwu nke ọma bụ azịza nye ajụjụ a : Gịnị bụ Biafra ?

en: The answers to this question are as varied as there are agitators .
ibo: Azịza ajụjụ a dị iche iche dị ka ndị na-achọ ya.

en: There are those who will tell you that Biafra encompasses the area that used to be the Eastern Region of Nigeria and beyond, including parts of Southern Cameroon and stretching to Equatorial Guinea and Gabon.
ibo: Enwere ndị ga-agwa gị na Biafra gụnyere mpaghara ahụ bụbu mpaghara ọdịda anyanwu nke Naịjirịa na gafere, gụnyere akụkụ ụfọdụ nke Saut Cameroon wee ruo Equatorial Guinea na Gabon .

en: Some define Biafra as simply the former Eastern Region of Nigeria that was given the name Biafra on May 30, 1967.
ibo: Ụfọdụ kọwara Biafra dịka nanị mpaghara izizi nke ọdịda anyanwu nke Naịjirịa nke enyere aha ya bụ Biafra na Mee 30, 1967.

en: Some say it is the five states (Abia, Anambra, Ebonyi, Enugu and Imo) in south-east Nigeria where the Igbos are the major ethnic group .
ibo: Ụfọdụ kwuru na ọ bụ steeti ise ( Abia, Anambra, Ebonyi, Enugu na Imo) na south-east nke Naịjirịa ebe ndị Igbo bụ ndị kacha na agbụrụ.

en: Yet, others define Biafra as encompassing all the Igbo-speaking areas of southern Nigeria, including parts of present-day Rivers, Bayelsa, Delta, Akwa Ibom, Cross River and Benue States.
ibo: Agbanyeghị, ndị ọzọ kọwara na Biafra gụnyere mpaghara niile na-asụ asụsụ Igbo mpaghara ndịda nke Naịjirịa, gụnyere Rivers, Bayelsa, Delta, Akea Ibom, gafere osimiri na steeti Benue.

en: The issue of definition is important because the lack of understanding and agreement can pose great problems .
ibo: Okwu banyere nkọwa dị mkpa n'ihi enweghị nghọta na nkwekọrịta nwere ike ibute nnukwu nsogbu.

en: Of course, up until May 30, 1967, there was nothing like Biafra as nation or political territory.
ibo: Dịka ruo ọnwa Mee 30, 1967, o nweghi ihe dịka Biafra dịka obodo ma ọ bụ mpaghara ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị .

en: The only thing that bore the tag Biafra was a bight off the West African coast, in the easternmost part of the Gulf of Guinea, stretching to Cape Lopez in Gabon, over which Britain established a colonial protectorate in 1849.
ibo: Naanị ihe gosipụtara Biafra bụ ebe mpụtara dị n'akụkụ ọdịda anyanwụ nke Africa, n'akụkụ ebe ọwụwa anyanwụ nke Guinea, na-eru Cape Lopez dị na Gabon, ebe ndị bekee guzobere ikike nchịkwa na 1849.

en: Biafra as a nation was a child of circumstance that would become a child of necessity.
ibo: Biafra dịka mba bụ nwa amụrụ ka ihe si dị nke ga-abụzị nwa dị mkpa e kwesiri ịmụ.

en: What if the bloody January 15, 1966, coup and the attendant assassinations didn't happen ?
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ọgbaghara ọbara nnatụ ọchịchị nke ọnwa Jenụwarị 15, 1966 emeghi .

en: If Igbo political leaders had been killed alongside their counterparts from the 'North' and 'West';
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na e gbụrụ ndị isi ọchịchị si n'ala Igbo na ibe ha ndị si na ndịda na ọwụwa anyanwụ .

en: If the 'revenge coup' of July 29, 1966, and the attendant murders didn't occur;
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na o gbụgbụ nke Julai 29,1966 na o gbụgbụ ndị bịara emeghi .

en: If the Nigerian state had reined in the murderous groups (military and civilian) that had targeted Igbos after the July 29 coup;
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na steeti ndị Naijiria nọ na ọchịchị ndị na-akwafụ ọbara (ndị agha na ndị nkiti) nke lekwasara anya na ndị Igbo mgbe ọgbahara nke Julai, 29 ghara .

en: If Gen Aguiyi Ironsi—the first indigenous general and leader of the Nigerian Army—an Igbo who was not part of the January 15 abortive coup, had not been a major beneficiary by seizing power and becoming head of state;
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na onye isi agha bụ Ironsi - nwa afọ izizi bụ Onyeisi agha na onyeisi ndi agha Naiijiria - onye Igbo esonyeghị na nnatụ Jenuwarị 15 ahụ - abughi one rikarisiri uru ya site n'iweghara ọchịchị ma bụrụ onyeisi obodo .

en: If Gen Ironsi had executed the coup plotters of January 15 as military tradition dictates;
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na onye isi agha bụ Ironsi gburu ndị na-akpa nkata i were ọchịchị na Jenụwarị 15 dịka iwu ndị agha siri kwuo.

en: If the regime of Gen Ironsi did not promulgate Decree No. 34 — which abrogated the country's federal structure in exchange for a unitary one;
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ọchịchị onye isi agha bụ Ironsi emebeghi iwu 34 nke wepụrụ udi ọchịchị nke federal ji ọchịchị nke inwe otu onye isi ji gbanwee ya.

en: If the 'January 15 boys' had completed their 'project' either by one of them becoming head of state or as some have alluded, released the imprisoned leader of the national opposition, Chief Obafemi Awolowo, and installed him as prime minister;
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ụmụ nwoke nke ọnwa Janụwarị 15, rụchara ọrụ ha site na otu onye ibu onye ndu ma ọ bụ dịka ụfọdụ si chee, ị kpọpụta onye isi ndị otu na emegide ndị ọchịchị bụ Obafemi Awolowo na ngha ka ọ bụrụ onye isi,

en: If the Nigerian government led by Gowon had implemented the agreement reached at Aburi ?
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị nke Naijiria n'okpuru Gowon mejuputara nkwekọrịta ha n'Aburi ?

en: The secret police had stormed the place to effect the rearrest of pro-democracy campaigner and journalist, Omoyele Sowore, who was standing trial in a case brought against him by the Nigerian Government.
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii nzuzo wakporo ebe ahụ iji wee ruo ọrụ azụ nye onye nta akụkọ na-ekwu maka ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na onye nta akụkọ, Omoyele Sowore, onye na-ekpe ikpe n'okwu gọọmentị Naịjirịa wetara ya.

en: Sowore was first arrested on August 3, 2019 by the DSS for calling on Nigerians to take to the streets in peaceful demonstrations to demand a better country from the administration of President Muhammadu Buhari.
ibo: Ndị uwe ojii DSS jidere Sowore na ọgọst 3, 2019 maka ịkpọ ndị Naịjirịa ka ha gaa n'okporo ụzọ ngosipụta udo iji chọọ obodo ka mma site na ọchịchị Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari.

en: The government is accusing him of insulting President Buhari and planning to bring down his regime.
ibo: Gọọmentị na-ebo ya ebubo na ọ na-akparị onye isi ala Buhari na-eme atụmatụ iweda ọchịchị ya.

en: He was rearrested by the DSS on Friday less than 24 hours after being released on bail after 125 days in detention.
ibo: Ndị DSS kpọgharịrị ya na Fraịde erughị elekere iri abụọ na anọ ka a gbapụtachara ya n'nga nọrọ ụbọchị iri abụọ na ụma.

en: Chairman of Senate Committee on Judiciary, Human Rights and Legal Matters, Opeyemi Bamidele, moved the motion for the probe of the court invasion by the DSS.
ibo: Onye isi oche Kọmitii na-ahụ maka ọkaikpe, ihe ndị ruuru mmadụ na okwu gbasara iwu, Opeyemi Bamidele kpaliri ngagharị maka nyocha nke mwakpo ụlọ ọrụ ndị DSS.

en: Senate President, Ahmed Lawan, instructed the committee to begin legislative procedure on the matter and report next week.
ibo: Onye isi oche Sinet, Ahmed Lawan, nyere kọmitii ahụ iwu ịmalite usoro iwu gbasara okwu ahụ ma kọọ akụkọ na-abịa n'izu .

en: Public Bus (BRT) Currently Burning On Third Mainland Bridge In Lagos
ibo: Ụgbọ ala na-akwọ ọha na eze (BRT) Ugbu a na-agba Ọkụ n'akwa mmiri III Mainland na Legos

en: According to an eyewitness, the blue bus, which was heading towards Iyana-Oworo, caught fire just after Adeniji Adele axis of the bridge with the disaster resulting in chaos and heavy traffic gridlock
ibo: Dị ka onye hụrụ ya hụrụ, ụgbọ ala ahụ na-acha anụnụ anụnụ, nke na-aga Iyana-Oworo, gbara ọkụ mgbe Adeniji Adele gbariri àkwà mmiri nke kpatara ọdachi kpatara ọgbaghara na nnukwu okporo ụzọ.

en: There is chaos on the third mainland bridge right now as one of the buses used for the bus rapid transit (BRT) in Lagos is currently burning on the bridge.
ibo: Enwere ọgbaghara na akwa mmiri nke ala ugbu a dịka otu n'ime ụgbọ ala ndị e ji mee njem ngwa ngwa (BRT) na Legos na-agba ọkụ ugbu a na akwa mmiri.

en: According to an eyewitness, the blue bus, which was heading towards Iyana-Oworo, caught fire just after Adeniji Adele axis of the bridge with the disaster resulting in chaos and heavy traffic gridlock.
ibo: Dabere na onye hụrụ ya anya, ụgbọ ala na-acha anụnụ anụnụ, nke na-aga Iyana-Oworo, gbara ọkụ mgbe Adeniji Adele gbariri àkwà mmiri nke kpatara ọdachi ọgbaghara na nnukwu okporo ụzọ.

en: It is unclear if there have been any casualties from the incident.
ibo: Amabeghị ma onwere onye meruru ahu na ihe ndachị ahụ

en: The officials of Lagos fire service and LASTMA are desperately trying to put out the fire and ensure order in the area.
ibo: Ndị ọrụ nchekwa ọkụ na Legos na LASTMA na-achọsi ike ịmenyu ọkụ ma hụ na enwere nhazị dị na mpaghara ahụ.

en: Queen's College Student To Face Disciplinary Panel Over Artificial Eyelashes
ibo: Nwa akwụkwọ nke Queen's College ga-aza ndị na-agbazị mmadụ maka nku anya ọkwunyere.

en: The college's Parents-Teachers Association have condemned the girl's mother seen in a viral video harassing a security guard of the school because her daughter was punished, according to The Nation.
ibo: Ndị otu nne na nna ndị nkuzi kọleji ahụ katọrọ nne nwa nwanyị ahụ a hụrụ na ihe nkiri na-enye ndị nche ụlọ akwụkwọ ahụhụ n'ihi ntaramahụhụ nwa ya nwanyị, ka 'Nation' kwuru.

en: Queen's College was founded as a girls' school in 1927 during the colonial era
ibo: E guzobere Queen's College dị ka ụlọ akwụkwọ ụmụ nwanyị na 1927 n'oge ọchịchị ndị ọcha

en: More details have emerged about what transpired in the viral video of a Queen's College pupil harassed out of the college for wearing artificial eyelashes and painting her nails.
ibo: Nkọwa ndị ọzọ apụtaala gbasara ihe mere na ihe nkiri nke nwa akwụkwọ Queen's College agbara akwụkwọ na kọleji maka ịkwụnye nku anya ma tee kwa mbọ aka.

en: The college's Parents-Teachers Association have condemned the girl's mother seen in a viral video harassing a security guard of the school because her daughter was punished, according to The Nation.
ibo: Ndị otu nne na nna ndị nkuzi kọleji ahụ katọrọ nne nwa nwanyị ahụ a hụrụ na ihe nkiri na-enye ndị nche ụlọ akwụkwọ ahụhụ n'ihi ntaramahụhụ nwa ya nwanyị, ka The Nation kwuru.

en: The girl had resumed two weeks late after midterm on Monday and was being punished for wearing artificial eyelashes and painted nails.
ibo: Nwatakịrị nwanyị ahụ lọghachitere izu abụọ ka ọ gafesịrị ezumike ha na Mọnde, enye ya ntaramahụhụ maka iyi nku anya ma tee mbọ aka.

en: However, unknown to her teachers, her mother was watching but did not identify herself.
ibo: Agbanyeghị, ndị nkuzi amaghị na nne ya na-ele ma onweghị onye ọ kọwara onwe ya.

en: Trouble started when she attempted to drag the girl out of the school and the security man (not knowing she was the mother) challenged her.
ibo: Nsogbu malitere mgbe ọ nwara ịchụpụ nwa agbọghọ ahụ n'ụlọ akwụkwọ na nwoke nchekwa (n'amaghị na ọ bụ nne ya) mara ya aka.

en: The mother reacted by attacking the security guard.
ibo: Nne ya mere ihe site na ịwakpo onye nche.

en: A source said, 'The girl was returning to school two weeks after the mid-term had ended.
ibo: akụkọ kọrọ, sị, 'Nwata nwanyị ahụ loghachitere ụlọ akwụkwọ izu abụọ ka izu ezumike gwuru.

en: When the teachers saw her with eyelashes and painted nails, they asked her to kneel down.
ibo: Mgbe ndị nkuzi hụrụ nku anya ya na mbọ aka ya, ha gwara ya gbuo ikpere n'ala.

en: Her mother came in with her, sat down and listened but did not say anything.
ibo: Mama ya batara, soro ya nọdụ ala ma gee ntị ma ọ nweghị ihe ọ bụla o kwuru.

en: Someone heard her telling her daughter in Igbo that she should run away.
ibo: Otu onye nụrụ mgbe ọ na-agwa nwa ya nwanyị na olu Igbo na ya gbaa ọsọ.

en: But the girl refused.
ibo: Ma nwa agbọghọ ahụ jụrụ.

en: After the third time, the mother grabbed the girl's bag and made to leave.
ibo: Mgbe oge nke atọ gasịrị, nne ya jidere akpa nwa agbọghọ ahụ wee chọọ ịpụ.

en: When people realised that she was the girl's mother, she quickly dragged the girl out. The security man did not did not know it was the girl's mother dragging her out.
ibo: Mgbe ndị mmadụ matara na ọ bụ nne nwatakịrị nwanyị ahụ, ọ kpọpụtara nwa agbọghọ ahụ ngwa ngwa. Onye nchekwa amabeghị na ọ bụ nne nwa agbọghọ ahụ na-akpọpụta ya.

en: In an attempt to ask why she was taking one of our students out, that was when she attacked the security man.
ibo: Mgbe ọ si ka ọjụọ ihe mere o ji na-akpọpụ otu n'ime ụmụ akwụkwọ anyị, ọ bụ mgbe ahụ ka ọ wakporo nwoke ahụ na-eche nche.

en: The girl was even remorseful .
ibo: Nwa agbọghọ ahụ chegharịrị .

en: She was asking the mother why she was disgracing her .
ibo: Ọ nọ na-ajụ nne ya ihe mere o ji na-emenyere ya ihere .

en: The source said the girl was returned to school by her mother on Tuesday and would face disciplinary measures.
ibo: Isi akụkọ ahụ kwuru na nne ya kpọghachiri ya n'ụlọ akwụkwọ na Tuzde ebe ọ ga-anara usoro ọzụzụ.

en: The source added, the woman came to drop the girl around 5:00am in the morning urging her to sneak into her class.
ibo: Isi akụkọ ahụ gbakwụnyere, nwanyị ahụ zụbara nwa agbọghọ ahụ n'ihe dị ka elekere 5 nke ụtụtụ wee gbaa ya ume ịbanye na klasi ya.

en: But the girl did not sneak .
ibo: Ma nwa agbọghọ ahụ agaghị.

en: She stood by the security gate till morning and presented herself to the school management.
ibo: O guzo n'akuku uzo nche rue ututu wee gosi onwe ya onye isi ụlọ akwụkwọ.

en: A man who claimed to be her father came to the school to apologise on her behalf but we found out that he is not her father .
ibo: Otu nwoke nke kwuru na ya bụ nna ya bịara ụlọ akwụkwọ ịrịọ mgbaghara mana anyị chọpụtara na ọ bụghị nna ya.

en: She will face the disciplinary committee .
ibo: Ọ ga-eche kọmitii ọzụzụ .

en: Many people – including the state, are now interested in the case .
ibo: Ọtụtụ ndị mmadụ - gụnyere steeti, nwere mmasị ugbu a n'okwu ikpe.

en: So we are investigating .
ibo: Ya mere anyị na-eme nchọpụta .

en: In a statement, the Caretaker Committee of the College's PTA noted that the association was in support of the school management's position on discipline .
ibo: Na nkwupụta, Kọmịshọna na-ahụ maka PTA kọleji ahụ kwuru na ndị otu ahụ nọ na-akwado ọnọdụ nchịkwa ụlọ akwụkwọ na ịdọ aka na ntị .

en: The statement reads: We condemn in totality the action of the parent .
ibo: Nkwupụta ahụ kwuru, sị: 'Anyị na-akatọ akparamagwa dum nne na nna ya.

en: We stand by the management in enforcing discipline in the school .
ibo: Anyị na-eguzo n'akụkụ ndị nlekọta ụlọ akwụkwọ na ịmanye ịkpa ezi agwa n'ụlọ akwụkwọ.

en: However, the Committee will invite both the parent and the student with a view to ameliorating the situation and preventing a repeat of similar occurrence .
ibo: Otuodi, Kọmitii ahụ ga-akpọ ma nne ma nna ma nwa akwụkwọ ahụ ka ha chebara ọnọdụ ahụ echiche wee gbochie imeghachi ụdị ihe ahụ.

en: The lesson we need to take home on this is simply that Queen's College will not tolerate violation of its well settled rules and regulations.'
ibo: Ihe nkuzi anyị kwesịrị ịmụta na nke a bụ naanị na ụlọ akwụkwọ Queen agaghị anabata iwu megidere ya na ụkpụrụ ya .

en: Questions Amaechi Should Answer On Transportation University By Olabisi Deji-Folutile
ibo: Ajụjụ Amaechi Kwesịrị ịza gbasara ụgbọ njem mahadum Site na Olabisi Deji-Folutile

en: Honestly, Nigeria should concentrate on building its research capacity and developing innovative curricula that will help its students develop the crucial skills of creativity and critical thinking.
ibo: N'ezie, Naịjirịa kwesiri itinye uche na iwulite ikike nyocha ya na iwulite usoro mmụta ga-enyere ụmụ akwụkwọ ya aka ịzụlite ikike dị mkpa nke okike na echiche siri ike.

en: These are some of the things that can make Nigeria relevant in the development space.
ibo: Ihe ndị a bụ ụfọdụ n'ime ihe nwere ike ime ka Naịjirịa nwee ohere na mmepe obodo.

en: I never believed Nigeria was serious about starting a Transportation University until Monday when President Muhammadu Buhari and other government officials commissioned the project in Daura, the President's home town.
ibo: Ekweteghị m na Naịjirịa kpọrọ ịmalite Mahadum ụgbọ njem ihe ruo ụbọchị Mọnde mgbe Onye isi ala bụ Muhammadu Buhari na ndị ọrụ gọọmentị ndị ọzọ mepere ọrụ ahụ na Daura, obodo nke Onye isi ala.

en: The university, according to Transportation Minister, Mr Rotimi Amaechi, is a response to the question of how Nigeria would maintain and manage its railway infrastructure.
ibo: Mahadum ahụ, ka mịnịsta ụgbọ njem, Mazị Rotimi Amaechi si kwuo, bụ azịza nye ajụjụ ahụ banyere etu Naịjirịa ga-esi lekọta ma jikwaa akụrụngwa okporo ụzọ ya.

en: The reason given notwithstanding, the whole gamut of excitement that characterized the groundbreaking ceremony, suggests something else.
ibo: N'agbanyeghị ihe kpatara ya, obi ụtọ niile nke emume a, na-egosi ihe ozo.

en: Going by the way the minister resorted to insults and vituperation on Nigerians that dared to query the rationale for establishing the university in the President's home town;
ibo: Otu mịnịsta ahụ jiri mkparịa ndị Naịjirịa juru maka ebumnuche iguzo mahadum n'obodo nke Onye isi ala;

en: It appears the project was borne out of political contingency than any other reason.
ibo: Ọ dị ka ebumnuche nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị karịrị ihe ọzọ ọ bụla .

en: Besides, Amaechi stole the show at the ceremony that ordinarily should have been organised by the ministry of education and the National Universities Commission in conjunction with the Transportation ministry
ibo: Agbanyeghị, Amaechi weere ụbọchị ahụ nke kwesịrị isite na ngalaba agụmakwụkwọ na ụlọ ọrụ n'ahụ maka ọchịchị Mahadum ma gbaziri ụlọ ọrụ na ahụ maka ụgbọ njem .

en: From the minister's excitement, it is as if the transportation university is the best thing that has ever happened to Nigeria in recent times.
ibo: Site na mkparịta ụka obi ụtọ nke onye ozi, ọ dị ka a ga - asị na mahadum njem ahụ bụ ihe kachasị mma nke emetụla na Naịjirịa n'oge ndị na - adịbeghị anya .

en: He boasted about how he forced the China Civil Engineering Construction Company to undertake the project by refusing to sign the contract for Lagos-Ibadan Rail project and how he also forced the company to take some Nigerians to China for training in railway technology .
ibo: O turu ọnụ banyere etu o siri mee ka ụlọ ọrụ na akụ igwè nke China wee rụọ ọrụ a site na ịhapụ ịbịanye aka na nkwekọrịta maka iwu ụzọ tren Legos / Ibadan na otu o si manye ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ịkpọrọ ụfọdụ ndị Naịjirịa gaa mba China maka ọzụzụ gbasara iwu okporo ụzọ .

en: The Director of Rail Services of the Federal Ministry of Transportation, Mohammed Babakobi, didn't help matter, as he too, was more concerned about why the university must be in the President's town.
ibo: Onye isi n'ahụ maka okporo tren na Naịjirịa bụ Mohammed Babakobi, enyereghị aka n'okwu a, ihe kachasị dị ya mkpa bụ ihe kpatara eji hibe mahadum a n'obodo onye isi ala.

en: Amaechi's action, reminds me of the popular Yoruba adage that says forcing a man to get married is not a big deal, but making him to make provision for the family is the real work .
ibo: Ihe Amaechi mere, na-echetara m usoro ilu ndị ofe mmanụ a ma ama na-ekwu na ịmanye nwoke ịlụ nwaanyị abụghị mkpa, mana ime ka ọ zụọ ezinaụlọ ya nri bụ ọrụ .

en: Beyond constructing a university structure, there are numerous questions that Amaechi must answer to convince Nigerians that he understands what he is doing .
ibo: N'agbanyeghị iwu mahadum a, enwere ọtụtụ ajụjụ Amaechi ga-azariri iji mee ka ndị Naịjirịa kwenye na ọ ghọtara ihe ọ na-eme .

en: For example, he needs to come clear on who owns the university and the institution that is funding it .
ibo: Dịka ọmụmaatụ, ọ kwesiri ịpụta kwuo onye nwe mahadum ahụ na ụlọ ọrụ na-akwado ya .

en: Is it to be fully funded by the Chinese government or partly funded by the Federal Government ?
ibo: Ọ bụ ndị gọọmentị China ga-enweta ego nkwado ya ka ọ bụ gọọmentị etiti na-akwado ?

en: The only reason why anybody should be excited about a transportation university in Nigeria at a time like this as far as I am concerned is if the CCECC is fully running it as a gift to Nigeria .
ibo: Naanị otu ihe mere mmadụ ọ bụla kwesịrị iji nwee obi ụtọ banyere mahadum njem na Naịjirịa n'oge dị ka nke a bụ na ọ bụrụ na ọ bụ CCECC na-arụ ya nke ọma dịka onyinye nye Naịjirịa .

en: But, if all that CCECC is doing is to construct a university as part of its corporate social responsibility, then Amaechi's display of a sense of achievement is totally misplaced .
ibo: Mana, ọ bụrụ na ihe niile CCECC na-eme bụ ibulite mahadum dị ka akụkụ nke ọrụ mmekọrịta ya na ụlọ ọrụ, mgbe ahụ, ngosipụta Amaechi gosipụtara na ọ ga-eme ka a mata nke ọma ma inwe mahadum njem ọ bụ ihe kachasị mkpa na Naịjirịa .

en: If government wants to develop transportation, what stops it from expanding transport departments in existing universities ?
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị chọrọ imepụta ngalaba njem, gịnị na-egbochi ya ịgbasa ngalaba njem na mahadum ndị dị ugbu a ?

en: The Institute of Transportation in Zaria is there as well as many others .
ibo: Ụlọ akwụkwọ nke ụgbọ njem dị na Zaria na ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ .

en: The Federal Government could have simply increased the capacity of existing institutions to provide better manpower and training in the sector.
ibo: Gọọmentị etiti gaara enyekwu ikike nye ụlọ ọrụ ndị dị ugbu a iji nye ndị mmadụ ọzụzụ kachasị mma na mpaghara ahụ .

en: For me, it doesn't make any difference where the university is sited.
ibo: Maka m, ọ nweghị ọdịiche ọ bụla ebe edoziri mahadum ahụ .

en: I believe the current administration has proved beyond any reasonable doubt that it does not have any iota of regard for federal character.
ibo: Ekwenyere m na nchịkwa gọọmentị ugbu a gosipụtara n'enweghị obi abụọ ọ bụla enweghị ezi uche ọbụla maka nchịkọta gọọmentị .

en: President Buhari showed the direction his administration would follow with his very first set of appointments and he has continued on that path ever since.
ibo: Onye isi ala bụ Buhari gosipụtara ụzọ ọchịchị ya ga - agbaso na nhọpụta ndị ọrụ ya, ọ na - aga n'ihu n'ụzọ ahụ kemgbe .

en: So, there is no point dissipating energy on something that is not likely to change.
ibo: Yabụ, enweghị isi na-agbasapụrụ ike na ihe n'agaghị enwe ike mgbanwe.

en: The reason given by President Buhari for establishing the Transportation University is even more interesting.
ibo: Ebumnuche nke Onye isi ala Buhari nyere maka iguzobe Mahadum ugbọ njem na-adọrọ mmasị karị .

en: According to him, the university will bring rapid development to the nation's transport sector and generate both academic and non-academic employment opportunities to Nigerians.
ibo: Dị ka ya si kwuo, mahadum ahụ ga-eweta mmepe ngwa ngwa na ngalaba njem ụgbọ ala nke mba ma mepụta ohere ọrụ na agụmakwụkwọ nyere ndị Naịjirịa .

en: How can a Federal Government struggling to fund its 43 universities be on an adventure of establishing more ?
ibo: Kedụ ka gọọmentị si na-adọga ịkwado mahadum iri anọ na atọ ya ga-enwe obi ụtọ maka ịmalite ọzọ ?#

en: A lot of people, including our leaders, know that Nigeria's federal universities are nothing to write home about.
ibo: Ọtụtụ ndị mmadụ, gụnyere ndị isi anyị, maara na mahadum gọọmentị etiti Naịjirịa abụghị ihe edere banyere ya .

en: This is one of the reasons why you are not likely to find children of the President, governors and other political leaders in these universities.
ibo: Nke a bụ otu n'ime ihe kpatara na ọ rara ahu ka ịhụ ụmụ nke Onye isi ala, ndị gọvanọ na ndị isi ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ndị ọzọ na mahadum ndị a .

en: Many of the university administrators are struggling to cope.
ibo: Ọtụtụ n'ime ndị na-elekọta mahadum na-agbasi mbọ ike ịnagide .

en: Recently, the Vice Chancellor of the University of Ibadan, Prof. Idowu Olayinka, revealed that what the university was getting as overhead was less than N100m, whereas it needs a minimum of N800m for overhead.
ibo: N'oge na-adịbeghị anya, osote onye isi mahadum nke Ibadan, ọkammụta Idowu Olayinka kpughere na ihe mahadum ahụ na-enweta bụ nde narị naịra, ebe ọ chọrọ opekata mpe nde narị naịra asatọ .

en: The VC wondered where universities were expected to get money from when reacting to lawmakers' call for cancellation of admission fees in Nigeria's tertiary institutions .
ibo: VC na-eche ebe elere anya na mahadum ga-enweta ego site na mgbe ha na-aza oku ndị omebe iwu maka ịkagbu ụgwọ nnabata na ụlọ akwụkwọ mahadum nke Naịjirịa .

en: The VC said what the university gets from the Federal Government in one year is not enough to fund it in a month .
ibo: VC kwuru na ihe mahadum ahụ na-enweta n'aka gọọmentị etiti ala n'otu afọ ezughi iji kwado ya na otu ọnwa.

en: How soon can this Transportation University catch up with the rest of the world on rail technology ?
ibo: Ogologo oge ole ka Mahadum ụgbọ njem a ga - ejide ụwa ndị ọzọ na ogo teknọlọji ụgbọ oloko ?

en: When several countries are operating driverless trains and efficient underground rail system, Nigeria is still struggling to construct surface rail systems .
ibo: Mgbe ọtụtụ mba na-arụ ọrụ n'ụgbọ okporo ígwè na-enweghị ọkwọ ụgbọ ala ma na-arụ ọrụ nke ọma n'ime ala, Nigeria na-agbasi mbọ ike iji rụọ usoro okporo ụzọ .

en: The coaches here still run on the oldest technology and unfortunately for the country, its President thinks the aim of creating a university is to get people to be employed .
ibo: Ndị nkuzi ebe a ka na-agba ọsọ na teknọlọji kacha ochie ma ọ dị mwute na maka mba a, Onye isi ala ya na-eche na ebumnuche nke ịmepụta mahadum bụ iji mee ka ndị mmadụ were ọrụ .

en: The Texas Central train will soon be transporting riders on the 240-mile trip from Dallas-Fort Worth to Houston in less than 90 minutes, making it the fastest train in North America .
ibo: Okporo ígwè Texas ga-ebugharị ndị na-anya ụgbọ elu na njem 240 site na Dallas / Fort Worth na Houston erughị nkeji 90, na-eme ka ọ bụrụ ụgbọ oloko kachasị ọsọ na mpaghara ugwu nke mba America .

en: Going by the way we develop in Nigeria, it could take forever for the university to be relevant to the rail business .
ibo: Site na ụzọ anyị si zụlite na Naịjirịa, o nweghị ike iwere mahadum a ka ọ dị mkpa maka azụmahịa okporo ígwè. Teknọlọji ga-aga n'ihu na-aga n'ihu .

en: Technology will definitely keep evolving and it is almost certain that our leaders won't do what it takes to make the university relevant .
ibo: Ọ dịkwa ihere na ndị isi anyị agaghị eme ihe iji mee ka mahadum ahụ nwee ùgwù.

en: Engaging in high research and experimentation is one of the hallmarks of universities all over the world.
ibo: Itinye aka na nyocha dị elu na nnwale bụ otu n'ime ihe e ji mara mahadum n'ụwa niile .

en: How much budget does Nigeria devote to research in its universities ?
ibo: Ego ole ka Naịjirịa na-etinye na nyocha na mahadum ya?

en: As of today, Africa, as a continent, produces one per cent of research technologies in the world.
ibo: Ruo taa, Afrịka, dịka kọntinenti, na -emepụta otu pasenti nke nyocha n'ime ụwa.

en: Tackling this problem should be of more importance to the giant of Africa than turning universities to a constituency project.
ibo: Ijikwa nsogbu a kwesịrị ịbụ ihe kachasị mkpa nye ndị Africa karịa ịtụgharị mahadum ka ọ bụrụ ọrụ mpaghara.

en: As rightly noted by the African Research Universities Alliance, Africa can't speak about development until it has the capacity to generate its own knowledge.
ibo: Dika ekwupụtara nke oma site na otu jịkọrọ mahadum nke Afrika, Afrika apụghị ikwu okwu banyere mmepe rue mgbe o nwere ikike imeputa ihe omuma ya .

en: The rest of the world is concerned about how African universities are preparing students for the 4th Industrial Revolution (4IR) calling for more doctoral training.
ibo: Ndị ụwa ọzọ n'enwe mgbasa banyere otu ndị mahadum n'Afrika siri na-akwado ụmụ akwụkwọ maka agha mmekorita nke ano (4IR) na- achọ ka ha nwekwuo ọzụzụ ịbụ ọkammụta .

en: The challenge is lack of innovation and technologies that can solve the continent's problems.
ibo: Ihe ịma aka a bụ enweghị azịza na teknọlọji nwere ike idozi nsogbu kọntinent ahụ .

en: For those who will argue that this is the essence of establishing Transportation University, I challenge them to tell Nigerians where they hope to get the academic staff that will run the university from.
ibo: Maka ndị ga-ekwu na nke a bụ nhiwe maka ịmalite Mahadum ụgbọ njem, m na-ama ha aka ka m gwa ndị Naịjirịa ebe ha nwere olileanya inweta ndị ọrụ agụmakwụkwọ ga-esi na mahadum ahụ pụọ .

en: Are they going to be sourced from this current university system that is suffering from dearth of academic staff ?
ibo: Ha ga-enweta usoro mahadum a dị ugbu a na-arịa ụkọ nke ndị ọrụ agụmakwụkwọ ?

en: There are reports of universities renting staff to get their courses accredited by the National Universities Commission .
ibo: Enwere akụkọ nke mahadum na-akwụ ụgwọ ndị ọrụ mahadum iji nweta Mahadum nke Mahadum Mba.

en: The NUC cannot claim to be ignorant of this phenomenon.
ibo: Ndị NUC enweghị ike ikwu na ha amaghị maka ihe a.

en: A lot of lecturers in public universities work in private universities and vice versa .
ibo: Ọtụtụ ndị nkuzi na mahadum ọha na-arụ ọrụ na mahadum nkeonwe na nke ọzọ.

en: The NUC, for instance, has a template for the minimum number of PhDs that universities should have in each department, how many Nigerian universities meet this requirement ?
ibo: Dịka ọmụmaatụ, NUC nwere ndebiri maka ntakịrị ọnụọgụgụ PhD nke mahadum kwesịrị inwe na ngalaba ọ bụla, kedu mahadum Naịjirịa ruru ihe achọrọ.

en: How many universities in Nigeria are producing PhDs on annual basis ?
ibo: ụlọ akwụkwọ ole na Naịjirịa na emeputa ndị PhD kwa ubochi?

en: I know UI produces the highest number of PhDs annually but I doubt if it could produce up to 500 per annum.
ibo: Amaara m na UI na-emepụta ọnụ ọgụgụ kachasị elu nke PhD kwa afọ mana enwere m obi abụọ ma ọ nwere ike iwepụta ihe ruru 500 kwa afọ.

en: The last figure I knew was around 250 per annum.
ibo: Onu ogugu ikpeazụ m maara gbara 250 kwa afọ.

en: Honestly, Nigeria should concentrate on building its research capacity and developing innovative curricula that will help its students develop the crucial skills of creativity and critical thinking.
ibo: N'ezie, Naịjirịa kwesiri itinye uche na iwulite ikike nyocha ya na iwulite usoro mmụta ga - enyere ụmụ akwụkwọ ya aka ịzụlite ikike dị mkpa nke okike na echiche siri ike.

en: These are some of the things that can make Nigeria relevant in the development space.
ibo: Ihe ndị a bụ ụfọdụ n'ime ihe nwere ike ime ka Naịjirịa nwee ohere na mmepe.

en: China is one of the few countries in the world controlling over 80% of research innovations.
ibo: China bụ otu n'ime mba ole na ole n'ụwa na-achịkwa ihe karịrị pesent 80 nke nyocha.

en: The Federal Government should commit more resources into funding research activities and capacity building.
ibo: Gọọmentị ala kwesịrị itinyekwu akụ na ụba n'ime mmemme nyocha ego na ike ikike.

en: Universities are not secondary schools.
ibo: Mahadum abụghị ụlọ akwụkwọ sekọndrị.

en: We don't need this proliferation!
ibo: Anyị achọghị mmụba a!

en: Olabisi Deji-Folutile is a member of the Nigerian Guild of Editors.
ibo: Olabisi Deji-Folutile bụ onye otu ndị odeakwụkwọ nke Naịjirịa .

en: My most recent published article, 'Recalling Tai Solarin's prediction', which appeared in the first week of this month, ended with a series of questions .
ibo: Edemede m bipụtara n'oge na-adịbeghị anya, 'Icheta amụma Tai Solarin', nke pụtara n'izu mbụ nke ọnwa a, ji ọtụtụ ajụjụ jedebe.

en: I reproduce four of them that are most relevant to this sequel: 'Why is it that despite the Nigerian Left's insistence, at least since 1979, on the inevitability and irreducibility of a Revolutionary Party, the party has not emerged?
ibo: M mepụtara anọ n'ime ha nke dabara adaba na usoro a: 'Gịnị kpatara na n'agbanyeghị ntuli aka nke ndị Naịjirịa, ka ọ dịkarịa ala site na afọ 1979, maka mbuso agha na enweghị ike ọfụma nke otu mgbanwe, otu ahụ apụtabeghị ?

en: Why should we find ourselves repeating the same theses and propositions after every bloody and farcical display called 'election'?
ibo: Kedu ihe kpatara anyị ga - eji hụ na anyị na - emegharị otu echiche na atụmatụ a mgbe ngosipụta ọbara niile ana - akpọ 'ntuli aka' ?

en: How has Nigeria's ruling class been able to periodically renew itself, assume new organizational forms and continue its rule ?
ibo: Kedụ ka ndị ọchịchị Naịjirịa siri nwee ike ịhazị onwe ha oge ụfọdụ, were usoro nhazi ọhụrụ wee gaa n'ihu na-achị ya ?

en: Put differently, why has it not been possible to overthrow Nigeria's ruling capitalist class, as a class, or dislodge it as the dominant political force ?
ibo: N'akụkụ dị iche, gịnị kpatara na ọ kaghị enwe ike ịkwatu ndị isi ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa, dị ka klaasị, ma ọ bụ tufuo ya dị ka ike ọchịchị kacha ike ?

en: The day after the article appeared, a comrade, Wumi Raji, who is a Leftist academic at the Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, called me on phone .
ibo: Otu ụbọchị ka edemede ahụ pụtachara, otu komred bụ Wumi Raji, onye bụ onye agụmakwụkwọ akaịpa na Mahadum Obafemi Awolowo, Ile-Ife kpọrọ m na ekwentị.

en: After the usual pleasantries, he respectfully 'complained' that my article ended abruptly, that he had expected me to answer or begin to answer the questions I posed .
ibo: Mgbe ọ masịrị ya, ọ jiri nkwanye ugwu 'kọchaa' na edemede m gwụrụ na-akụghị ekwe, na ọ tụrụ anya na m ga-aza ma ọ bụ malite ịza ajụjụ ndị m jụrụ.

en: As I was about to suggest a time for us to discuss the answers on phone, he expressed preference for a written response – perhaps a sequel to the previous article .
ibo: Ka m na-achọ ịtụwa oge ka anyị kpaa mkparịta ụka n'ekwentị, o kwupụtara mmasị maka nzaghachi edereede m - ikekwe ide asịsam ede.

en: Finally, he 'requested' that the sequel should not take too long in coming .
ibo: N'ikpeazụ, ọ 'rịọrọ' ka usoro ahụ ghara iwe ogologo oge.

en: When he asked what I thought of his 'request' I told him bluntly that I did not understand what he asked me to do as a request, that I understood it as a comradely order which, coming, in particular, from his generation, I could not turn down.
ibo: Mgbe ọ jụrụ m ihe m chere banyere 'arịrịọ' a, agwara m ya n'ezoghị ọnụ na aghọtaghị m ihe ọ gwara m ka m mee dị ka arịrịọ, na m ghọtara ya dị ka iwu nke, na-abịa, ọkachasị, n'ọgbọ ya, m enweghị ike ịgbatu.

en: Wumi Raji did not give me any space in our brief telephone conversation to say something that I would have liked to say, namely, that my questions were drafted as open questions to the Nigerian Left.
ibo: Wumi Raji enyeghị m ohere ọ bụla na mkparịta ụka ekwentị dị mkpirikpi iji kwuo ihe m ga-enwe mmasị ikwu, ya bụ, na edepụtara ajụjụ m dị ka ajụjụ azịza nye n'aka ekpe ndị Nigeria.

en: They were not drafted as an introduction to a 'lecture' which, perhaps, I was preparing to deliver; nor were they rhetorical questions (which demand no answers) nor exam-type questions (which demand answers from entities that exclude the examiner).
ibo: E deghị ha ka okwu mmeghe nke 'nkuzi', ikekwe, m na-akwado ikwu; ha abụghịkwa ajụjụ ajụrụ (na achoghi azịza ha) ma ọ bụ ajụjụ (nke chọrọ azịza site n'aka ndi mmadụ ewezuga onye nlere).

en: In any case, what, practically, should I or could I do now, I asked myself at the end of my discussion with Raji.
ibo: N'ọnọdụ ọ bụla, kedu, ihe m ga - eme ma ọ bụ mee m ugbu a, ajụrụ m onwe m na njedebe nke mkparịta ụka mụ na Raji.

en: The answer, which came a day later, was that I could expand the questions and supply explanatory notes to some of them.
ibo: Azịza ya, nke bịara otu ụbọchị mgbe nke ahụ gasịrị, bụ na m nwere ike ịgbatị ajụjụ na ọkọnọ nkọwa ụfọdụ nye ha.

en: If I perform these minimum tasks well, I would have begun to contribute to discussions leading to answers.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ n'ọrụ ndị a pere mpe ọfụma, aga m amalite itinye aka na mkparịta ụka na-eduga azịza.

en: If the four questions I have reproduced here are combined, they translate to a loud and angry regret that since the end of Nigeria's Civil War in 1970 and particularly since the 1979 general elections with which the Second Republic (1979-1983) was inaugurated, a sufficiently strong Leftist Revolutionary Party has not emerged in the country to frontally and seriously challenge the ruling capitalist class.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na ejikọta ajụjụ anọ ndị m depụtara ebe a, ha tụgharịrị gaa n'oké iwe na ebe ọ bụ na kemgbe njedebe nke agha Naịjirịa na 1970 na karịsịa kemgbe e guzobere ntuli aka 1979 nke bụ repọblik nke abụọ (1979-1983), ndị otu mgbanwe akaịpa nke nwere ike zuru oke apụtabeghị na mba ahụ n'ihu na ịma ndị isi ọchịchị aka ike ọchịchị.

en: This serious and frontal challenge would have been either for power or for the dominant political position in the country or, minimally, for a significant shift in the balance of socio-political forces in favour of the working and toiling masses of Nigeria.
ibo: Ihe ịma aka a dị mkpa ga-abụ maka ike ma ọ bụ n'ọkwá ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị kachasị na mba ahụ ma ọ bụ obere, maka mgbanwe dị ukwuu na nguzosi ike nke ndị ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na-akwado ọrụ na ike Naịjirịa.

en: This regret about what could have happened—but did not, or had not happened—now translates back to a single question, Why?
ibo: Ta ụta a banyere ihe gaara eme — ma ọ meghị, ma ọ bụ emeghị — ugbu a sụgharịrị n'otu ajụjụ, N'ihi gịnị?

en: In my view, a view shared by many Leftists, the major reasons for the non-emergence of a Revolutionary Party, sufficiently strong to frontally and seriously challenge Nigeria's ruling capitalist class may be broadly separated into two segments: the objective and the subjective.
ibo: N'echiche m, echiche nke ọtụtụ ndị akaịpa, bụ isi ihe kpatara na enweghị mmalite nke otu mgbanwe, nke nwere ike zuru oke iji chee ihu na ịma ndị isi ọchịchị Naịjirịa aka nwere ike ikewapụ onwe ha ụzọ abụọ: ebumnuche na isiokwu ahụ.

en: We may defer the objective reasons.
ibo: Anyị nwere ike wepụ ebumnuche.

en: But of the subjective reasons, the most prominent is what I had described as 'differences within the Nigerian Left' (The Guardian, October 4, 2018).
ibo: Mana nke ndị metụtara ya, nke akachasị mara bụ nke m kọwara dị ka ndịrịta iche dị n'etiti ndị hapụrụ ala Naịjirịa . (Guardian, Ọktọba 4, 2018).

en: This important factor will be our focus in the rest of this piece.
ibo: Ihe a dị mkpa ga-abụ ihe anyị ga-elebara anya na ibe ya.

en: It is on account of the differences within the Left that I have insisted, in the last two years, on the production and dissemination of a People's Manifesto.
ibo: Ọ bụ n'ihi ọdịiche dị na ekpe a ka m siri ọnwụ na, n'ime afọ abụọ gara aga, na nrụpụta na mgbasa nke Manifesto nke Ndị mmadụ.

en: My reasoning is that in the process of producing and disseminating the People's Manifesto (The Left platform) the differences that many Leftists presume do not exist, or are not serious, will emerge and be engaged.
ibo: Echiche m bụ na n'ịmepụta ma na-agbasa echiche nke Manifesto (nke nyiwe akaịpa) ọdịiche ọtụtụ ndị akaịpa chere na-adị, ma ọ bụ na-adịghị njọ, ga-apụta ma tinye aka .

en: It is, of course, expected that the Manifesto—which in the process of production and dissemination will begin to resolve our internal differences—will first appear as a robust draft document that attempts to take precise positions on some critical questions before the masses and the nation.
ibo: N'ezie, a tụrụ anya na Manifesto — nke ga - emeputa ma kesaa ga - ebido idozi esemokwu dị n'ime anyị - ga - ebu ụzọ gosipụta akwụkwọ siri ike nke na - anwa iweghara ọnọdụ ụfọdụ dị mkpa n'ihu nnukwu mba .

en: The draft may begin with a Preamble or Introduction: Who we are, what we propose to do, the agency of the revolutionary transformation and the social forces of the transformation.
ibo: Mpempe akwụkwọ ahụ nwere ike ịmalite ma ọ bụ Okwu Mmalite: wenye anyị bụ, ihe anyị na-atụ alo ime, ụlọ ọrụ nke mgbanwe na ndị otu ndị na - eme mgbanwe .

en: It may then go on to Popular-Democratic Ideas (constitutional and republican democracy, the rule of law, the state and the people, socioeconomic rights, political rights and civil rights).
ibo: Ọ nwere ike ịga n'ihu na echiche ndị ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya (usoro iwu ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na usoro iwu, steeti na ndị mmadụ, ikike mmekọrịta ọha na eze, ikike ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na ikike obodo).

en: It may then proceed to Strategy of the Revolutionary Transformation; Democratic Governance; Philosophy of Governance and Principles of State Policy; SocioEconomic Restructuring; The National Question, National Unity and Geo-political Restructuring; National Independence and Foreign Policy.
ibo: Ọ nwere ike ịga n'ihu na Usoro nke Mgbanwe; Ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya; Nkà ihe ọmụma banyere ọchịchị na ụkpụrụ nke iwu Ọchịchị; Idozi akụ na ụba ndị mmadụ; Ajụjụ Mba ahụ, ịdị n'otu mba na idozigharị ihe ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị; Nnwereonwe nke mba na iwu Ofesi.

en: The document should, of course, end with a Transitional Programme (immediate agenda).
ibo: Akwụkwọ ahụ kwesịrị, n'ezie, ijedebe na Usoro Mgbanwe (usoro a na-eme ozugbo).

en: My current position on each of these proposed elements of a Peoples Manifesto has been explicit in my published articles of the past two years.
ibo: Ekwupụtalam ọnọdụ m na nke ọ bụla ugbu a n'ime akwụkwọ m bipụtara n'afọ abụọ gara aga.

en: But a particular sensitive subject—the National Question—requires further explanatory notes here.
ibo: Ma otu isiokwu dị ire - ajụjụ nke mba - chọrọ nkọwa ndị ọzọ.

en: Nigerian Leftists, especially Marxists, know or should know that neither theory nor history has resolved what Marxism knows as the National Question—from the standpoint of Marxism.
ibo: Ndị akaịpa nke Naịjirịa, ọkachasị ndị otu Marx ma ọ bụ na edemede ma akụkọ ntolite emebeghị mkpebi nke Marxism, dị ka ajụjụ nke mba - site n'echiche nke Marxism.

en: Had it been resolved—even if badly—we could have been more confident to take positions on the tragic things that happened within the leaderships of the ruling communist parties of the former Soviet Union, former Yugoslavia and former Czechoslovakia and to the countries and peoples over whom they ruled for decades.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na e kpebiri ya, ọbụlagodi ma ọ dị njọ - anyị nwere ike inwe ntụkwasị obi karịa ịnwe ọnọdụ n'ihe ọjọọ ndị mere n'etiti ndị isi nke ndị otu ọchịchị Kọmunist n'oge mbụ otu Soviet, Yugoslavia na mbụ. Czechoslovakia na mba ndị dị n'ofe ndi ha chiri arọ iri.

en: If there were a near-settled Marxist position on the National Question the enduring ethnic question in China (since the 1949 Revolution) would not have remained an embarrassing issue for Marxists and socialists everywhere.
ibo: Oburu na ndopụta ndị Marxist dị nso n'ajụjụ nke mba China n'abia (kemgbe Mgbanwe nke 1949 ) agaraghị adị ihe idochu ndị Marxist na ndị ọkacha amara n'ebe niile.

en: If the history of Marxism had handed us a resolution of the National Question, we would have been bolder in taking positions on what happened between Ethiopian and Eritrean Marxists and Leftists in the last quarter of last century.
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na akụkọ banyere Marxism wetara anyị mkpebi nke Ajụjụ mba, anyị gaara enwe obi ike were ọnọdụ maka ihe mere n'etiti ndị Etiopia na ndị Eritrea na ndị akaịkpa na nkeji iri na ise gara aga.

en: And coming home, if we had a near-settled theory or if Marxism had substantially advanced the debate on the National Question since the Russian Revolution and the Third International, Nigerian Marxists would today be bolder to take positions on what happened to the Nigerian Marxist Left during the Nigerian Civil War and on the status of current pro-Biafra Nigerian Marxists.
ibo: Ma na abia n'ulo, oburu na anyị nwere echiche dị nso ma ọ bụ nweko nke Marxism mere nke oma na nkparịta ụka nke ala, ajụjụ nke ndị Russia kemgbe ndị Ju nke Russia na ndị nke atọ, ndị ala Marxist ga enwe obi ike iguzosi ike n'ihe mere ndị ọchịchị nke ndị Marxist n'oge agha obodo Naịjirịa na ọkwa ndị ugbu a. Ndị ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị ndị Naịjirịa tupu Biafra abịa.

en: I do not know how many living Nigerian Marxists followed and still remember the public 'national question' debate between two leading Nigerian Leftist intellectuals: Comrade GG Darah and the late Comrade Yusufu Bala Usman about a decade ago.
ibo: Amaghị m mmadụ ole ndị ndọrọndọrọ ala Naịjirịa sochiri ma na-echeta arụmụka a na-ajụ ajụjụ gbasara 'ajụjụ mba' n'etiti ndị isi ọgụgụ isi nke ndị akaịpa Naịjirịa: Comrade GG Darah na onye nke nwuru anwụ Comrade Yusufu Bala Usman ihe dị ka afọ iri gara aga.

en: Let me end the present piece with the following poser: Before, during and after the Russian Revolution, a Marxist tendency closely connected with Lenin introduced 'national oppression' as a 'Marxist category, related to class oppression but not identical with or subordinate to it'
ibo: Ka m kwubie okwu a ugbua site n'ihe ndịa: Tupu, n'oge na mgbe mbugharị Russia gasịrị, echiche Marxist nwere njịkọ chiri anya na Lenin gosipụtara 'mmegbu nke mba' dị ka otu 'ụdị Marxist, metụtara mmegbu otu mana ọ bụghị otu ihe ma ọ bụ nọ n'okpuru ya. ',

en: Whereas in that period, Rosa Luxembourg, who requires no introduction, stood (and still stands) 'at the apex of the attempt to make operational the Marxist concept of class as the primary social referent, and to break once and for all the old alternative stranglehold of nation'.
ibo: Ebe oge ahụ, Rosa Luxembourg, onye na-achọghị iwebata, guzo (ma kwụrụ ọtọ)' na njịkọ nke nnwale iji mee ka echiche nke Marxist nke otu bụrụ ntụle maka mmekọrịta mmadụ na ibe ya, yana imebi ozugbo oge niile. uzọ ochie ọzọ nke mba '.

en: From this poser I propose that Nigerian Leftists, especially those of Marxist orientation, should advance the debate on the National Question and Geopolitical Restructuring in Nigeria with the twin-objective of arriving at a common position in Nigeria and simultaneously contributing to the further development of Marxism on this question.
ibo: Site n'okwu a, m na-ekwupụta na ndị akaịpa Naịjirịa, ọkachasị nke mgbakwasị ụkwụ Marxist, kwesịrị ịkwalite arụmụka ahụ na Ajụjụ mba na idozi gburugburu ọchịchị Naịjirịa nwere ebumnuche ibilite n'otu ọnọdụ na Naịjirịa ma n'otu oge na-enye aka maka mmepe nke Marxism n'ajụjụ a.

en: This effort will also, simultaneously, advance the process of founding a nationwide Revolutionary Party that is substantial, authoritative and respected.
ibo: Mgbalị a ga-emekwa n'otu oge ahụ ga - eme ka usoro ịchọpụta otu Ntugharị Mba nke dị ukwuu, nke nwere ikike na nkwanye ùgwù.

en: Torrential rain has destroyed makeshift tents and caused severeflooding to temporary displacement camps in northeast Nigeria, leaving vulnerable families homeless.
ibo: Oke mmiri ozuzo ebibiela ụlọ ntu nke mere obere oge ma mekwaa ka idei mmiri jupụta n'ogige ịhapụ ụlọ nwa oge na ugwu ọwụwa anyanwụ Naịjirịa, ma mee ka ezinụlọ dị iche iche hara ịnwe ebe obibi.

en: In Dikwa, 500 people have been rendered homeless due to flooding and have set up home in disused registration centres .
ibo: Na Dịkwa, mmadụ 500 aburula ndị enweghị ebe obibi n'ihi ịde mmiri ma hiwe ụlọ n'ụlọ ebe ndị a na-edebe akwụkwọ maka ndị a na-akwabeghị.

en: Large numbers of families, who fled from conflict months ago, are left homeless while others are forced to share overcrowded tents with neighbours or relatives
ibo: Ọnụ ọgụgụ dị ukwuu nke ezinụlọ, bụ ndị gbabara n'ọgba aghara ọnwa gara aga, bụ ndị na-enweghị ebe obibi ebe ndị ọzọ na-amanye ka ha soro ndị agbata obi ma ọ bụ ndị ikwu ụlọikwuu karịrị akarị

en: My home is completely destroyed.
ibo: Ụlọ m bibiri kpamkpam.

en: My floor has turned to mud and water is everywhere.
ibo: Ala m aghọọla apịtị na olulu mmiri n'ebe niile.

en: The rain keeps coming and we do not have any choice butto wait for it to stop or share with others,' said displaced mother-of-four Fatima Mohammed (30)
ibo: Amaghị ebe mmiri ahụ si na-abịa, anyị enweghị nhọrọ ọzọ karịa ichere ka ọ kwụsị ma ọ bụ ịnọọrọ ndị ọzọ - Fatima Mohammed (30) nne ụmụ anọ kwuru.

en: The Adamawa State government, the organization said, had officially declared an outbreak of cholera in three local government areas duringthe rainy season.
ibo: Gọọmentị steeti Adamawa ekwupụtala ọkwa na oria ọgbụgba. n'ime mpaghara ọchịchị obodo atọ n'oge mmiri.

en: The total number of cases reported as of August 16 stands at 633.
ibo: ọnụọgụgụ nke mkpesa emere na ọnwa ọgọst 16 bụ 633.

en: Four people have so far lost their lives to the disease.
ibo: Mmadụ anọ ka agụtagoru bụ ndi tufugoro ndụ ha n'aka nrịanrịa .

en: Due to recent heavy rain and flooding, more cases could be confirmed over the coming weeks, the NRC pointed out .
ibo: Site na mmiri ozuzo na ide mmiri oge na-adịbeghị anya, enwere ike ikwenye ọnọdụ ndị ọzọ na izu ndị na-abịa, NRC mere ka ọ pụta ìhè.

en: There are no sanitation or drainage facilities in most camps.
ibo: Enweghị adịmọcha ọbụla ma ọ bụ ọwa mmiri n'ọtụtụ ogige.

en: People are going to the toilet in open spaces because there are nofacilities for them to use and now that the camps are filled withstagnant floodwater, water-borne diseases like cholera quicklyspread,' Batonon added.
ibo: Ndị mmadụ na-aga ụlọ mposi n'ime oghere maka enweghị ebe ha nwere ike iji rụọ ọrụ ma ugbu a ụlọ ọrụ jupụtara na ide mmiri, ọrịa ndị eji mmiri ebute dị ka ọgbụgbọ na-agbasa ngwa ngwa, 'Batonon kwukwara.

en: Meanwhile, the United Nations and partners have appealed for $848million to address the needs in northeast Nigeria this year.
ibo: Ka ọ dị ugbu a, otu jịkọrọ mba na ndị mmekọ rịọrọ arịrịọ maka nde dọla 848 iji lebara mkpa ndị dị na ugwu ọwụwa anyanwụ Naịjirịa afọ a.

en: About eight months into the year, less than 40 per cent has been received.
ibo: Ihe dika ọnwa asatọ dị n'ime afọ ahụ aga, eritebeghị pasent 40 n'ime ya.

en: Additional financial support is urgently needed to reach the 6.2million people targeted for humanitarian aid in 2019.
ibo: A na-achọ nkwado ngwa ngwa iji gwoo nde mmadụ 6.2 ezubere maka enyemaka mmadụ na 2019.

en: People will die if they don´t receive urgent assistance now,' Batonon said.
ibo: Ndị mmadụ ga-anwụ ma ọ bụrụ na ha enwetaghị enyemaka ugbu a,' Batonon kwuru.

en: Furthermore, heavy rain periods present opportunities by armed groupsto infiltrate and target displacement camps.
ibo: Ma, oke mmiri ozuzo na - enye ohere site n'aka ndị otu ndi agha gbabigoro ma buso ogige ndị mmadu agha.

en: On Tuesday night (August 20) in Dikwa, a female suicide bomberdetonated a bomb, killing herself and injuring four civilians.
ibo: N'abalị Tuzdee (ọgọst 20) na Dika, nwanyị gbara ogbunigwe tụbara bọmbụ, gbuo onwe ya ma merụọ ndị nkịtị anọ ahụ.

en: This was the first attack of its kind in the area since December 2018.
ibo: Nke a bụ nke mbu n'mpaghara ebe a na Disemba afọ 2018.

en: RE: DSS And The 6th December Federal High Court, Abuja Incident By Lucky Ighoyota
ibo: RE: DSS na Ụlọ Ọkaịkpe nke Ụbọchị Isii N'Ọnwa Disemba, ihe mere n'Abuja site n'aka Lucky Ighoyota

en: The invasion of the Federal High Court on Friday by DSS operatives to perfect a rearrest of Omoyele Sowore and his co-defendant, Olawale Bakare, less than 24 hours after they were granted bail is the highest act of sacrilege against the judicial arm of government that the operative has constantly expressed contempt for .
ibo: Mwakpo nke ụlọ ọrụ ndị ọkaịkpe wakporo na Fraịdee ka onye ọrụ ya bụ Omoyele Sowore na onye na - agbachitere ya, Olawale Bakare erughị awa iri abụọ na anọ ka enyere ha ohere mgbapụta bụ ihe kacha njọ na-akwado megide ikike ikpe nke gọọmentị nke onye ọrụ ahụ egosipụtala nlelị maka ya.

en: On Saturday, December 7, 24 hours after the debacle at the Federal High Court, Abuja, the Department of State Services prevaricated about the real fact just to offset its damaged reputation.
ibo: Na Satọde, Disemba 7, ka awa iri abụọ garachara, ụlọ ikpe ukwu ahụ, n'Abuja, Ngalaba Na-ahụ Maka Ọrụ kwuru banyere eziokwu n'ezie iji kwụsị aha ya mebiri emebi.

en: It is no surprise to us or the general public, who are now used to the DSS' novelties of historical records of numerous lies m intended to create a false or misleading impression.
ibo: Ọ bụghị ihe ịtụnanya nye anyị ma ọ bụ ọha na eze, bụ ndị maara akụkọ ndị DSS nke nwere ọtụtụ akụkọ ụgha iji mepụta echiche ụgha ma ọ bụ nke na-eduhie eduhie.

en: The invasion of the Federal High Court on Friday by DSS operatives to perfect a rearrest of Omoyele Sowore and his co-defendant, Olawale Bakare, less than 24 hours after they were granted bail is the highest act of sacrilege against the judicial arm of government that the operative has constantly expressed contempt for.
ibo: Mwakpo nke ụlọ ọrụ ndị ọkaịkpe wakporo na Fraịdee ka onye ọrụ ya bụ Omoyele Sowore na onye na - agbachitere ya, Olawale Bakare erughị awa iri abụọ na anọ ka enyere ha ohere mgbapụta bụ ihe kacha mma na-akwado megide ikike ikpe nke gọọmentị. onye ọrụ ahụ egosipụtala nlelị maka ya.

en: After willfully violating two different court orders that granted bail to Omoyele Sowore, and until Justice Ijeoma Ojukwu's 24-hour ultimatum to the operative, it became an obvious fact that the compliance with the court order was with the ulterior motive of releasing and rearresting Sowore, just to be seen to have obeyed the pending court.
ibo: Mgbe akpachara anya mebie iwu ụlọ ikpe abụọ nyere ikike ịgbazigharị Omoyele Sowore, rue mgbe onye ọka ikpe Ijeoma Ojukwu nyere ọrụ ahụ, ọ bịara bụrụ ihe doro anya na nrube isi n'iwu ụlọịkpe ahụ bụ ebumnobi nke ịgbahapụ na iweghachite Sowore, naanị ka a hụ ka o rubere isi n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ.

en: During the court proceeding of the day under reference, defence counsel, Femi Falana (SAN), intimated the judge of the intention of the DSS to rearrest Sowore, but it was overlooked.
ibo: N'oge usoro ikpe nke ụbọchị ahụ n'okpuru ntụnye aka, onye ọka ikpe nchekwa, Femi Falana (SAN), gwara onye ọka ikpe na ebumnuche ndị DSS bụ idobe Sowore, mana elefuru anya.

en: However, as soon as Sowore was about stepping out of the courtroom, DSS operatives laid hands on him to rearrest him without a charge; hence, the pandemonium between the violent operatives of the DSS and supporters of Sowore who couldn't comprehend the justification for a rearrest barely 24 hours after his release.
ibo: Agbanyeghị, ozugbo Sowore na-achọ isi n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ pụta, ndị ọrụ DSS tụkwasara ya aka ịwakpo ya n'enweghị ebubo; N'ihi ya, ọgba aghara dị n'etiti ndị na-eme ihe ike nke DSS na ndị na-akwado Sowore bụ ndị na-enweghị ike ịghọta ihe mere eji eme ihe n'erughị awa 24 ka ahapụchara ya.

en: Eyewitness and media accounts have it that the DSS operatives stormed the courtroom violently and disrupted proceeding for which the sitting judge, Justice Ojukwu, had to scamper for safety.
ibo: Onye hụrụ ya anya na akụkọ mgbasa ozi nwere na ndị ọrụ DSS were iwe were ọsọ wee megharia usoro onye ọka ikpe nọ ebe ahụ, bụ Justice Ojukwu, gbara izu maka nchekwa.

en: In the press release of the DSS, it accused Sowore's supporters of shielding him from an 'imaginary arrest.'
ibo: Na akụkọ mgbasa ozi nke DSS, o boro ndị na-akwado Sowore ebubo na ha na-egbochi ya 'njide efu.' Mana n'eziokwu, mwakpo ahụ gosipụtara na ọ bụghị njide echere n'echiche.

en: But in reality, the rearrest already proved that it wasn't an imaginary arrest.
ibo: Ebe ọ bụ na Sowore pụtara n'ụlọ ikpe maka okwu a na DSS, ndị ọrụ agha na-arụ ọrụ n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ na Disemba 6 dị ọtụtụ karịa mgbe ọ bụla. Nke a bụ iji gosipụta na mwakpo ọzọ awakporo Sowore bụ mkpebi nke ọrụ ahụ kwudịrị tupu ọ tọhapụ ya na Disemba 5!

en: Since Sowore's appearances in court over this case with the DSS, armed operatives of the service in the court premises on December 6 were greater in number than ever.
ibo: N'okwu ndị DSS kwuru na ndị ọrụ ya anọghị n'ime ụlọ ikpe ahụ iji wee mepụta mwakpo ahụ, nyocha dị egwu na ihe nkiri ndị mgbasa ozi na ndị hụrụ ya kpughere gosiri na ụfọdụ ndị ọrụ ha na-eyighị uwe DSS nke akpọrọ aha otu na-adọkpụ Sowore na ala n'ime ogige.

en: This is to show that Sowore's rearrest was a decision reached by the service even before his release on December 5!
ibo: Otu onye n'ime ụmụ nwoke na-eje ozi n'ime ụlọ ikpe ahụ nke onye ọrụ ike Sowore nwere bụ Marshall.

en: On the claim by the DSS that its operatives were not inside the courtroom to carry out the rearrest, a critical look at the videos in circulation by the media and eyewitnesses revealed that some men of the operatives not dressed in DSS' branded uniform dragging Sowore on the ground inside the courtroom.
ibo: O yighị uwe ndị DSS mara akara.

en: One of the service men inside the courtroom to forcefully rearrest Sowore was Marshall. He was not dressed in the branded uniform of the DSS. He was in a black jacket as seen in all videos in circulation.
ibo: Ọ nọ na jaket ojii dịka a na-ahụ ya na ihe nkiri niile ana-ekesa.

en: Marshall was always the DSS operative restraining Sowore from speaking with the press during his previous appearances in court.
ibo: Marshall bụ onye ọrụ DSS na-egbochi Sowore ka ọ ghara iso ndị nta akụkọ na-ekwu okwu oge ọ gara n'ụlọ ikpe.

en: Also, it is worthy to note that Sowore while still within the premises of the court told this same Marshall that he was a disgrace.
ibo: Ọzọkwa, ọ dị mma ịmara na Sowore mgbe ọ ka nọ n'ụlọ ikpe ahụ gwara otu Marshall na ọ bụ ihe ihere.

en: With this fact alone, it is abundantly clear that after 24 hours of silence over the court debacle by the DSS, in a bid to salvage their publicly damaged reputation, they still couldn't manufacture a 'smart lie' that serves to make amends.
ibo: N'ezie eziokwu a, o doro anya nke ukwuu na mgbe awa 24 nke ịgbachi nkịtị gbasara akwụkwụ ụlọ ikpe nke ndị DSS, n'ịzọ iwepụ aha ha mebiri emebi n'ihu ọha, ha ka nwere ike ghara imepụta 'amamịghe ụgha' nke na-enyere aka ịgbanwe.

en: It is unthinkable of the DSS to accuse Sowore of addressing a group of persons at Transcorp Hilton Hotel, Abuja, on the same day of his release of a 'reassured cause' to create anarchy in the country.
ibo: Ọ bụ ihe jọgburu onwe ya na ndị DSS boro Sowore ka ọ kpọọ otu mmadụ okwu na ụlọ nkwari Transcorp Hilton, Abuja, n'otu ụbọchị a tọhapụrụ ya 'ihe masiri obi ike' iji mepụta ọgbaghara na mba ahụ.

en: This allegation is spurious, bogus, fake, and inauthentic.The DSS intends to make the public think something that is not true.
ibo: Ebubo a bụ okwu ojoo, okwu ugha, na-abụghị eziokwu. Ndị DSS bu n'obi ime ka ọha na eze chee ihe na-abụghị eziokwu.

en: In other words, the DSS is trying to establish the basis for rearresting Sowore to be that he had violated one of his bail conditions. This is laughable!
ibo: N'ikwu ya n'ụzọ ọzọ, DSS na-anwapụta ihe ndabere maka ijigide Sowore na ọ bụ na ọ dara iwu otu ịgbapụta ya. Nke a bụ ihe ọchị!

en: It is on record that when the DSS earlier insisted on validating the sureties to Sowore's bail, Justice m Ojukwu asked the counsel to the DSS if the agency was running a parallel court.
ibo: Ọ bụ na ndekọ na mgbe ndị DSS kwusiri ike na nkwado nke ịgba akwụkwọ Sowore ebubo, Justice M. Ojukwu jụrụ ndụmọdụ DSS ma ọ bụrụ na ụlọ ọrụ ahụ na-arụ ọrụ ụlọ ọrụ ọzọ yiri ya.

en: Most reasonably now, if a bail condition has been violated, it is of the same court that gave the conditions to determine that. The bail conditions were not by the DSS but by the court.
ibo: Ihe kachasị dị ugbu a, ọ bụrụ na emebila mgbapụtaa, ọ bụ otu ụlọikpe ahụ nyere ọnọdụ iji kpebie nke ahụ. Ọnọdụ mgbapụta abụghị nke ndị DSS kama ọ bụ nke ndị ụlọ ikpe.

en: By DSS' inconsistent actions, the agency has assumed both the role of the court, the law, and the judge in this matter. This is a tragedy and a travesty of justice.
ibo: Site na omume DSS, ndị ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ewerela ọrụ ụlọ ikpe, iwu na onye ọka ikpe n'okwu a. Nke a bụ ọdachi na aghụghọ nke ikpe.

en: DSS' historical records of numerous lies, human right violations, court contempt, and the recent desecration of the court all speak of one truth, which is, the operative is unabashedly unruly and does not have the genetic composition to abide by the law.
ibo: Ihe ndekọ akụkọ ihe mere eme nke DSS nke ọtụtụ ụgha, mmebi iwu ndị ruuru mmadụ, nlelị ụlọ ikpe, na mmejọ ụlọ ikpe na nsonso a, na-ekwu maka otu eziokwu, ya bụ, ndị na-arụ ọrụ na-enweghị isi na enweghị usoro mkpụrụ ndụ iji rube isi n'iwu.

en: There is no plan by any one group connected to Omoyele Sowore to organise an insurrection in the country.
ibo: Onweghị atụmatụ otu ọ bụla jikọrọ Omoyele Sowore ịhazi ọgbaghara na mba a.

en: A wise saying has it that the evil that men do live after them.
ibo: Okwu amam-ihe kwuru na ihe ọjọ nke mmadụ so ya biri.

en: DSS' unequivocal reputation for false alarms is a psychological self-defense mechanism to preempt the provocative paranoia their oppressive tendencies are stirring in Nigerians.
ibo: DSS 'aha enweghị nkatọ maka mkpu ụgha bụ usoro nchedo onwe onye iji gbochie ajọ mkpamkpa nke omume mmegbu ha na-akpali na ndị Naịjirịa.

en: The agency is gradually militarising our democracy by its undemocratic actions and terrorising assaults on dissenting
ibo: Ụlọ ọrụ ahụ na-eji nwayọọ nwayọọ na-ebuso ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya agha n'ọrụ site na omume ya na-esighi ike na mwakpo na-eyi ọha egwu.

en: We are requesting well meaning Nigerians to lend their voices to condemn the disobedience against the democratic rights and freedom of expression of our staff.
ibo: Anyi na-arịọ ndị Naịjirịa nke oma ka ha tinye olu nke ha megide nnupu isi megidere ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya anyị, ndị ọrụ anyị na nnwere onwe ikwu okwu dịka iwu anyị siri dị.

en: Also, we are demanding the unconditional release of Omoyele Sowore from illegal detention.
ibo: Ọzọkwa, anyị na-achọ ntọhapụ nke mwakpo Omoyele Sowore nke iwu na-akwadoghị njide ya.

en: Reactions Trail Genevieve's Lionheart Movie Oscar Disqualification
ibo: okwu ndị so ihe nkiri obi agụ nke Genevieve ewepụrụ na ntụli OSCAR .

en: 'Lionheart' is among the 10 African films that were submitted for Oscar consideration this year.
ibo: 'Lionheart' so n'ime ihe nkiri Africa iri nke edepụtara maka ntụli Oscar afọ a .

en: Since this news broke, there have been arguments for and against the decision by Oscar.
ibo: Kemgbe a nuru ozi a, na e nwere okwu arụmụka na okwu imegide gbasara mkpebi Oscar.

en: Today, Nigerians woke up to the news that their first-ever submission for best international feature Oscar consideration, 'Lionheart' has been disqualified by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
ibo: Taa, ndị Naịjirịa kpọtere ozi na ntinye akwụkwọ nke izizi ha kachasị mma nke Oscar, 'Lionheart' agụmakwụkwọ nke Arts na Mgbakọ Sayensi kewapụrụ ya.

en: The panel said the movie had 'too much English dialogue'.
ibo: Ndị otu ahụ kwuru na ihe nkiri ahụ nwere 'mkparịta ụka Bekee buru oke ibu . '

en: The movie which was directed by ace Nollywood actress, GenevieveNnaji, according to the Los Angeles Times ran afoul of the academy rule which states that an International feature film category must have 'a predominantly non-English dialogue track' .
ibo: Ihe nkiri omere nke Nollywood, Genevieve Nnaji duziri, dị ka akwụkwọ akụkọ Los Angeles si kwuo na ụlọakwụkwọ na-ekwu na ihe ngosipụta nke ihe nkiri mba ụwa kwesịrị ịhapụ 'usoro mkparịta ụka na-abụghị Bekee.

en: 'Lionheart' is among the 10 African films that were submitted for Oscar consideration this year.
ibo: 'Lionheart' so na ihe nkiri iri nke Africa nyere maka ntụli Oscar nke afọ a.

en: This isn't the first time the academy has disqualified a foreign film from consideration for having too much English dialogue
ibo: Nke a abụghị nke mbụ ụlọ a na ewepu ihe nkiri mba ọzọ maka bekee;

en: In recent years, the 2015 Afghan film, Utopia, and the 2007 Israeli movie, The Band's Visit, were disqualified for the same reason,' Los AngelesTimes reports.
ibo: Na nso nso a, ihe nkiri Afrịka nke Afghanistan, Utopia, na ihe nkiri Israel nke 2007, bụ nleta otu egwu, ka ewepụrụ aha ha maka otu ihe ahụ, 'ka akụkọ Los Angeles na-akọ.

en: Since this news broke, there have been arguments for and against the decision by Oscar.
ibo: Kemgbe akụkọ a pụtara ihe, e nwela arụmụka maka mkpebi Oscar imeghachị omume ya,

en: Giving her reaction, an American filmmaker, Ava Duvernay wondered whythe movie was disqualified when the official language of Nigeria was English.
ibo: Onye ihe nkiri America, Ava Duvernay nọ na-eche ihe kpatara na ewezighi ihe nkiri ahụ ebe asụsụ gọọmentị Naịjirịa bụ bekee.

en: In a tweet on her official Twitter handle she wrote: 'To the academy(Oscar), You disqualified Nigeria's first-ever submission for Best International Feature because its in English.
ibo: O dere n'akara twita : 'Iji na-ụlọ mmụta (Oscar), Ị wepuru ihe nkiri mbu nke Naịjirịa maka njirimara ha bụ bekee.

en: But English is the official language of Nigeria.
ibo: Mana asụsụ bekee bụ asụsụ ala Naịjirịa.

en: Are you barring this country from evercompeting for an Oscar in its official language?
ibo: Ị na-egbochi obodo a ka ọ ghara ịdị na-eme Oscar n'asụsụ mbụ ya?

en: 'In her response to Ava Duvernay's tweet, Genevieve Nnaji said: 'I am the director of Lionheart.
ibo: 'Na nzaghachị Ava Duvernay na akara twita, Genevieve Nnaji kwuru, sị:' Abụ m onye nhazigharị nke 'Lionheart'

en: This movie represents the way we speak as Nigerians.
ibo: Ihe nkiri a na-anọchi anya ụzọ anyị si ekwu okwu dịka ndị Naịjirịa.

en: This includes English which acts as a bridge between the500+ languages spoken in our country; thereby making us one Nigeria.
ibo: Nke a gụnyere asụsụ Bekee nke emere dị ka àkwà mmiri dị n'etiti asụsụ ruru 500 ana-asụ n'obodo anyị; nke mere anyị otu Naịjirịa.

en: 'It's no different to how French connects communities in former Frenchcolonies.
ibo: 'Ọ dịghị iche na otu French si ejikọ obodo na mba ha chịburu.

en: We did not choose who colonized us.
ibo: Anyị ahọrọghị ndị chịrị anyị.

en: As ever, this film andmany like it is proudly Nigerian.
ibo: Dị ka ọ dị ugbu a, ihe nkiri a na nke dị ka ya bụ ihe onye Naịjirịa na-anya isi.

en: 'For Nigerian actor, Deyemi, he chose to see the positive side, saying:'I can only imagine how many more views Lionheart will have on Netflix by the end of today!
ibo: Nye onye na-eme ihe nkiri Naịjirịa, Deyemi, ọ họọrọ ịhụ akụkụ dị mma, na-ekwu, sị:' Apụrụ m iche ọtụtụ echiche obi ga-enwe na Netflix na njedebe nke taa!

en: Anyhow you look at it this is a win! Staywinning.
ibo: N'ụzọ ọ bụla ịlere ya anya na nke a bụ mmeri! .

en: 'To think that some Nigerians actually complained that Lionheart had too much Igbo!
ibo: I ji na-eche na ụfọdụ ndị Naịjirịa n'ezie mere mkpesa na obi agụ nwere asụsụ Igbo nke ukwuu!

en: Only for the Oscars to think it has too much English?
ibo: Naanị ịnụ ndị Oscars ka ha kwuru na ọ nwere ọtụtụ Bekee?

en: Total BS!
ibo: Oke BS!

en: Honestly, I don't even care for the Oscars at this point!
ibo: N'ezie, adịghị m ele ndị Oscar anya ugbu a!

en: They might as well change the name back to 'Foreign language',' a Twitter user, Steven Chuks, stated.
ibo: Ha nwekwara ike gbanwee aha ahụ laghachị 'Asụsụ Ọzọ', otu onye twita, Steven Chuks kwuru.

en: Another Twitter user, Britain Danielle, said, 'Something about this doesn't seem fair.
ibo: Onye ọzọ na-eji Twitter eme ihe, Danielle kwuru, sị, 'Ihe ụfọdụ gbasara ihe a adịghị mma.

en: The film was disqualified because it's mostly in English.
ibo: Ewepụrụ ihe nkiri ahụ n'ihi na ọ kacha n'asụsụ Bekee .

en: Meanwhile, the official language of Nigeria is English.'
ibo: Ka ọ dị ugbu a, asụsụ gọọmentị Naịjirịa bụ Bekee. '

en: Recalling Tai Solarin's Prediction By Edwin Madunagu
ibo: Icheta amụma Tai Solarin Site Edwin Madunagu

en: Does it mean that nothing has changed fundamentally in Nigeria's social order or in the Leftist challenge to it, or both?
ibo: O putara na onweghị ihe gbanwegogoro n'usoro ọrụ ndị mmadụ na Naịjirịa ma ọ bụ n'ime aka ndị akaịpa na ya, ma ọ bụ ha abụọ?

en: How has Nigeria's ruling capitalist class been able to periodically renew itself, assume new organizational forms and continue its rule?
ibo: Kedụ ka ndị otu ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa siri nwee ike ịmegharị onwe ha oge ụfọdụ, wepụta ụdị nhazi ma na-aga n'ihu?

en: Put differently, why has it not been possible to overthrow Nigeria's ruling capitalist class, as a class, or dislodge it as the dominant political force?
ibo: N'akụkụ dị iche, gịnị kpatara na ọ kaghị enwe ike ịkwatu ndị isi ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa, dị ka otu, ma ọ bụ tufuo ya dịka ike ọchịchị kacha ike?

en: Nigeria's 2019 elections, particularly the recent governorship contests in Kogi and Bayelsa states, have forcefully brought back a prediction which the late Tai Solarin made about 40 years ago in the aftermath of the 1979 elections.
ibo: Ntụli aka nke 2019 nke Naịjirịa, karịsịa asọmpi gọvanọ n'oge na-adịbeghị anya na steeti Kogi na Bayelsa, ejirila ike weghachite amụma nke onye ikpe azụ Tai Solarin mara ihe dị ka afọ 40 gara aga na ntụli aka nke 1979.

en: Of course, recalling this prediction is also recalling my response to it at the time.
ibo: N'ezie, ịcheta amụma a na-echetakwa azịza m n'ebe m nọ n'oge ahụ.

en: I was then 33.
ibo: Adị m afọ 33 mgbe ahụ.

en: It is appropriate to begin any story I might wish to tell here by introducing Tai Solarin to young Nigerians who were not born when the prediction was made.
ibo: Ọ dị mma ịmalite akụkọ ọ bụla m nwere ike ịkọ ebe a site na iwebata Tai Solarin na ndị na-eto eto ndị Naịjirịa na-amụghị amụ mgbe amara amụma ahụ.

en: This set of Nigerians now constitutes the majority of the Nigerian population.
ibo: Ndi Naịjirịa ugbu a mejupụtara ọnụ ọgụgụ ndị mmadụ nọ n'Naịjirịa.

en: Tai Solarin was a prominent Nigerian male from South-Western Nigeria who was a secular humanist and educationist, but whose humanism was exceptional because it was all-round (that is, in thought as well as in action), consistent, courageous and well-informed.
ibo: Tai Solarin bụ nwa nwoke ama ama nke Naịjirịa si mpaghara ọdịda-ọwụwa anyanwụ nke Naịjirịa nke bụ onye ọrụ ụwa na agụmakwụkwọ, mana ọrụ mmadụ ya enweghị atụ n'ihi (ya bụ n'echiche na omume) nnagide ya, obi isi ike ya na oke mmụta ya.

en: Tai Solarin was not a Marxist, not a communist and not a worker by class placement.
ibo: Tai Solarin abụghị onye Marxist, ọ bụghị onye komunizim ọ bụghị onye ọrụ site na idobe otu.

en: But he was a proletarian in lifestyle.
ibo: Mana ọ bụ onye mkwado ndụ.

en: In politics he would be described as a progressive, but not a progressive in the mould of the present-day Nigeria's neofascist 'progressive'.
ibo: Na ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị a ga-akọwa ya dịka onye na - aga n'ihu, mana ọbụghị onye na - aga n'ihu ugbua ndị Naịjirịa 'na-aga n'ihu'.

en: Tai Solarin was a progressive in the original sense of being located in the Leftist ideological and political universe.
ibo: Tai Solarin bụ ihe na-agagharị n'echiche mbụ nke ịbụ onye nọ na mpaghara echiche ndị akaịkpa na ụwa ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị.

en: He was, in general, a 'social critic' and, in particular, a critical, popular and respected newspaper columnist.
ibo: Ọ bụ ya n'ozuzu ya, 'onye nkatọ mmekọrịta mmadụ na ibe ya' na ọkachasị, ọ bụ onye edemede akụkọ pụrụ iche, ama ama ma na-akwanyere ùgwù.

en: Now to the beginning of this piece.
ibo: Ugbu a ruo n'isi mmalite nke mpempe a.

en: We may recall that Nigeria's Second Republic began on October 1, 1979 after a 13-year period (1966-1979) of military rule that witnessed a civil war.
ibo: Anyị nwere ike icheta na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche nke abụọ Naịjirịa malitere na Ọktọba 1, 1979 mgbe afọ 13 (1966-1979) nke ọchịchị ndị agha nke hụrụ agha obodo .

en: In the general elections that ushered in the Republic, Shehu Shagari of the National Party of Nigeria (NPN) emerged as (Executive) President and Obafemi Awolowo of the Unity Party of Nigeria (UPN) emerged as the second strongest presidential candidate.
ibo: Na ntuli aka niile emere na ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya, Shehu Shagari nke otu mba Naịjirịa (NPN) pụtara dị ka (Ezekutiv) onye isi ala na Obafemi Awolowo nke otu njịkọ Naịjirịa (UPN) pụtara dịka onye ntuli aka nke abụọ.

en: The result was, to say the least, very contentious—as we can recall or research.
ibo: Nsonaazụ ya bụ, ịsị ntakịrị, oke esemokwu — dịka anyị nwere ike icheta ma ọ bụ mee nyocha.

en: But the issue here is neither the contentiousness of the result of the presidential contest nor the side which Tai Solarin supported.
ibo: Mana ihe dị ebe a abụghị esemokwu nke nsonaazụ onye isi ala ma ọ bụ akụkụ nke Tai Solarin kwadoro.

en: He was a member of the UPN .
ibo: Ọ bụ onye otu n'ime ndị UPN .

en: Rather, we are concerned with his prediction five weeks into the new Republic.
ibo: Kama, anyị na-echebara amụma ya izu ise ga-abanye na mba ọhụrụ.

en: On November 4, 1979, 34 days after the installation of President Shehu Shagari, the Sunday edition of the Tribune newspaper carried a column by Tai Solarin titled The Stolen Presidency.
ibo: Na Nọvemba 4, 1979, ụbọchị 34 ka e hibechara Onye isi ala Shehu Shagari, mbipụta Sọnde nke akwụkwọ akụkọ ikpe bụ otu nke Tai Solarin kpọrọ aha oche Onye isi ezuuru .

en: In it the columnist wrote: 'If this government lasts four years the four-year-old NPN will have been firmly planted as Government Party everywhere, and the UPN, the GNPP, the NPP and the PRP will have been drained to annihilation, both in membership—it is already starting—and in morale.
ibo: N'ime ya, onye edemede ahụ dere, sị: 'Ọ bụrụ na gọọmentị a ga-adị afọ anọ… NPN ga-anọ etinyere onwe ya dịka otu Ọchịchị ebe niile, na UPN, GNPP, NPP na PRP ga-ebibikwa ma ndi otu ya - o bidola - na ihe omumu.

en: The 1983 election would therefore be between the NPN and the Revolutionary Party which, having studied how the NPN came to power knows exactly what to do to supplant the NPN for the presidency.
ibo: Ntụli aka nke afọ 1983 ga-adị n'etiti NPN na otu mgbanwe, ebe ọ mụrụ banyere NPN wee bụrụ ọchịchị maara nke ọma ihe ọ ga-eme itinye onye NPN maka onye isi ala.

en: There would then be a confusion on the national raft.
ibo: A ga-enwe ọgba aghara na ụdọ mba ahụ.

en: Then commotion among the sharks.
ibo: Mgbe ahụ ọgbaghara n'etiti ndị shark.

en: And we, the common people, will have, as victims, paid the supreme sacrifice'.
ibo: Anyị onwe anyị, ndị nkịtị, ga-akwụrịrị ụgwọ dị ka ndị a na-enye ụgwọ.

en: My comment on this prediction was immediate—as was expected in those days.
ibo: Ihe m kwuru banyere amụma a bụ ihe ozugbo - dịka a tụrụ anya n'oge ahụ.

en: It appeared in an edition of the Nigerian Chronicle, a daily newspaper owned and published by the Cross River State government.
ibo: Ọ pụtara na mbipụta nke akwụkwọ akụkọ nke Naịjirịa, akwụkwọ akụkọ kwa ụbọchị nke gọọmentị Cross River dere ma bipụta ya.
