en: The comment was later revised and included in the text of a lecture I delivered at the University of Ife (now Obafemi Awolowo University) in November 1980 under the auspices of the institution's Alliance of Progressive Students (ALPS) on the occasion of the 31st anniversary of the killing of Nigerian miners at the Iva Valley Mines, Enugu, by the colonial police.
ibo: Edegharịrị nkwupụta ahụ ma tinye ya na ederede okwu nkuzi m kwuru na Mahadum Ife (Mahadum Obafemi Awolowo ugbu a) na Nọvemba 1980 n'okpuru nkwado nke ụlọ Akwụkwọ Ndị Ọzụzụ Ndị Mmụta (ALPS) n'oge emume ncheta nke 31 nke ogbugbu ndị na-egwu ala Naịjirịa na ndagwurugwu Iva Valley, Enugwu, site n'aka ndị uwe ojii .

en: And later still, in May 1981, the comment was included in a book which emanated from the lecture.
ibo: Ma mesịa, na Mee 1981, ekwupụtara nkọwa a n'akwụkwọ nke si na nkuzi ahụ .

en: The lecture as well as the book that emanated from it were titled: Human Progress and Its Enemies: The Struggle for a more humane social order in Nigeria.
ibo: Okwu nkuzi a yana akwụkwọ nke si na ya pụta bụ aha akpọrọ: oganihu mmadụ na iro Ya: Mgba maka usoro mmekọrịta mmadụ na ibe ya karị na Naịjirịa.

en: In the book, I said, 'Tai Solarin's prediction is unusual in two ways.
ibo: N'akwụkwọ ahụ, ekwuru m, 'Amụma Tai Solarin bụ ihe pụrụ iche n'ụzọ abụọ .

en: In the first place, Tai Solarin was predicting the disintegration and demise of his party, the UPN.
ibo: Na mbu, Tai Solarin na-ebu amụma banyere mwepu na mbibi nke otu ya, UPN .

en: In the second place he was predicting that it would require a Revolutionary Party to dislodge the NPN from power: a type of prediction that normally comes from a revolutionary and not a liberal.
ibo: N'ebe nke abụọ ọ na-ebu amụma na ọ ga-achọ ndị otu mgbanwe iji chụpụ NPN n'ike: ụdị amụma na-esitekarị na ngagharị iwe abụghị nke na-emesapụ aka .

en: We may ignore Tai Solarin's scenario—for the Revolutionary Party, when it emerges, will not fight according to the rules fashioned by the enemies of progress.
ibo: Anyị nwere ike ileghara ọnọdụ Tai Solarin anya - maka otu mgbanwe, mgbe ọ na-apụta, ọ gaghị agha dịka iwu nke ndị iro nke ọganiihu siri dị .

en: But we agree completely that the NPN, as a political party, is today the best organization of the Nigerian bourgeoisie and the most accurate reflection of Nigerian bourgeois interests.
ibo: Mana anyị kwenyere kpam kpam na NPN, dịka ndị otu ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, bụ taa ọgbakọ kacha mma nke ndọrọndọrọ ọchịchị Naịjirịa na ngosipụta ziri ezi gbasara ọdịmma ndị Naịjirịa .

en: So long as the bourgeois social order remains so long will the NPN (or a new monster it may give birth to) continue to be the dominant political organization of the bourgeoisie.'
ibo: Ọ bụrụhaala na usoro ọdịmma ọha mmadụ ka ga-anọ ogologo oge, NPN (ma ọ bụ anụ ọhụrụ ọ nwere ike ịmụ) ga-anọgide na-abụ nzukọ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị kachasị elu nke ndị ogaranya .

en: It follows from above that 'only a revolutionary agency, representing the true aspirations of the popular masses (the workers, the peasants, students, etc.) and fighting consistently for an entirely new social order, can ever dislodge the NPN from power.
ibo: O si n'elu pụta na 'naanị ụlọ ọrụ na-agbanwe agbanwe, na-anọchite anya ezi ọchịchọ nke ọha mmadụ a ma ama (ndị ọrụ, ndị nkịtị, ụmụ akwụkwọ, wdg) na ịlụ ọgụ maka usoro mmekọrịta ọha na eze kpamkpam, nwere ike ịchụpụ NPN n'ike .

en: To that extent—and to that extent alone—we agree with Tai Solarin.
ibo: Ruo ókè ahụ — na ruo naanị ọnụ ụzọ ahụ - anyị kwenyere Tai Solarin .

en: But we do not share his pessimism.
ibo: Ma anyị adịghị enwe echiche enweghị nchekwube .

en: A revolution cannot be conceived in a pessimistic perspective.
ibo: Enweghị ike ịtụgharị mgbanwe site n'ọnọdụ ọjọọ .

en: A revolution—to use the words of Leon Trotsky—is incompatible with pessimism and other forms of spiritual collapse.
ibo: Ntughari - iji okwu Leon Trotsky na-emegide enweghị nchekwube na ụdị mbibi ime mmụọ ndị ọzọ .

en: Tai Solarin's pessimism arose from the fact that he made a separation between the people and the Revolutionary Party—a type of separation that exists between the people and the existing political parties.
ibo: Nkwuputa okwu Tai Solarin sitere na eziokwu ahụ ọ kewara ndị mmadụ na ndị otu mgbanwe - ụdị nkewa dị n'etiti ndị mmadụ na ndị otu ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị dị ugbu a .

en: A genuine revolution can only be made by the people under the leadership of their revolutionary organization, and such a revolution demands the highest forms of optimism and moral courage.'
ibo: Naanị ndị ndu ha nwere ike ịme nghazigharị, mgbanwe dị otú ahụ chọrọ ụdị nchekwube kachasị elu na obi ike omume .

en: Looking now at this nearly 40-year old 'exchange' between Tai Solarin and myself, it strikes me that I could myself not have realized its full import.
ibo: N'ileghachi anya ugbu a ihe 'afọ agbanweta' n'etiti Tai Solarin na onwe m, ọ na-akụ m n'enweghị m ike ịghọta na mbubata ya zuru oke .

en: Tai Solarin said only a Revolutionary Party could dislodge the NPN from power.
ibo: Tai Solarin kwuru na ọ bụ naanị otu mgbanwe nwere ike ịchụpụ NPN n'ike .

en: I agreed with him but amended the proposition by replacing 'NPN' with the phrase 'NPN or a new monster it might give birth to'.
ibo: Ekwenyere m ya ma mezie echiche ahụ site n'iji 'NPN' dochie 'NPN' ma ọ bụ ogologo anụ mmiri ọ nwere ike ịmụ ' .

en: This suggests that I had a 'flash' that NPN could be succeeded by another party—or another entity—but nonetheless, a 'monster' (such as a military junta) organically emerging from NPN.
ibo: Nke a na-egosi na enwere m 'ọkụ' nke NPN nwere ike bụrụ onye ọzọ - ma ọ bụ onye ọzọ ga - anọchi - mana agbanyeghị, 'anụ mmiri' (dịka isi iyi ndị agha) na-esite na NPN .

en: But the 'flash' was not pursued.
ibo: Mana 'ịcha ọkụ' ahụ achughị.

en: It is clear that the class perspective was missing from Tai Solarin's analysis and prediction.
ibo: O doro anya na echiche otu ahụ nyocha na ịkọ amụma Tai Solarin .

en: This is explicable, given that he was not a Marxist.
ibo: Nke a bụ ihe kwere omume, ebe ọ bụ na ọ bụghị ndị otu Marx .

en: But my response was also not sufficiently ideological.
ibo: Ma azịza m ezughị echiche m zuru ezu .

en: Let me explain.
ibo: Ka m kọwaa .

en: In political-ideological contestation, even in our own context, the terms 'bourgeois' and 'capitalist' are not simply interchangeable.
ibo: Na ndoro-ndoro echiche nke ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị, ọbụlagodi n'ọnọdụ nke anyị, okwu 'ndị ọgaranya' na 'onye isi ike' abụghị ndị agbanwere .

en: The absence of 'capitalist' in my 'disquisition' qualifies it as petty-bourgeois, even if revolutionary.
ibo: Enweghị 'ikeketeorie' na 'ọkwa m' mere ka ọ pụta ìhè dịka obere-ọgaranya, ọbụlagodi ma ọ bụrụ na mgbape agba .

en: If I had adopted a more appropriate ideological posture I would have stated explicitly that what I was alluding to was the removal of the capitalist class, as a class, and not just its political organisations like the NPN.
ibo: ọbụrụ na mụ tinye echiche ziri ezi karie, m ga ekwupụta n'ụzọ na ihe m na-atụgharị bụ iwepu ndị akwụkwọ ikekarị ya dịka akwụkwọ, ọbụghị ndị otu ndọrọ-ndọrọ ọchịchị ya dịka ndị NPN.

en: Having said this, the questions now are: Why is it that for almost 40 years, I have periodically—after every major election or change of government—felt the way I felt following the 1979 general elections and Tai Solarin's prediction?
ibo: Mgbe ikwuru nke a, ajụjụ dị ugbu a bụ: Gini mere na ọ fọrọ obere ka ọ bụrụ afọ iri anọ, na-enwe oge - mgbe ọ bụla ntuli aka ma ọ bụ mgbanwe ọ bụla nke gọọmentị - nwere mmetụta dị m ka m soro ntụli aka ndị isi na 1979 na amụma Tai Solarin ?

en: Why is it that despite the Nigerian Left's insistence, at least since 1979, on the inevitability and irreducibility of a Revolutionary Party, the party has not emerged?
ibo: Gini mere na agbanyeghị na mkparịta ụka nke ndị akaịpa Naịjirịa, ọ dịkarịa ala kemgbe 1979, na-aga-agharịrị na enweghị mgbagha nke otu Ree, otu ahụ apụtabeghị ?

en: Why should we find ourselves repeating the same theses and propositions after every bloody and farcical display called 'election'?
ibo: Kedu ihe kpatara anyị ga - eji hụ na anyị na - emegharị otu echiche na atụmatụ a mgbe ngosipụta ọbara niile na nke ọrụ ugbo na - akpọ 'ntụli aka'?

en: Does it mean that nothing has changed fundamentally in Nigeria's social order or in the Leftist challenge to it, or both?
ibo: O putara na onweghi ihe gbanwegogoro n'usoro ọrụ ndị mmadụ na Naịjirịa ma ọ bụ n'ime aka ndị akaịpa na ya, ma ọ bụ ha abụọ ?

en: How has Nigeria's ruling capitalist class been able to periodically renew itself, assume new organizational forms and continue its rule?
ibo: Kedụ ka ndị otu ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa siri nwee ike ịhazi onwe ha oge ụfọdụ, wee were usoro nhazi ọhụụ wee gaa n'ihu na-achị ya ?

en: Put differently, why has it not been possible to overthrow Nigeria's ruling capitalist class, as a class, or dislodge it as the dominant political force?
ibo: N'akụkụ dị iche, gịnị kpatara na ọ kaghị enwe ike ịkwatu ndị isi ọchịchị onye isi ala Naịjirịa, dị ka otu, ma ọ bụ tufuo ya dịka ike ọchịchị kacha ike?

en: Madunagu, mathematician and journalist, writes from Calabar, Cross River State.
ibo: Madunagu, onye na-ahụ maka mgbakọ na mwepụ na odeakụkọ, dere si Calabar, Cross River Steeti.

en: Reflections On Cold War And Africa's Human Progress By Phumlani Majozi
ibo: Ntughari banyere agha Nzuzo na Ọganihu ndị Afrika Mmadụ Site na Phumlani Majozi

en: In contrast to 30 years ago, the world is a better place in consideration of almost all the metrics of human development including economic growth, healthcare, access to education, and human right.
ibo: N'adịghị ka afọ iri atọ gara aga, ụwa bụ ebe kachasị mma n'ịtụle ihe omimi niile nke mmepe mmadụ gụnyere mmepe akụ na ụba, ahụike, ịnweta agụmakwụkwọ, na ikike mmadụ .

en: This rate of progress is unprecedented in human history.
ibo: Mmụba a a na-enwe n'ihu bụ ihe a na-ahụtụbeghị mbụ n'akụkọ mmadụ .

en: My colleague at African Liberty, Alexander Hammond, has done incredible work on global human progress for the Cato Institute.
ibo: Onye ọrụ ibe m na ntọghapụ ndị Afrika, Alexander Hammond, arụwo ọrụ dị egwu na ọganihu mmadụ na ụwa maka ụlọ akwụkwọ Cato.

en: Unsurprisingly, it's only after the Cold War that we have seen extraordinary advancements in technology and declines in global poverty rates.
ibo: N'agha, ọ bụ naanị mgbe Agha Nzuzo gasịrị ka anyị hụworo ọganihu pụrụ iche na teknọlọjị wee jupụta na ọnụego ịda ogbenye zuru ụwa ọnụ .

en: But before the fall of the Berlin Wall, the world was divided.
ibo: Mana tupu ọdịda nke mgbidi Berlin, ụwa kewara .

en: While Russia led the Soviet Union on a mission to turn the world into a communist paradise, the United States (US) invested huge resources to stall the Soviet Union's communist ambitions.
ibo: Ezie na Russia duuru otu Soviet na ụwa ime ka ụwa ghọọ paradaịs, United States (US) tinyere ego buru ibu iji kwụsị ebumnuche ndị otu Soviet .

en: The two countries, Russia and the United States, had distinct philosophical worldviews; communism and capitalism.
ibo: Mba abụọ a, Russia na United States, nwere echiche nkà ihe ọmụma ụwa dị iche; komunizim na ikeketeorie .

en: Because of their differences, they both exploited many resources to advance their ideologies to every corner of the globe.
ibo: N'ihi ọdịiche ha, ha abụọ jiri ọtụtụ akụ rụọ ọrụ iji bulie echiche ha n'akụkụ niile nke ụwa.

en: The clash of these ideologies has resulted in incessant global instability, which negatively affects almost all regions of the world.
ibo: Esemokwu nke echiche ndị a akpatawo ọgba aghara zuru ụwa ọnụ, nke na-emetụta ihe fọrọ nke nta ka ọ bụrụ mpaghara niile nke ụwa .

en: Multilateral institutions like the United Nations became an ideological battlefield for the two powers.
ibo: Otutu ụlọ ọrụ dịka out jikọrọ mba ụwa United buru agha ebe ndị echiche ha nọ buru agha.

en: In that tumultuous period in human history, none of us benefited; in fact, things became worse for much of the developing world with political dysfunction fuelled, in part, by the Cold War.
ibo: N'oge ọgba aghara ahụ n'akụkọ ihe mere eme nke mmadụ, ọ dịghị onye ọ bụla n'ime anyị ritere uru; n'ezie, ihe kara njọ maka ọtụtụ mba na-emepe emepe, ebe ọnụọgụ ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ka ọkụ, akụkụ ya ụfọdụ, site na Agha Nzuzo .

en: Today, sadly, people tend to underestimate the harm that was done by this global ideological standoff that lasted decades.
ibo: Taa, ọ dị mwute ikwu na ndị mmadụ na-echefukarị nsogbu nke esemokwu echiche ụwa niile nke were ọtụtụ afọ ime .

en: Could it be due to short memories?
ibo: O nwere ike ibute obere ncheta?

en: Well, the African continent was one of the Cold War battlegrounds.
ibo: N'ezie, Afrika bụ otu n'ime ala ndi agha .

en: My homeland, South Africa, was one of the victims of the Cold War.
ibo: Ala nna m, ọdịda nke Afrika, bụ otu n'ime ndị ihe metụtara Agha Nzuzo .

en: One of the reasons why it took us longer to end apartheid was because global powers saw our struggle against apartheid in the Cold War lens; Americans viewed Nelson Mandela as a communist and they believed his outlawed political movement, the African National Congress, was funded by Moscow.
ibo: Otu n'ime ihe mere o jiri were anyị ogologo oge ịkwụsị ịkpa ókè agbụrụ bụ n'ihi na ike ụwa niile hụrụ mgba anyị na-alụ megide ịkpa ókè agbụrụ na agha oyi; Ndị Amerika lere Nelson Mandela dị ka onye ọchịchị Kọmunist, ha kwenyere na ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ya, ndị kongres Afrika, nke Moscow kwadoro.

en: The US and Britain were conflicted about the struggle against apartheid in South Africa, hence, when we talk about the history of South Africa's black struggle against apartheid, we should not isolate it from the dynamics of the Cold War.
ibo: US na Britain gbara mgba banyere ọgụ megide ịkpa ókè agbụrụ na South Africa, n'ihi ya, mgbe anyị na-ekwu banyere akụkọ banyere ọgụ ojii South Africa megide ịkpa ókè agbụrụ, anyị ekwesịghị ikewapụ ya na Agha Nzuzo.

en: The Cold War raged on for years in Zaire — now the Democratic Republic of Congo — as the country endured crisis after crisis.
ibo: agha oyi ahụ bidoro ruo ọtụtụ afọ na Zaire - ugbu a ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya na Congo - ka mba ahụ diri mgbe nsogbu gasịrị .

en: The political turmoil that culminated in Patrice Lumumba's brutal death in 1961, usually called the Congo Crisis, was in part, fuelled by the power struggle between Russia and the US.
ibo: Ọgba aghara ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị ahụ bilitere na ọnwụ obi ọjọọ Patrice Lumumba na 1961, nke a na-akpọkarị Kọnị Kongo, bụ akụkụ nke mgbagha ike dị n'etiti Russia na US kpalitere .

en: The corrupt Mobuto Sese Seko who took power in 1965 and ran Zaire to the ground, was supported by the United States for most of his tyrannical rule because he was an ally against the Soviet Union.
ibo: Onye nrụrụ aka bụ Mobuto Sese Seko onye weghaara ọchịchị na 1965 wee gbaa Zaire n'ala, ndị United States kwadoro ya maka ọtụtụ ọchịchị aka ike ya n'ihi na ọ bụ onye jikọrọ otu Soviet.

en: The above Cold War cases on South Africa and the DRC, and on many other fronts in Africa, caused enormous political and socioeconomic damage to the continent.
ibo: Ikpe ndị a dị n'etiti South Africa na DRC, na ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ na Africa, kpatara mbibi ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na mmekọrịta akụ na ụba na kọntinent ahụ.

en: The end of the Cold War put the world in a new, positive direction.
ibo: Ọgwụgwụ nke Agha Nzuzo butere ụwa ụzọ ọhụrụ, nke ziri ezi .

en: A more cooperative world led by the US.
ibo: Morewa na-arụkọ ọrụ ọnụ nke US na-eduzi .

en: The results of the formation of this new world were astonishingly a boon for human progress.
ibo: Nsonaazụ nguzobe nke ụwa ọhụrụ a bụ ihe ịtụnanya maka ọganihu mmadụ.

en: Speedy advancements in technology and globalization have cut global poverty to less than ten percent.
ibo: Ọganihu ndị dị na teknọlọjị na ijikọ ụwa ọnụ emewo ka ịda ogbenye zuru ụwa ọnụ belata pasent iri .

en: Today, most women have the opportunity to go to school, and child mortality has reduced by more than half.
ibo: Taa, ọtụtụ ụmụ nwanyị nwere ohere ịga ụlọ akwụkwọ, ọnwụ nke ụmụaka ebelataala ihe karịrị ọkara .

en: Global healthcare has generally improved.
ibo: Ahụike ụwa niile adịla mma .

en: Equally, experts seem to agree that we now live in the most peaceful times in modern human history.
ibo: N'otu aka ahụ, ndị ọkachamara na-ekwenye na anyị bi ugbu a n'oge udo kachasị mma n'akụkọ ihe mere eme nke mmadụ .

en: But it is Africa that still lags behind on fundamental measures of human development in the post-Cold War era.
ibo: Mana ọ bụ Afrika ka na-akwado ụzọ dị iche iche nke mmepe mmekọrịta mmadụ na Afọ mgbe Agha Ọgbọ nzuzo gasịrị.

en: African countries have failed abysmally to liberalise their economies; they still rank at the bottom of the Heritage's Index of Economic Freedom.
ibo: Mba Afrịka emeghị nke ọma ịhapụ akụ na ụba ha; ha ka nokwa na nkenke akara ngosiputa ihe Nketa nke Onwe ha .

en: Civil conflicts, dictatorships, and corruption have continued unabated.
ibo: Esemokwu obodo, ọchịchị aka ike, na nrụrụ aka ka na-ebelata .

en: Although global poverty rates may have declined since the early 1990s, Africa's rates remain incredibly high compared to other regions of the world.
ibo: Ọ bụ ezie na ọnụego ịda ogbenye ụwa nwere ike gbadata kemgbe mmalite 1990, ọnụego Afrika na-anọgide n'ụzọ dị elu ma e jiri ya tụnyere mpaghara ụwa ndị ọzọ.

en: Having gone through one of its rough periods in history, Africa needs a pro-market revolution.
ibo: N'ịgafe n'otu n'ime oge siri ike ya na akụkọ ntolite, Afrika chọrọ mgbanwe nghazi ahịa .

en: The revolution needs people that are willing to put their countries first, not their personal interests.
ibo: Ntughari a chọrọ ndị mmadụ ibute mba ha ụzọ, ọbụghị nke onwe ha .

en: Ethiopian Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed, recipient of the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize, is one of the people we must look up to in moving Africa forward.
ibo: Onye isi ala Etiopia, Abiy Ahmed, onye natara onyinye nke udo nke 2019, bụ otu ndị anyị ga-elerukwu anya n'ịkwaga Afrika n'ihu .

en: The Cold War is now history.
ibo: Agha Nzuzo bụ akụkọ ihe mere eme ugbu a .

en: And history is history; there's not much we can do to change it.
ibo: Ọ bụkwa akụkọ ihe mere eme; O nweghi ọtụtụ ihe anyị nwere ike ime iji gbanwee ya .

en: All we can do is to learn from it and use it as a guide to a better future.
ibo: Naanị ihe anyị ga - eme bụ ịmụta ihe na ya ma jiri ya na-eduzi ọdịnihu ka mma.

en: Phumlani M.
ibo: Phumlani M .

en: Majozi is a politics and international affairs analyst, and a senior fellow at AfricanLiberty.org.
ibo: Majozi bụ onye nyocha ndọrọ ndọrọ ọchịchị na onye na-ahụ maka ihe gbasara mba ụwa, yana onye otu okenye na ntoghapu Afrika.org .

en: You can follow him on Twitter: @PhumlaniMMajozi
ibo: ịnwere ike iso ya na akara Twita: @PhumlaniMMajozi

en: REPORTER'S DIARY: 'Who Did You Come To See?
ibo: Akwụkwọ ukwu: 'onye ka ịbịara ịhụ?'

en: ' — A Visit To The 'Racist' Shi Shi Chinese Restaurant In Lagos
ibo: - Nleta 'ndị na-akpa ókè' ebe ana ere ihe oriri ndị China Shi Shi dị na Legos

en: On arriving Shi Shi, tucked away in a residential area in Ikeja, we approached the gate.
ibo: Mgbe anyị bịarutere Shi Shi, gbachie ebe obibi na Ikeja, anyị rutere n'ọnụ ụzọ ámá ahụ .

en: 'Good afternoon,' we called out to the grumpy and irritated-looking security guard.
ibo: 'N'ehihie ọma,' anyị kpọkuru ndị nche na-ama jijiji ma na-ewe iwe .

en: 'Who did you come to see ? he queried.
ibo: 'Onye ka ị bịara ịhụ?' ọ jụrụ .

en: Taken aback by the question, the SaharaReporters correspondent asked: 'Is this not a restaurant?'
ibo: N'ajụjụ a, onye nta akụkọ SaharaReporters jụrụ, sị: 'Ihe a abụghị ụlọ oriri?'

en: The security guard looked as if he was contemplating a response, but seemed to think twice about it and stepped back.
ibo: Onye nche ahụ dị ka ọ na-eche echiche banyere nzaghachi, mana ọ dị ka ọ na-eche ugboro abụọ banyere ya wee laa.

en: What better place to have lunch than a restaurant accused of racism?
ibo: Kedu ebe ka mma iri nri ehihie karịa ụlọ oriri eboro ebubo ịkpa ókè agbụrụ?

en: SaharaReporters visited Shi Shi Chinese restaurant on Thursday due to multiple allegations of racism towards Nigerian visitors to the restaurant, located at 21B, Emina Crescent, off Toyin Street, Ikeja, Lagos.
ibo: Ndi ntaakụkọ Sahara gara ụlọ oriri ndị China Shiụ Shiụ na Tọzde n'ihi ọtụtụ ebubo nke ịkpa ókè agbụrụ megide ndị ọbịa Naịjirịa na ụlọ oriri ahụ, nke dị na 21B, Emina Crescent, kwụsịrị Toyin Street, Ikeja, Legos

en: Our Experience
ibo: Ahụmahụ anyị

en: On arriving Shi Shi, tucked away in a residential area in Ikeja, we approached the gate.
ibo: Mgbe anyị bịarutere Shi Shi, gbachie ebe obibi na Ikeja, anyị rutere n'ọnụ ụzọ ámá ahụ.

en: Good afternoon, we called out to the grumpy and irritated-looking security guard.
ibo: N'ehihie ọma, anyị na-akpọ ndị nche na -atakasị ahụ na-ewe iwe.

en: Who did you come to see? he queried.
ibo: Onye ka ị bịara ịhụ ? ọ jụrụ .

en: Taken aback by the question, the SaharaReporters correspondent asked: 'Is this not a restaurant?'
ibo: N'ajụjụ a, onye ntaakụkọ Sahara jụrụ, sị: 'Ihe ọbụghị ụlọ oriri?'

en: The security guard looked as if he was contemplating a response, but seemed to think twice about it and stepped back.
ibo: Onye nche ahụ dị ka ọ na-eche echiche banyere nzaghachị, mana ọ dị ka ọ na-eche ugboro abụọ banyere ya wee laa azụ.

en: The team proceeded (we came disguised as a company of people who had come to hang out).
ibo: Ndị otu ahụ malitere (anyị nwoghachitere dịka ndị mmadụ bịara ibubata ihe).

en: The entrance smelt of something funny, but the source of the smell was not readily visible.
ibo: Ọnụ ụzọ mere ihe na-atọ ọchị, mana a naghị ahụ ihe mmalite nke isi ahụ ngwa ngwa .

en: There was a show glass displaying what looked like bags made of real leather.
ibo: E nwere otu ihe nkiri na-egosi ihe yiri akpa ezigbo akpụkpọ anụ .

en: We made our way into the dimly-lit restaurant.
ibo: Anyị bara n'ụlọ oriri na-adịghị mma .

en: Inside, we approached the front desk, which had a stern-looking female Chinese national at the register (probably trying to reconcile the books).
ibo: N'ime, anyị bịarutere na tebụl ihu, nke nwere ụmụ nwanyị China na-ele anya n'azụ na ndebanye aha (ikekwe na-achọ idozi akwụkwọ ndị ahụ) .

en: She barely looked up, save for the Nigerian attendants, waiters who looked completely bewildered and almost shocked that we were standing there.
ibo: O weliteghị anya elu, ewezuga ndị Naịjirịa na - eje ozi, ndị na - eche ndị Naịjirịa gosiri itunanya ma tụọ ụjọ na anyị guzo ebe ahụ.

en: In the sitting area, two Asian men were seated, looking on at us.
ibo: N'ebe ndị mmadụ nọdụrụ ala, ụmụ nwoke abụọ si Eshia nọ ọdụ, na-ele anyị anya .

en: We were ushered to a seat, five of us on a round table overlooking a transparent glass and an outdoor sitting area.
ibo: A kpọgara anyị n'oche, anyị ise na tebụl okirikiri na-eleghara iko na-ahụ ụzọ na ebe a na-anọdụ ala n'èzí .

en: As the menu arrived, so did about three waiters, circling for no reason, with one making as if she wanted to serve tea, all the while peeking into our phones.
ibo: Ka nri ahụ bịarutere, ihe dịka mmadụ atọ na - echere anyị, na - agbagharị n'enweghị ihe kpatara ya, otu na - eme ka a ga - asị na ọ chọrọ inye tii, oge niile na - eleba anya na ekwentị anyị.

en: The Wait
ibo: Nche ahụ

en: As we awaited our moderately-priced fried rice and spaghetti, we made small talk, sipping the tea.
ibo: Ka anyị na-eche osikapa anyị na eghe eghe, anyi kwuru obere okwu, na-añụ tii .

en: By now, apart from the waiters who looked aloof and were now stationed at strategic points in the restaurant, the stern-looking Chinese lady behind the counter was now sitting close by in the restaurant.
ibo: Ka ọ dị ugbu a, ewezuga ndị na-eche nche na-ele anya ma nọrọ n'akụkụ ebe a na-echekwa oriri n'ụlọ oriri ahụ, nwanyị China ahụ na-ele anya n'azụ ebe ọ nọ ọdụ n'akụkụ nri.

en: She beckoned to another lady (Chinese) and spoke something to her in their language, while motioning at us.
ibo: Ọ bekuru nwanyị ọzọ (onye China) wee gwa ya okwu n'asụsụ ha, mgbe anyị na-emegharị anyị .

en: The new lady in the most inconspicuous manner (even for an amateur) started taking photos of us and recording.
ibo: Nwaanyị ọhụụ na - enweghị atụ (ọbụlagodi onye na-amụ amụ) bidoro n'ese anyị foto na ndekọ .

en: I caught her glance and she tried to look away while concealing her phone.
ibo: Ahụrụ m ya ile ma ọ nwara ilepụ anya ka ọ na-ezo ekwentị ya .

en: Sigh.
ibo: Maa usu.

en: We continued to have conversations and our food began to arrive, the Chinese fried rice first.
ibo: Anyị gara n'ihu na-enwe mkparịta ụka ka ebutere nri, osikapa e ghere eghe nke China bịara na mbụ.

en: In a bid to what I perceive as remedying our awkward 'glance lock', 'Camera lady' approached our table and offered to teach us how to use chopsticks.
ibo: N'ịgbaso ihe m chọpụtara dị ka idozi 'mkpọchi nlegharị anya' anyị, 'Nwanyị igwe foto' bịakwutere tebụl anyị ma kwee nkwa ịkụziri anyị otu esi eji osisi eje eri nri.

en: Please note: while I was preoccupied with documenting our experience with a secret recorder, the team noticed that the two Asian men who were seated and had made their orders 'looked disgusted, got up and made their way into one of the many rooms' in the restaurant.
ibo: Biko detuo: mgbe m na-echekwa banyere ihe ndekọ banyere ahụmịhe anyị na onye na-edekọ ihe nzuzo, ndị otu ahụ chọpụtara na ụmụ nwoke abụọ Eshia nọ ọdụ ma mee ihu ha 'na-asọ oyi, bilitere ma banye n'otu n'ime ọtụtụ ụlọ' n'ụlọ oriri

en: The Show Must Go On
ibo: Ihe nkiri a ga-agariri n'ihu

en: And so it began, the overly choreographed friendliness, niceness, half-smiles and forced response to questions.
ibo: Ya mere, ọ malitere, oke ọrụ ọbụbụenyi a na-eme, ka ọdịmma, ịmụmụ ọnụ ọchị na ịmanye azịza ajụjụ .

en: Ya ya (camera lady) was now tutoring us on how to use the chopsticks.
ibo: eh eh (nwanyị igwe foto) na - akụzịrị anyị ugbua etu esi eji osisi nri .

en: A member of the team quickly requested a selfie and with concealed reluctance, she proceeded and everyone was obliged, including me.
ibo: Otu onye so n'òtù ahụ rịọrọ maka ise foto ngwa ngwa wee zilaga ya, ọ gara n'ihu, iwu ji onye ọ bụla, tinyere mụ onwe m.

en: I wondered if they took selfies with all their guests or if it was a curated PR move?
ibo: Anọ m na-eche ma ha na ndị ọbịa ha niile ọ na-esekọ foto ka ọ bụ ọ bụrụ na ọ bụ ihe nlegharị anya nke PR ?

en: Soon after, we had to leave and requested takeaway packs for what was left off our spaghetti and fried rice (God forbid it wastes).
ibo: N'oge na-adịghị anya ka nke ahụ gasịrị, anyị ga-apụ ma rịọ maka ngwugwu maka ihe fọdụ spaghetti anyị na osikapa e ghere eghe (Chineke ajụ ka ha laa n'iyi) .

en: As we were about to leave, a woman clad in black (Chinese) appeared from one of the many doors.
ibo: Ka anyị na-achọ ịpụ, otu nwanyị nwanyị yi akwa ojii (onye Cjina) pụtara site n'otu n'ime ọtụtụ ụzọ.

en: She walked up to us and said 'hello' and stayed there.
ibo: Ọ rutere anyị nso ma sị 'ndewo' ma nọrọ ebe ahụ .

en: A member of the team asked for her name and she said Si Si and introduced herself as the manager of the place.
ibo: Otu onye so n'òtù egwuregwu ahụ rịọrọ maka aha ya ma ọ sị Si Si ma gosipụta onwe ya dị ka onye na-elekọta ebe ahụ .

en: One member of the team queried if 'everyone is welcome here?
ibo: Otu onye otu ha jụrụ ajụjụ ma 'a na-anabata mmadu niile ebe a?' nke o kwuru, sị 'ee'.

en: ' to which she simply said 'yes'.
ibo: Ọ gara soro anyị pụọ n'ọnụ ụzọ (ọzọ, kedu ntọala onye ọrụ ya hụrụ ndị ahịa ruo n'ọnụ ụzọ ahụ?) .

en: She then proceeded to accompanying us out the front door (again, what establishment has its manager see customers to the door?
ibo: Ka anyị na-apụ n'ụlọ ahụ, ahụrụ m onye nche ọ dịka ọ bụ onye Naịjirịa n'anya ya dị ka ụjọ ọna-atụ ya .

en: As we exited the building, I noticed the security guard (seemed like a Nigerian from his looks) looked jittery.
ibo: Apụghị m ịhapụ ya, n'ihi ya, m laghachịrị wee see foto n'ihu ụlọ ahụ .

en: I couldn't let it go, so I went back to take a photo in front of the building.
ibo: Kedu otu ọzọ anyị ga-esi gosi na anyị bịara iri spaghetti ịkpa oke?

en: How else would we prove we came to eat racist spaghetti?
ibo: Ọ bụrụ na onye nlekọta ahụ si na windo nkụwa ahụ na-ele anyị m kọwara na mbụ; ọ tụghị anya na anyị ga-alaghachi na mberede maka foto.

en: It turned out the manager was watching from the glass window I described earlier; she hadn't anticipated our abrupt return for a photo.
ibo: Ihe ndị ọzọ na-enyo enyo bụ onye na-eche nche, bụ onye tụrụ alo ka m jiri mgbidi nwere ụfọdụ ifuru see foto ahụ ka m ghara iguzo n'akụkụ ọnụ ụzọ nke nwere aha ntọala ahụ akpụrụ na ya.

en: More suspicious was the security guard, who suggested I use a wall with some flower pots for the photo as opposed to standing by the entrance which had the name of the establishment carved into it.
ibo: Na njedebe

en: From our findings, interaction with staff and management, we couln't help thinking that Shi Shi resturant is indeed racist, hence the security guard's inquiry about who we were looking for in a place listed as a public restaurant even on Google.
ibo: Site na nchoputa anyi, nmekorita nlekọta na ndị ọrụ, enweghị ike iche ihe ọzọ na-abụghị na ụlọ oriri Shi Shi bụ ihe agbụrụ, ya mere ajụjụ ndị nche banyere onye anyị choro bịa na ebe edepụtara dika ụlọ nri ọnọdụ ọbụla na Google .

en: There was also the issue of the staff recording a video of us, the policing while in the restaurant and the manager accompanying us out.
ibo: Enwekwara esemokwu nke ndị ọrụ na-esekọ ihe nkiri anyị, ọrụ uwe ojii mgbe anyị na-eri nri na onye njikwa anyị na-eso anyị pụọ .

en: Would they have done all that if we were Chinese?
ibo: Ha gaara eme ihe niile ma ọ bụrụ na anyị bụ ndị China?

en: In the restaurant's bid to gloss this over, it ended us awarding us an exaggerated reception.
ibo: N'agba nke ụlọ oriri ahụ iji mee ka e kpuchie omume ha, ha nyere anyị nnukwu nnabata .

en: Reps Order Repair Of Terminal Receiving Vehicles At Apapa Port
ibo: Nde nnọchị anya nyere iwu ndozi nke ebe a na-anata ụgbọ ala na ọdụ Apapa

en: The House instructed the Nigerian Ports Authority to immediately repair the quay wall of the facility and carry out a much needed infrastructural upgrade at the Tin Can port as well.
ibo: Ụlọ ahụ gwara ndị ọrụ ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri na Naịjirịa ka ha rụzie mgbidi mbibi nke ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ngwa ngwa ma rụọ nkwalite ihe owuwu dị ukwuu na ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri.

en: Daily Trust
ibo: Daily Trust

en: The House of Representatives has ordered the repair of the terminal at Apapa port complex in Lagos responsible for receiving vehicles legally imported into the country.
ibo: Ndị ụlọ omebe iwu nyere iwu ka arụzie ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri n'ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri Apapa dị na Legos maka ịnata ụgbọ ala ebubatara n'ụzọ iwu.

en: The House instructed the Nigerian Ports Authority to immediately repair the quay wall of the facility and carry out a much needed infrastructural upgrade at the Tin Can port as well.
ibo: ụlọ ahụ gwara ndị ọrụ ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri na Naịjirịa ka ha rụzie mgbidi mbibi nke ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ngwa ngwa ma rụọ nkwalite ihe owuwu dị ukwuu na ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri.

en: Sponsor of the bill, Benjamin Bem, said the poor state of the facility was costing the country loses of N600bn annually.
ibo: Onye na-akwado ụgwọ ahụ, Benjamin Bem kwuru na steeti dara ogbenye n'ihi na ụlọ ọrụ ahụ na-efu mba ijeri naịra 600 kwa afọ.

en: Bem said, 'The House is worried that the collapse of the quay wall (retaining wall) and the apron area of the terminal, which has the length of 438 meters, could lead to closure of the only terminal that receives vehicle cargos from across the world into Nigeria being closed and loss of huge revenue accruable to government and loss of jobs to many Nigerians.'
ibo: Bem kwuru, 'ụlọ ahụ na-echegbu onwe ya na ndakpọ nke mgbidi mbibi (na-ejigide mgbidi) yana mpaghara nke ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri, nke nwere ogologo mita 438, nwere ike iduga mmechi nke naanị otu ọdụ ụgbọ elu nke na-ewebata nnukwu ụgbọ ala site na mpaghara mba ụwa n'ime Naịjirịa na-emechi ga ebutere gọọmentị ihe efu nakwa enweghị ọrụ ndị Naịjirịa '

en: While noting that the actual operation of the terminals have been privatised, Bem observed that it remains the duty of the ports authority to build and upgrade the infrastructure.
ibo: Ka amatara na enyefere ọrụ nke ndị ọrụ ụgbọ mmiri ahụ n'aka ndị nkiti, Bem chọpụtara na ọ ka bụ ọrụ ndị ikike ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri iji wuo ma kwalite akụrụngwa ndị ahụ.

en: REVEALED: NFF 2nd VP Masterminded Backdoor Inclusion Of DSS DG's Son Into Nigeria's U-17 Squad To Stop Corruption Case Against Him
ibo: Achọpụtala: NFF osote onye isi nke abụọ turu alo azụ ụlọ iji tinye Nwa DSS DG banye out U-17 nke Naịjirịa iji kwụsị ikpe nrụrụ aka megide ya.

en: Sources have revealed how Second Vice President of the Nigeria Football Federation, Shehu Dikko, masterminded how Bichi's son was smuggled into the final team list submitted by coach Manu Garba to FIFA despite his name not being on the 50 players provisional list.
ibo: Isi mmalite ekpughere otu onye na-esote onye isi oche nke NFF nke Naịjirịa, Shehu Dikko, lebara anya n'ụzọ nwa nwanne Bichi si tinye n'ime ndepụta otu ikpeazụ nke onye nchịkwa Manu Garba nyefere FIFA na-agbanyeghị aha ya na-anọghị na ndepụta ndị egwuregwu 50.

en: As the inclusion of Abba Bichi, son of the Director-General of the Department of State Services, in Nigeria's squad for the Golden Eaglets U-17 team in the ongoing FIFA U-17 World Cup continues to generate buzz, more details have emerged how the inclusion of Bichi's son was facilitated.
ibo: Dika ntinye Abba Bichi, nwa onye isi nke Ngalaba Na-ahụ Maka Ndị Ọrụ, na ndị otu Naịjirịa maka ndị otu egwuregwu Golden Eaglets U-17 na FIFA U-17 na-aga n'ihu na -eweta nsogbu, nkọwa ndị ọzọ apụtawo banyere ntinye nke nwa nwoke Bichi.

en: Sources have revealed how Second Vice President of the Nigeria Football Federation, Shehu Dikko, masterminded how Bichi's son was smuggled into the final team list submitted by coach Manu Garba to FIFA despite his name not being on the 50 players provisional list.
ibo: Isi mmalite ekpughere otu onye na-esote onye isi oche nke NFF nke Naịjirịa, Shehu Dikko, lebara anya n'ụzọ nwa nwanne Bichi si sonye n'ime ndepụta otu ikpeazụ nke onye nchịkwa Manu Garba nyefere FIFA na-agbanyeghị na aha ya anọghị na ndepụta ndị egwuregwu 50.

en: SaharaReporters had published how top NFF officials coerced Garba into selecting Bichi and even threatened him if he does not give-in to the request.
ibo: Ndị ntọakụkọ Sahara bipụtala etu ndị isi NFF siri rụgide Garba ịhọrọ Bichi ma yie ya egwu ma ọ bụrụ na o nyeghị ya.

en: It was revealed that Garba had expressed doubt in the ability of the young lad to break into the team.
ibo: E kpughere na Garba kwupụtara obi abụọ banyere ikike nwata nwoke nwere ịbanye n'òtù ahụ.

en: How NFF Smuggled DSS Director General's Son, Abba Bichi, Into U-17 World Cup Team
ibo: Otu NFF si dufuo Onye isi DSS, Abba Bichi, n'ime ndi egwuregwu ịkọ mba ụwa U-17

en: Also, to accommodate Bichi's son into the team, Garba had to drop one of the regulars in his team.
ibo: Ọzọkwa, iji mee ka nwa Bichi sonye n'òtù ahụ, Garba hapụrụ otu n'ime ndị otu egwuregwu ya.

en: However, fresh facts have revealed that Dikko hatched and implemented the plan with the support of some NFF officials.
ibo: Kaosi di, eziokwu ohuru ekpughere bụ na Dikko choro ma mejupụta atụmatụ ya site na nkwado nke ụfọdụ ndị NFF.

en: Multiple sources disclosed to SaharaReporters that Dikko came through with the plan to seek favour on his corruption case with the Independent Corrupt Practices and other related Offences Commission and the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission.
ibo: Egosila ndị ntọakụkọ Sahara otutu ihe na Dikko sitere na atụmatụ a iji chọọ ihu ọma gbasara omume aka azụ ya na ebe ndị n'akpọchị ndị aka azụ, ndị iwu ndị ọzọ na ndị ọrụ na-ahu maka mkpafu akụ na ụba.

en: The ICPC is investigating Dikko and some other executives of the NFF for financial malpractices and diverting funds meant for the association.
ibo: Ndị ICPC na-enyocha Dikko na ụfọdụ ndị isi NFF maka mmejọ ego na ụzọ ichekwa ego echere maka ọgbakọ a

en: The ICPC in September obtained a court order to seal a house belonging to Dikko in Rivers State.
ibo: Ndị ICPC na Septemba nwetara ikike ụlọ ikpe iji mechie ụlọ nke Dikko na Rivers Steeti.

en: 'The inclusion of DSS boss' son was to get favour and goodwill.
ibo: Nsonye nke nwa onye isi DSS bụ iji nweta ihu ọma.

en: Dikko carried out the plan so that he and other NFF executives undergoing investigation by EFCC and ICPC would be free.
ibo: Dikko mere atụmatụ ahụ ka ya na ndị isi NFF ndị ọzọ na-eme nyocha nke EFCC na ICPC ga-enwere onwe ha.

en: 'This was perfectly planned out at a time NFF is under intense watch and investigation,' sources said.
ibo: A kpara nkata a nke ọma n'oge NFF nọ na nche na nyocha siri ike.' akọrọ na .

en: NFF President, Amaju Pinnick; First Vice President, Seyi Akinwunmi; Dikko; and another executive member, Yusuf 'Fresh', are all facing corruption case in a 17-count charge on misappropriation of $8.4m belonging to the football body.
ibo: onye isi ndị NFF, Amaju Pinnick; osote onye isi nke mbu, Seyi Akinwunmi; Dikko; na onye so n'otu ndị isi ọzọ, Yusuf ' ịdị saam', ha niile nwere ikpe maka aka azụ na ikpe ọnụọgụgụ17 banyere ịkpafu dọla nde 8.4 nke otu bọlu .

en: The NFF executive members had been ordered to appear in court on November 5 2019, which is the next adjourned date for the case.
ibo: Enyere ndị isi NFF iwu ịpụta n'ụlọ ikpe na Nọvemba 5, 2019 nke bụ ụbọchị enwelara ikpe ahụ.

en: Meanwhile, the NFF had claimed that Oduko was selected by the coach because of his understanding of the game and skills, countering claims that he was dropped for a fellow teammate.
ibo: Mana ndị NFF kwuru na ọ bụ onye nhazị ha họrọ Oduko maka otu o si aghọta egwuregwu a, na-ekwughasi okwu ekwuru na a hapuru ya maka onye otu ha ọzọ .

en: 'Bichi is a striker; Oduko is a left-back.
ibo: Bichi bụ onye straika; Oduko bụ onye ukwu ịpa azụ

en: Oduko was dropped for Charles Etim.
ibo: A hapuru Oduko maka Charles Etim .

en: Oduko was the player that lost the kick in the shootout with Guinea in the semifinals of the U17 AFCON in Tanzania, which condemned Eaglets to the third-place match,' said NFF media officer, Demola Olajire.
ibo: Oduko bụ onye ahụ gbajọrọ na asọmpị anyị na Guinea gbara na U17 AFCON na Tanzania, nke mere anyị ji gbaa ndị nke atọ' onye kwuru bụ onye ntọakụkọ nke NFF, Demola Olajire.

en: The Golden Eaglets had played two matches in the ongoing tournament but Bichi is yet to feature in the competition.
ibo: Ndị Golden Eaglets emeela egwuregwu abụọ n'asọmpị a na-aga n'ihu mana Bichi apụtaghị na asọmpị ahụ.

en: Rivers Police Explain Closure Of Port Harcourt-Aba Road Since March 9 Elections
ibo: Ndị uweojii Rivers na-akọwa Mmechi ụzọ Port Harcourt-Aba Road Kemgbe ntuli aka nke Mach 9

en: The action was meant to 'protect INEC office situated between Waterlines and GRA bus stops, its personnel and electoral materials in the office'.
ibo: Emere ihe a 'iji chekwaa ụlọ ọrụ INEC dị n'etiti ebe nkwụsị Waterlines na ụgbọ ala GRA , ndị ọrụ ya na ihe ntuli aka dị na ụlọ ọrụ'

en: The Police Command in Rivers State has said the continuous closure of the Port Harcourt-Aba road leading to the office of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) is in 'public interest'.
ibo: ndị uwe ojii na Rivers steeti ekwuola na mmechi na-aga n'ihu na Port Harcourt-Aba na-eduga n'ọfịs ndị na-ahụ maka ntụlị aka (INEC) bụ 'maka ọdịmma ọhaneze'.

en: DSP Nnamdi Omoni, spokesman of the Rivers Police Command appealed to the residents of Port Harcourt, the Rivers State capital, to show understanding and cooperation.
ibo: DSP Nnamdi Omoni, ọnụ na-ekwuru ndị uwe ojii Rivers rịọrọ ndị bi na Port Harcourt, isi obodo Rivers steeti, iji gosi nghọta na imekọ ihe ọnụ.

en: According to Omoni, the closure was not intended to cause hardship for the residents.
ibo: Dị ka Omoni si kwuo, ebughị n'obi iwetere ndị bi na ya ihe isi ike.

en: The Waterlines Bus-stop to GRA stop axis of the road has remained closed since the March 9, 2019 governorship and house of assembly polls.
ibo: Mpụga Waterlines ruo nkwụsị okporo ụzọ GRA ahụ ka emechiri kemgbe ọnwa 9 nke afọ 2019, ntuli aka nke gọvanọ na nke ụlọ ọgbakọ.

en: 'It is in the interest of Rivers; it is not intended to cause hardship for the residents.
ibo: 'Ọ bụ maka ọdịmma nke ndị Rivers; ebughị n'obi ịkpatara ndị bi na ya ihe isi ike .

en: The people should bear with the Command; it is only for a while,' he said, adding that the action was meant to 'protect INEC office situated between Waterlines and GRA bus stops, its personnel and electoral materials in the office'.
ibo: Ndi mmadu doo obi maka Iwu a; ọ bụ naanị nwa oge, 'ka o kwuru, na-agbakwunye na ihe a mere iji' chekwaa ụlọ ọrụ INEC nke dị n'etiti nkwụsị bọs nke Waterlines na GRA, ndị ọrụ ya na akụrụngwa ntuli aka '.

en: Rivers Women To Turn Up At INEC Office Naked — Unless Effanga Is Removed As REC
ibo: ụmụnwanyị Rivers ga-agbaọtọ ga na ụlọ ọrụ INEC - Ọ gwụla ma ewepụrụ Effanga dịka REC

en: The women threatened that if in the next 48 hours, Professor Mahmood Yakubu, the National Chairman of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), fails to heed to their demand, they would storm INEC's Port Harcourt head office naked.
ibo: ụmụ nwaanyị ahụ yiri egwu na ọ bụrụ na n'ime awa 48 na-abịa, ọkamụta Mahmood Yakubu, Onye isi oche nke ụlọ ọrụ na-ahụ maka ntuli aka (INEC) jụrụ ịnabata arịrịọ ha, ha ga-agbaọtọ gaa n'isi ụlọ ọrụ INEC nke Port Harcourt.

en: Thousands of women have taken to the streets of Port Harcourt, the Rivers State capital, to demand the immediate redeployment of the Obo Effanga, Resident Electoral Commissioner (REC).
ibo: Ọtụtụ puku ndị nwaanyị agbaala n'okporo ụzọ Port Harcourt, isi obodo Rivers Steeti iji chọọ nchụpụ Obo Effanga, dịka REC.

en: The protesters, dressed in black and drawn from the 23 local government areas of the state, said his continued stay in the state was breeding tension and possible breakdown of law and order.
ibo: Ndị ngagharị iwe a, yi uwe ojii na ndị si mpaghara iri abụọ na atọ nke steeti ahụ wee sị na ọnụnọ ya na steeti ahụ bụ esemokwu na nsogbu ga - agbasa nke iwu na usoro ya.

en: Carrying placards with various inscriptions, the women threatened that if in the next 48 hours, Professor Mahmood Yakubu, the National Chairman of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), fails to heed to their demand, they would storm INEC's Port Harcourt head office naked.
ibo: Na-eburu kaadị e dere ihe dị iche iche, ụmụ nwanyị ahụ kwuru na ọ bụrụ na n'ime awa iri anọ na asatọ na-abịanụ, Prọfesọ Mahmood Yakubu, Onye isi oche nke ụlọ ọrụ na-ahụ maka ntuli aka (INEC) añaghị ntị na arịrịọ ha, ha ga-agbaọtọ gaa n'isi ụlọ ọrụ INEC dị na Port Harcourt .

en: Protests for and against the INEC REC have intensified in Rivers State in the last three days, with pro-government demonstrators asking that Effanga be retained in the state, whereas the anti-Effanga protesters want his removal, accusing him of compromising the outcome of the March 9 governorship and state house of assembly elections in the state to favour Nyesom Wike, incumbent Governor of Rivers State.
ibo: Ngagharị iwe nke megide INEC REC agbaliela na Rivers steeti n'ime ụbọchị atọ gara aga, ndị na-eme ngagharị iwe gọọmentị na-arịọ ka edobe Effanga na steeti ahụ, ebe ndị na-emegide Effanga na-achọ ka ewepu ya, na-ebo ya ebubo imebi ihe ga-esi na ya nhọpụta ndị isi ọchịchị n'abalị iri-iteghete nke ọnwa nke isii na steeti iji kwado Nyesom Wike, onye ọchịchị gọvanọ nke Gọọmenti Rivers steeti.

en: The women are not alone in the call for the removal of Effanga, as some governorship candidates have joined the call.
ibo: Ọ bụghị naanị ụmụ nwaanyị nọ n'ọkwa maka mkpochapu Effanga, ụfọdụ ndị na-azọ ọkwa gọvanọ esonyela oku a.

en: In a recent article he wrote and circulated, Tonye Cole, the governorship candidate of the All Progressives Congress (APC), said only the redeployment of Effanga would guarantee conducive atmosphere for free and fair elections in Rivers State.
ibo: N'edemede ya na-adịbeghị anya o dere ma kesaa, Tonye Cole, onye na-azọ ọkwa gọvanọ nke APC, kwuru na nanị nhapụ nke Effanga ga-eme ka enwee ntuli aka ziri ezi na Rivers Steeti.

en: He called for the outright cancellation of the polls, just as he re-echoed earlier calls by Dumo Lulu-Briggs, the Accord Party candidate, who had described the entire exercise as a 'charade', and Victor Fingesi of the Action Democratic Party (ADP), who said INEC planned the polls to fail.
ibo: Ọ kpọrọ oku ka akagbuo votu ahụ kpamkpam, dị ka ọ kpọghachiri oku Dumo Lulu-Briggs na ntuli aka ndị otu Accord, onye kọwapụtara mmemme ahụ niile dịka 'ọgbahara', yana Victor Fingesi nke ADP, onye kwuru na INEC mere atụmatụ ịtụ vootu ga-akụ afọ n'ala.

en: Ruiz Asks Anthony Joshua For Third Fight After Nigerian Reclaims Heavyweight Titles
ibo: Ruiz na-arịọ Anthony Joshua Maka ọgụ nke atọ mgbe ndị Naịjirịa welatara ịkọ mmeri

en: It was a masterful performance from AJ in Saudi Arabia; the Nigerian-born British boxer schooled Ruiz from range and never allowed the Mexican-American to close the gap.
ibo: Ọ bụ ọmarịcha arụmọrụ sitere na AJ na Saudi Arabia; onye Naịjirịa na-akụ ọkpọ amụrụ na Britain kụchara Ruiz, nye ya nnukwu oke ma ghara ikwe ka onye Mexican-American ahụ mechie oghere ahụ.

en: Anthony Joshua on Saturday night comprehensively defeated Andy Ruiz Jr 118-110, 118-110, 119-109 in their rematch to regain his IBF, IBO, WBO and WBA (super) heavyweight titles.
ibo: Anthony Joshua n'abali Satọde jiri nke ọma merie Andy Ruiz Jr 118-110, 118-110, 119-109 na nhazigharị ha iji nwetaghachi aha IBF, IBO, WBO na WBA (ike) ike mmeri.

en: It was a masterful performance from AJ in Saudi Arabia; the Nigerian-born British boxer schooled Ruiz from range and never allowed the Mexican-American to close the gap.
ibo: Ọ bụ ọmarịcha arụmọrụ sitere na AJ na Saudi Arabia; onye Naịjirịa na-akụ ọkpọ a mụrụ na Britain kụchara Ruiz nye ya nnukwu oke ma ghara ikwe ka onye Mexican-America ahụ mechie oghere ahụ.

en: Joshua jabbed Ruiz Jr to death and he never gave the champion a chance to get inside and land the nasty hooks that led to AJ's demise the first time around.
ibo: Joshua tiri Ruiz Jr ọnwụ ma ọ dịghị mgbe ọ nyere onye mmeri ohere ịbanye n'ime ma webata nko ahụ jọgburu onwe ya nke mere ka mbibi AJ na adaa nke mbụ.

en: After the fight, both men showed their respect for one another and embraced before they did their post-fight interviews, according to talksport.com
ibo: Mgbe ọgụ ahụ gachara, ụmụ nwoke abụọ ahụ kwanyeere ibe ha ugwu ma nabata tupu ha agbaa ajụjụ ọnụ mgbe ha na-ebuso agha, dịka talksport.com si kwuo.

en: When Joshua asked Ruiz if he wanted to retire following calls for AJ to do the same after he lost in New York, Ruiz answered that he wanted a third fight.
ibo: Mgbe Joshua jụrụ Ruiz ma ọ chọrọ ịla ezumike nká na-esochi oku maka AJ ime otu ihe ahụ mgbe ọ nwụsịrị na New York, Ruiz zara na ọ chọrọ ịlụ ọgụ nke atọ.

en: Grabbing the mic, he said, 'I want the third fight.'
ibo: ọ naara igwe okwu n'ike, si 'achọrọm ọgụ nke atọ'.

en: He then asked the crowd, 'Who wants to see the third fight?
ibo: ọ jụrụ ndị gbakọrọ, 'Kedu onye chọrọ ihu ọgụ nke atọ?'.

en: In fact, Ruiz Jr asked the Saudi Arabia crowd several times if they would like to see a third fight between the two men and he seemed to want to do it in Saudi again, too.
ibo: N'ezie, Ruiz Jr jụrụ igwe mmadụ Saudi Arabia ọtụtụ oge ma ha ga-achọ ịhụ ọgụ nke atọ n'etiti mmadụ abụọ ahụ na o yiri ka ọ chọrọ ime ya na Saudi ọzọ.

en: Joshua suggested he was well up for it too, declaring, 'If you've heard, we're gonna do a third.'
ibo: Joshua tụrụ alo ka ya nọrọ nke ọma, na-ekwupụta, 'Ọ bụrụ na ị nụrụ, anyị ga-eme nke atọ.'

en: Ruiz was outclassed on the night and he admits he went into the rematch too heavy, having tipped the scales at more than 20 stone on Friday.
ibo: N'abalị agbapụrụ Ruiz ọ ma kweta na ọ banyere ọgụ ahụ n'oke arụ ahu, na o tinyere ihe karịrị akpịrịkpa ahụ ihe karịrị okwute iri abụọ na Fraịde.

en: He said, 'It was his night.
ibo: O kwuru 'ọ bụ abalị ya .

en: I didn't prepare how I should have.
ibo: A kwadoghịm kam si kwesi'

en: 'I gained too much weight.
ibo: Eburu m ibu nke ukwuu .

en: I don't want to give excuses, he won.
ibo: Achọghị m ịnye ngọpụ, ọ meriri .

en: He boxed me around.
ibo: Ọ kụrụ m ihe tinka kuru pan.

en: 'If we do a third fight, I'm going to get in shape.
ibo: 'Ọ bụrụ na anyị na-agba ọgụ nke atọ, aga m enwe ọdịdị .

en: I'll be in the best shape of my life.
ibo: Aga m anọ n'ụdị kachasị mma nke ndụ m.

en: 'I thought I was going to feel stronger.
ibo: Echere m na m ga-enwe ahụ ike .

en: Next fight I'm going to get more prepared.
ibo: M na-esote ọgụ m ga-akwadokwu .

en: I tried to train myself for this.
ibo: Agbalịrị m ịzụ onwe m maka nke a.

en: I was chasing him too much.
ibo: Anọ m na-achụ ya nke ukwuu .

en: I was hesitating too much.
ibo: Anọ m na-egbu oge nke ukwuu .

en: Russia Gets Four Year Ban From All Global Sporting Events Over Doping
ibo: Russia na-enweta mmachi afọ anọ na mmemme egwuregwu ụwa niile maka nruruaka .

en: It means the Russia will not be allowed at events such as the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics and the 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar.
ibo: Ọ pụtara na a gaghị anabata Russia na ihe omume dịka Tokyo 2020 Olympics na Paralympics na 2022 na asọmpị mba ụwa FIFA na Qatar.

en: Russia has been handed a four-year ban from all major sporting events by the World Anti-Doping Agency.
ibo: Ndị otu mba ụwa na-arụ ọrụ megide nruruaka enyela Russia afọ anọ ha agaghị esonye na ihe omume egwuregwu niile.

en: It means the Russia will not be allowed at events such as the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics and the 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar, the BBC reports.
ibo: Ọ pụtara na a gaghị anabata Russia na ihe omume dịka Tokyo 2020 Olympic na Paralympics na asọmpi iko mba ụwa FIFA nke 2022 na Qatar, BBC na-akọ.

en: But athletes, who can prove they are untainted by the doping scandal, will be able to compete under a neutral flag.
ibo: Ma ndị na-eme egwuregwu, ndị nwere ike igosipụta na he esonyeghị n'asịrị ahụ, ga-enwe ike ịsọ mpi n'okpuru ọkọlọtọ nọpụrụ iche.

en: WADA's executive committee made the unanimous decision in a meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland.
ibo: Kọmitii na-ahụ maka WADA mere mkpebi a n'otu nzukọ na Lausanne, Switzerland.

en: It comes after Russia's Anti-Doping Agency was declared non-compliant for manipulating laboratory data handed over to investigators in January 2019.
ibo: Ọ abịara mgbe ekwuputara na ndị na-arụ ọrụ megide nruruaka nke Russia na-enweghị mmezi maka ịmegharị ọrụ nyocha n'ụlọ nyocha ha enyefere ndị ọrụ nyocha na Jenụwarị 2019.

en: It had to hand over data to WADA as condition of its controversial reinstatement in 2018 after a three-year suspension for its vast state-sponsored doping scandal.
ibo: O kwesiri inyefe WADA ihe eji arụ ọrụ dị ka ọnọdụ nke iweghachite arụmụka ya na 2018 mgbe a chụpụrụ ya afọ atọ maka asambodo nruruaka steeti ya buru ibu.

en: WADA president, Sir Craig Reedie, said the decision showed its 'determination to act resolutely in the face of the Russian doping crisis'.
ibo: Onye isi WADA, Mazịr Craig Reedie, kwuru na mkpebi a gosipụtara 'mkpebi ya ime mkpebi siri ike n'agbanyeghị nsogbu nruruaka nke Russia'.

en: He added, 'For too long, Russian doping has detracted from clean sport.
ibo: Ọ gbakwụnyere, 'Ruo ogologo oge, ọgwụ ndị Russia emerụsịrị emerụ site na egwuregwu dị ọcha .

en: The blatant breach by the Russian authorities of Rusada's reinstatement conditions demanded a robust response.
ibo: Mkpesa siri ike nke ndị ọchịchị Russia nke ọnọdụ iweghachi Rusada chọrọ nzaghachi siri ike.

en: That is exactly what has been delivered.
ibo: Nke ahụ bụ kpọmkwem ihe ewepụtara.

en: Russia was afforded every opportunity to get its house in order and re-join the global anti-doping community for the good of its athletes and of the integrity of sport but it chose instead to continue in its stance of deception and denial.
ibo: Enyere Russia ohere ọ iji jịkọta ụlọ ya n'usoro ma soro ndị obodo na-egbochi mkpokọ ụwa maka ọdịmma ndị egwuregwu ya na eziokwu nke egwuregwu kama ọ họọrọ ịga n'ihu na ọnọdụ ya nke aghụghọ na ngọnarị .

en: Sack DSS DG, Yusuf Bichi, Premium Times Tells Buhari In New Editorial
ibo: Chụọ DSS DG, Yusuf Bichi, Premium Times na-agwa Buhari na Nchịkọ Ọhụrụ

en: Evidently, Mr Bichi's DSS has become a major threat to the norms and values of a democratic system.
ibo: 'Ihe atụ gosiri na, Mz Bichi's onye isi ndị DSS abụrụla ihe iyi egwu nye ụkpụrụ usoro ọchịchị onye kwuo uche ya.

en: Premium Times, an independent news platform in Nigeria, has called on President Muhammadu Buhari to immediately fire Yusuf Bichi, head of the Department of State Services, over his role in his men's Invasion of the Federal High Court in Abuja last Friday to rearrest Omoyele Sowore.
ibo: Premium Times, ụlọ ọrụ akụkọ nọrọ onwe ya na Naịjirịa akpọọla Onye isi ala Muhammadu Buhari ka ọ chụọ Yusuf Bichi, onye isi Ngalaba nke Ọrụ ọrụ, maka ọrụ ya na mwakpo nke ndị agha ya na mwakpo ụlọ ikpe gọọmentị etiti na Abuja na Fraịde gara aga iji nwuchie Omoyele Sowore .

en: DSS Spokesperson, Peter Afunanya, had initially denied the invasion despite evidence.
ibo: Onye na-ekwuchitere DSS, Peter Afunanya, agọnarị ụzọ mwakpo ahụ n'agbanyeghị ihe akaebe.

en: The service later backtracked when Bichi sent a delegation to apologise to the Chief Judge of the Federal High Court over the incident.
ibo: Ọrụ ahụ mechara kụọ azụ mgbe Bichi zigara ndị nnọchi anya ịrịọ Onye isi ọka ikpe nke ụlọ ikpe dị elu nke etiti ala ịrịọ maka ihe ahụ merenụ.

en: In an editorial on Friday, Premium Times said, The frightening scale of impunity and arbitrary conduct under the presidency of General Muhammadu Buhari plumbed new depths on Friday, December 6 when armed operatives of the State Security Service (often called the Department of State Services – DSS), invaded Federal High Court No.
ibo: N'ime nchịkọta akụkọ na Fraịde, Premium Times kwuru, ọnụ ọgụgụ dị egwu nke enweghị ntaramahụhụ na akparamaagwa n'okpuru ọchịchị Onye isi ala bụ Muhammadu Buhari dakwasịrị omimi ọhụụ na Fraịde, Disemba 6 mgbe ndị ọrụ agha nke Ndị Ọrụ Nchebe Obodo (nke a na-akpọkarị Ngalaba Ọrụ - DSS), wakporo ụlọ ikpe ukwu nke etiti ala No .

en: 7 in Abuja, the Federal Capital Territory.
ibo: 7 na Abuja, isi ngalaba obodo .

en: We are now at that point where it is being argued that never in the history of Nigeria, including during the colonial period and the dark days of military rule, has such brazen act of disrespect for the sanctity of our law courts and independence of the judiciary been perpetrated.
ibo: Anyị nọzi n'oge ahụ ebe a na-arụ ụka na ọ dịghị mgbe ọ bụla n'akụkọ ihe mere eme nke Nigeria, gụnyere n'oge ọchịchị ndị ọcha na oge ọchịchịrị nke ọchịchị ndị agha, nwere omume enweghị nsọpụrụ dị otú ahụ maka ịdị nsọ nke ụlọ ikpe iwu na nnwere onwe nke ikpe.

en: We are greatly concerned that the DSS under the leadership of Yusuf Bichi has repeatedly acted as if it is above the laws of the land.
ibo: Anyị nwere nchegbu dị ukwuu na ndị DSS n'okpuru Yusuf Bichi emeela ihe ugboro ugboro ka a ga-asị na ọ karịrị iwu nke ala .

en: The serial violations of the fundamental human rights of the citizens by the security outfit since Mr Bichi assumed the reins of leadership and the disdain with which it has been treating the judicial arm of government through flagrant disobedience of court orders that seek to put a stop to such violations, have indeed become routine.
ibo: Mmebi ahụ mebiri ikike ụmụ amaala mmadụ nke site na nchekwa ebe ọ bụ na Mz Bichi chere na ikike nke onye isi na nlelị nke o jirila na-emeso ikpe nke gọọmentị site na nnupụisi dị egwu nke iwu ụlọikpe na-achọ ịkwụsị nkwụsi ike ụdị mmebi a, abụrụla ihe a na-eme kwa ụbọchị .

en: Dr Okpala said that the disease symptoms include fever, headaches, sore throat, general body weakness, coughing, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle and chest pains.
ibo: Dọkịta Okpala kwuru na ihe e ji ama oria a gụnyere ahụ ọkụ, isi ọwụwa, ọnya akpịrị, adịghị ike anụ ahụ, ụkwara, ọgbụgbọ, afọ ọsịsa, akwara na obi mgbu.

en: He explained that in severe cases, unexplainable bleeding from ears, eyes, nostrils, mouths and other body openings were observed.
ibo: Ọ kọwara na n'ọnọdụ dị oke njọ, a na-ahụ ọbara ọgbụgba na-enweghị atụ site na ntị, anya, imi, ọnụ na oghere ndị ọzọ.

en: Commissioner said the time between the infection and appearance of symptoms of the disease ranges from 3 to 21 days.
ibo: Kọmịshọna kwuru na oge mbute ọrịa ahụ na ọdịdị mgbaàmà ya bụ site n'ụbọchị atọ ruo ụbọchị iri abụọ na otu.

en: He emphasised that early treatment and diagnosis increase the chances of survival.
ibo: O kwusiri ike na ọgwụgwọ na nchọpụta ọrịa n'oge na-amụba oghere nke ịdị ndụ.

en: Dr Okpala explained that people of all age groups, who come in contact with urine, faeces, saliva, and blood of rats, stand higher risk of contracting the disease.
ibo: Dọkịta Okpala kọwara na ndị nọ n'afọ niile, bụ ndị mamịrị, nsị, asọmmiri na ọbara oke metụtara nwere oke ihe egwu ibute ọrịa a.

en: People living in rat-infested environment also have increased chances of coming in contact with rats.
ibo: Ndi mmadụ bi na gburugburu ebe e nwere oke bu ọrịa a nwekwara oghere ibute ya.

en: People who consume potentially contaminated food stuff especially those left open overnight or dried outside in the open.
ibo: Ndị na-eri nri nwere nje ahụ ọkachasị nri ndị gho oghe n'abali maọbụ ndị a gbara n'anwụ n'èzí.

en: People who handle or process rodents for consumption and those who do not perform hand hygiene when appropriate.
ibo: 'Ndị na-ejikwa maọbụ hazie òké maka oriri na ndị anaghị akwọ aka mgbe o kwesiri.

en: Relatives who care for sick persons with unexplained illnesses at home, doctors, nurses and other health workers providing direct patient care in the absence of standard precautions.
ibo: 'Ndị ikwu ndị na-elekọta ndị ọrịa nwere ọrịa ndị agaghị akọwa n'ụlọ, ndị dọkịta, ndị nọọsụ na ndị ọrụ ahụike ndị ọzọ na-enye ndị ọrịa nlekọta ebe enweghi ozigbo.

en: Hospital staff that clean, disinfect contaminated surfaces, materials and supplies without adequate protective gear.
ibo: 'Ndị ụlọ ọgwụ na-ehicha, na-ehicha ihe ndị butere ọrịa a, ihe na akụrụngwa na-enweghị ngwa nchebe zuru oke.

en: He adds: Laboratory staff who handle blood samples of suspected Lassa fever patients, without appropriate precautions, medical or support staff that prepare or handle dead bodies without appropriate precautions can contract the disease'.
ibo: Ọ gbakwụnyere: 'Ndị ọrụ ụlọ nyocha na-eme nlele ọbara nke ndị a na-enyo enyo na ha bu ọrịa Lassa fever, na-enweghị nlezianya kwesiri ekwesi, ụlọ ọgwụ maọbụ ndị ọrụ nkwado na-akwadebe maọbụ na-edozi ozu ndị enweghi nlezianya kwesiri ekwesi nwere ike ibute ọrịa ahụ.'

en: To reduce the risk of Lassa fever, he gave the following advice:.
ibo: Iji belata ihe egwu nke ọrịa Lassa fever, o nyere ndụmọdụ ndị a:.

en: Ensure proper environmental sanitation, i.e.
ibo: ' Gbaa mbọ hụ na a na-edebe gburugburu ebe obibi ọcha, i.e.

en: The ministry is also working toward facilitating the Diaspora Estate and portal, where Ndi Anambra in The Diaspora can register online to ascertain their numeric strength.
ibo: Ụlọ ọrụ mịnịstrị ahụ na-agbakwa mbọ ime ka ndị 'Diaspora Estate and Portal', ebe ndị Anambra bi na 'Diaspora' nwere ike ịdebanye aha n'ịntanetị iji chọpụta ike ha.

en: keep your environment clean at all times, and block all holes in your houses to prevent rats from entering.
ibo: Debe gburugburu gị ọcha mgbe niile, ma gbochie oghere niile dị n’ụlọ gị iji gbochie oke ịbanye.

en: Cover your dustbins and dispose refuse properly.
ibo: Kpuchie ebe ị na-awụkọ ahịhịa gị ma tụfuo ya nke ọma.

en: Communities should set up dump sites very far from their homes to reduce the chances of having rodents within homes.
ibo: Ọha obodo kwesiri itinye ebe ikpofu ahịhịa ka ọ ghara ịdị nso n'ụlọ ebe obibi ha iji belata ohere inwe oke n’ime ulo.

en: Store food stuff like rice, garri, beans, corn/maize and the likes in air tight containers.
ibo: Chekwaa nri dịka osikapa, garri, agwa, ọka na ihe ndị ọzọ n'ihe ikuku agaghị aba.

en: Avoid drying food stuff outside on the floor and on roadside where it will be exposed to contamination.
ibo: Zeere ịgba ihe oriri n'anwụ na mbara na n'okporo ụzọ ebe ọ ga-ebute nje ahụ.

en: Youths of Anambra will undergo training on Project Smart Job' that will make booking of hotel, transportation and other online services, easy and accessible.
ibo: 'Ndị ntorobịa nke Anambra ga-anata ọzụzụ na 'Project Smart Job ' nke ga-eme ka ntinye akwụkwọ n'ụlọ nkwari akụ, njem na ọrụ ịntanetị ndị ọzọ, dị mfe ma kwe nnweta.

en: He advised Ndi Anambra to avoid bush fires which could lead to displacement of rats from bushes to human dwellings and eliminate rats in homes and communities by setting rat traps.
ibo: Ọ dụrụ ndị Ndị Anambra ọdụ ka ha zeere ịgba ọhịa ọkụ nke nwere ike ime ka oke site n'ọhịa baa n'ụlọ obibi mmadụ ma kpochapụ oke n'ụlọ na obodo site n'ikwere ha ọnya.

en: He enjoined healthcare workers to practice standard precautions at all times, that is, wearing gloves when handling patients or providing care to an ill patient/relative.
ibo: Ọ gwara ndị ọrụ ahụike ka ha na-akpachapụ anya ha mgbe niile, ya bụ, iyi uwe aka (gloves) mgbe ha na-elekọta ndị ọrịa.

en: Healthcare workers should maintain a high index of suspicion for Lassa fever, be vigilant and look out for symptoms of Lassa fever.
ibo: 'Ndị ọrụ ahụike kwesiri ịdị na-enyocha nke ukwuu maka ọrịa Lassa, kee nkwụcha ma lelee ihe mgbaàmà nke ọrịa Lassa fever.

en: Dr Okpala advised that any febrile illness that has not responded to 48 hours use of anti-malaria or antibiotics should raise an index of suspicion for Lassa fever.
ibo: dr Okpala dụrụ ọdụ na ọrịa ọbụla ejighi ọgwụ ịba maọbụ ọgwụ nje gbochie awa iri anọ na asatọ kwesiri ka e enyoo ya dịka ọrịa Lassa fever.

en: He also called on the healthcare workers to report any suspected case of Lassa fever to their local government disease surveillance and notification officer to access care.
ibo: ọ kpọkuzikwara ndị ọrụ ahụike ka ha kọọrọ ndị ọrụ gọọmentị obodo na-enyocha ọrịa a maka onye ọbụla ha chere bu ọrịa Lassa fever iji nweta nlekọta.

en: The commissioner said that Anambra State Ministry of Health was on the alert and fully prepared to respond to any outbreak of Lassa fever in the state.
ibo: Kọmịshọna ahụ kwuru na Mịnịsta Ahụike steeti Anambra nọ na nche ma jikere nke ọma maka ọria Lassa fever na steeti ahụ.

en: GOVERNMENT ASSURES OF READINESS TO COMPLETE OKPUNOEZE /UMEOJILIGWE NNEWI ROADS By Mercy Akaolisa/Theresa Muowe :
ibo: GỌỌMENTỊ KWERE NKWA ỊRỤSỊ OKPOROỤZỌ OKPUNOEZE/UMEOJILIGWE NNEWI site n'aka Mercy/Akaolisa/Theresa Muowe:

en: Anambra State Government has assured the leadership of Uruagu Nnewi Community of its readiness to complete Okpunoeze/Umeojiligwe Uruagu Nnewi roads.
ibo: Gọọmentị Anambra emela ka obi sie ndị isi Uruagu Nnewi ike na ọ ga-adị njikere ịrụsị okporoụzọ Okpunoeze/Umeojiligwe Uruagu Nnewi.

en: Special Adviser (SA) to the Governor on Budget Monitoring and Efficiency, Mr Melie Onyejepu said this while addressing the group after an inspection tour on ongoing reconstruction of drainage channel of the roads.
ibo: Onye ndụmọdụ pụrụ iche (SA) nye Gọvanọ na Nnyocha Mmezi a kpọrọ Budget Monitoring and Efficiency, Maazị Melie Onyejepu kwuru nke a mgbe ọ na-agwa ndị otu ahụ okwu mgbe ọ gasịrị njem nlegharị anya na mwugharị okporo ụzọ mmiri.

en: Mr Onyejepu expressed the determination of the Gov. Obiano-led administration to ensure that the roads were in good shape, noting that the contractor had since been mobilised back to the site.
ibo: Maazị Onyejepu kwupụtara mkpebi nke gọọmentị Gọvanọ Obiano iji hụ na okporoụzọ ndị ahụ dị mma, na-arịba ama na kemgbe ka onye ọrụ ngo ahụ nọ na saịtị ahụ.

en: The economy of Anambra State is doing well because Gov. Willie Obiano has invested a lot on security, education, good roads, and in other vital areas.
ibo: Akụnaụba nke steeti Anambra na-eme nke ọma n’ihi na Gov. Willie Obiano etinyela ọtụtụ ego na nchekwa, mmụta, ezi ụzọ, na mpaghara ndị ọzọ dị mkpa.

en: According to him, the roads were delayed because of the prolonged rains, the redesigning of the drainage channel as well as increase in the bearing strength on the pavement.
ibo: Dịka o si kwuo, ụzọ ndị ahụ gburu oge n'ihi oke mmiri ozuzo, nrụgharị nke ọwa mmiri yana mmụba ike nke 'pavement'.

en: The SA re-assured them that Government was committed to completing the roads before the next raining season.
ibo: SA ahụ kwere ha nkwa na Gọọmentị na-agba mbọ ịrụcha ụzọ ndị ahụ tupu oge udu mmiri.

en: The President General, Uruagu Community, Mr Charles Nwoye praised the giant strides of Gov. Obiano.
ibo: Onyeisi obodo Uruagu, Maazị Charles Nwoye toro Gov. Obiano.

en: She said that Anambra was the safest state in Nigeria with accessible good road network.
ibo: O kwuru na Anambra bụ steeti kasị nwe nchebe na Naịjiria nke nwere ezigbo okporo ụzọ.

en: The PG said that although the community was grateful for the intervention by the state government, but stressed the need to ensure completion of the roads before the rainy season.
ibo: PG kwuru na n'agbanyeghị na ndị obodo na-ekele ekele maka ntinye aka nke gọọmentị steeti ahụ, mana o kwusiri ike mkpa ọ dị iji hụ na arụchara okporoụzọ tupu oge udummiri.

en: A stakeholder in Uruagu Nnewi, Mr Ben Aghazu pledged that the community would offer the construction company the needed support to complete the project.
ibo: Onye nwere ego n'Uruagu Nnewi, Maazị Ben Aghazu kwere nkwa na obodo ahụ ga-enye ụlọ ọrụ ahụ ihe enyemaka ha chọrọ iji rụchaa ọrụ ahụ.

en: In my personal capacity, I have provided a place of residence for the workers to ensure their availability in the site.
ibo: N'ikike m, enyela m ebe obibi maka ndị ọrụ iji hụ na ha nọ na saịtị ahụ.

en: Aghazu commended Onyejepu efforts in ensuring that the state government intervened in 100-Foot Road, Nnewi.
ibo: Aghazu toro mbọ Onyejepu gbara iji hụ na gọọmentị etiti tinyere aka n'okporo ụzọ dị '100Foot', na Nnewi.

en: Another stakeholder of the community, Mr Agu Okonkwo praised the Onyejepu for ensuring that the roads continued to command government's attention.
ibo: Onye ọzọ nwere ego n'obodo ahụ, Maazị Agu Okonkwo toro Onyejepu maka ịgba mbọ hụ na okporoụzọ ndị ahụ gara n'ihu na-adọta ndị gọọmentị.

en: He also said that the community was worried because the sand earlier coated on the roads was posing health challenges to residents of the community.
ibo: O kwukwara na obodo ahụ na-echegbu onwe ha n'ihi na ájá ahụ a wụrụ n'okporo ụzọ ndị ahụ na-ewetara ndị bi n'obodo ahụ nsogbu ahụike.

en: ADB TO BANKROLL CONSTRUCTION OF RURAL/FARM ROADS IN ANAMBRA AT PROJECT COST OF 50 MILLION DOLLARS
ibo: ADB ỊKWADO ỌRỤ OKPOROỤZỌ IME OBODO/UGBO NA ANAMBRA NKE GA-EWE NDE DỌLA IRI ISE.

en: The African Development Bank (ADB) is to bankroll the construction of rural/farm roads in 14 Local Government Areas of Anambra state at the cost of 50 million dollars, a top aid of the Anambra state Government says.
ibo: Ụlọakụ 'The African Development Bank (ADB) ga-eji ego ruru nde dọla iri ise kwado ịrụ okporoụzọ ime obodo/ugbo na mpaghara okpuru ọchịchị iri na anọ nke steeti Anambra, otu enyemaka dị elu nke gọọmentị steeti Anambra kwuru.

en: The Project Coordinator of Anambra Rural Access and Agricultural Marketing Project (RAAMP), Mr Joe Onyejekwe, an engineer said the project would be sited in some select food producing corridors of the state.
ibo: Onye nchịkọta ọchịchị nke Anambra Rural Access and Agricultural Marketing Project (RAAMP), Maazị Joe Onyejekwe, onye injinia kwuru na a ga-arụ ọrụ ahụ n'ụfọdụ obodo na-akọpụta nri na steeti ahụ.

en: According to him diligent decisions were reached to site the projects within these food producing belts of the state -- Ayamelum, Anambra East, Anambra West, Oyi, Dunukofia, Awka North, Awka, South, Orumba North, Orumba South, Aguata, Ihiala, Ogbaru, Idemili South and Anaocha.
ibo: Dịka o siri kwuo, mkpebi siri ike ka e wepụtara iji rụ ọrụ ndị a n'ime obodo ndị na-emepụta nri na steeti - Ayamelum, Anambra East, Anambra West, Oyi, Dunukofia, Awka North, Awka South, Orumba North, Orumba South, Aguata, Ihiala, Ogbaru, Idemili South na Anaocha.

en: He said the projects were originally conceived by the Federal Government, when it was established that the country was steadily losing 9.8 Billion dollars annually in post harvest losses.
ibo: Ọ sịrị na gọọmentị etiti bụ ndị mbụ chepụtara ọrụ ndị ahụ, mgbe mba ahụ na-emefu ihe ruru ijeri dọla 9.8 kwa afọ.

en: The commissioner said this when the Association of Ndi Anambra residing in Madrid, Spain paid her courtesy visit in her office at the Jerome Udoji Secretariat Complex, Awka.
ibo: Kọmịshọna ahụ kwuru nke a mgbe ndị otu Ndị Anambra bi na Madrid, Spain bịara nleta dị mma n'ọfịs ya na Jerome Udoji Secretariat Complex, Awka.

en: This stemmed from the inability of the food producing areas to readily access the markets to evacuate their harvests.
ibo: Nke a sitere na enweghi ike mpaghara na-emepụta nri iji ruo ahịa ngwa ngwa na repụ ihe ubi ha.

en: He said that the FG, then, opened up discussions with two major funding agencies -- the World Bank and the African Development based in Abidjan.
ibo: O kwuru na FG, mgbe ahụ, mepere mkparịta ụka ya na nnukwu ụlọ ọrụ nkwado abụọ- World Bank na African Development dị n'Abidjan.

en: Onyejekwe, a Senior Special Assistant (SSA) to the Governor on Works, noted that it was the bid to overcome this anomaly that the FG then, projected to execute the jobs in 18 states.
ibo: Onyejekwe, onye nnukwu enyemaka pụrụiche (SSA) nye Gọvanọ n'Ọrụ, kwuru na ọ bụ iji merie ọgbaghara a ka FG mgbe ahụ, chọrọ ịrụ ọrụ ahụ na steeti iri na asatọ.

en: He said that it was resolved that five states -- Anambra, Borno, Benue, Taraba and Cross River States would be financed by African Development Bank and the rest to be financed by the World Bank.
ibo: O kwuru na e kpebiri na steeti ise- Anambra, Borno, Benue, Taraba na Cross River Steeti ga-enweta nkwado site n'aka African Development Bank ebe ndị ọzọ ga-enweta ego site n'aka Ụlọakụ Mba Ụwa.

en: The ADB has since accepted to bankroll the projects, promising each of the five states 50 million dollars.
ibo: Ndị ADB anabatara ịkwado ọrụ ndị a, na-ekwe nkwa na steeti ise ga-enweta nde dọla iri ise n'otu n'otu.

en: Their officials have made two major visits to Anambra State, during which they have interacted with people from the concerned communities.
ibo: Ndị isi ha emeela njem nleta abụọ n'Anambra Steeti, oge ha na ndị mmadụ sitere na mpaghara ndị ahụ kpakọrịtara.

en: They have all mutually agreed to work together toward successful realisation of the projects.
ibo: 'Ha niile ekwekọrịtala ịrụkọ ọrụ ọnụ iji rụpụta ihe ọma n'ọrụ a.

en: Onyejekwe, said that project, which aims primarily at building all-season farm roads would have complementing infrastructure and facilities like building of markets, Veterinary clinics, cottage industries, Road Safety Service centres, Storage facilities.
ibo: Onyejekwe kwuru na ọrụ ngo ndị a bụ iji rụọ ụzọ gara ugbo nke ga-enwe akụrụngwa dịka ụlọ ebe a na-ere ahịa, ụlọ ebe a na-ere ọgwụ anụmanụ, ebe ọrụ nchekwa okporo ụzọ na ihe e ji echekwa ihe.

en: The benefitting communities benefiting communities would be trained on road maintenance and partnership with the private sector for provision of transport for evacuation of farm produce.
ibo: A ga-azụta obodo ndị ahụ na-erite uru na njikwa okporo ụzọ na mmekorita ya na otu mmadụ nwe maka inye aka ụgbọ njem maka ibupụ ihe ubi.

en: The job would also entail resettlement of people, who might be displaced in the process for project delivery.
ibo: Ọrụ ahụ ga-edubatakwa ndozi ndị mmadụ, ndị nwere ike ịbụ ndị a chụpụrụ n'usoro maka ịnye ọrụ.

en: He confirmed that Anambra State Government had demonstrated commitment by striving to meet all the local requirements to access the funding for the project.
ibo: O kwenyere na Gọọmentị Anambra gosipụtara nkwenye site n'ịgbalịsi ike imezu ihe niile dị na mpaghara iji nweta ego maka ọrụ ahụ.

en: Since conditions require that all participating states will provide 8 per cent of the counterpart funding, the state has since committed to this.
ibo: Ebe ọnọdụ chọrọ ka steeti niile sonyere ga-eweta pasenti 8 nke ego mbụbata, steeti enyefeelarịị nke a.

en: Indeed, the funding that has so far been utilised by Anambra to carry out its impact assessment studies and other relevant exercises considered important to assessing the project have come from the state Government.
ibo: 'N’ezie, ego ndị Anambra tinyere n'ọrụ iji wee mụọ ọmụmụ ntule na ihe omume ndị ọzọ e chere na ha dị mkpa maka ịtụle ọrụ a sitere n’aka gọọmentị steeti.

en: Onyejekwe said that Anambra State Government had so far spent N80 million, all still within the 8 per cent of Anambra State share of the counterpart funding.
ibo: Onyejekwe kwuru na gọọmentị Anambra Steeti emefuola nde naịra iri asatọ, ihe niile ka dị na pasenti asatọ nke steeti Anambra ketara.

en: We expect another tranche of payment from Government to undertake another critical aspect of the job; this is the design and then full implementation of the project, when the funding must been assessed for full execution of the various jobs.
ibo: 'Anyị na-atụ anya na ịkwụ ụgwọ ọzọ sitere n'aka gọọmentị ga-arụ ọrụ ọzọ dị oke mkpa; nke a bụ atụmatụ ahụ na mmejupụta ọrụ ahụ n'ụzọ zuru ezu, mgbe a na-enyocha ego ahụ maka mmezu nke ọrụ dị iche iche.

en: I am confident that the project will soon get off to a start with all the enormous engineering works in full steam.
ibo: 'Obi siri m ike na ọrụ ngo a ga-amalite n'oge adịghị anya, ebe a ga-arụ ọtụtụ ọrụ injinia niile.

en: The job execution would guarantee jobs at all levels – the Bank and communities will be happy at the jobs.
ibo: Ndị na-enye ọrụ ga-enye ọrụ n'ọnọdụ ọbụla- ụlọakụ ahụ na ndị obodo ga-enwe obi ụtọ n'ọrụ ndị ahụ.

en: Its going to be a win on win situation for all'.
ibo: 'Ọ ga-abụ ọnọdụ mmeri maka mmadụ niile'.

en: DOZZY FOUNDATION ENROLLS 1,500 PERSONS INTO ANAMBRA HEALTH INSURANCE SCHEME
ibo: DOZZY FOUNDATION EDEBANYELA MMADỤ OTU PUKU NA NARỊ ISE N'ANAMBRA HEALTH INSURANCE SCHEME

en: Dozzy Foundation, a subsidiary of Dozzy Group Nig. Ltd. , has enrolled no fewer than 1,500 Okija indigenes into Anambra State Health Insurance Scheme (ASHIA).
ibo: Dozzy Foundation, onye enyemaka nke Dozzy Group Nig. Ltd., edebanyela aha ụmụ amaala Okija opekata mpe mmadụ otu puku na narị ise n'Anambra State Health Insurance Scheme (ASHIA).

en: , has enrolled no fewer than 1,500 Okija indigenes into Anambra State Health Insurance Scheme (ASHIA).
ibo: Edebanyela aha ụmụ amaala Okija opekata mpe mmadụ otu puku na narị ise n'ime ngalaba Anambra State Health Insurance Scheme (ASHIA).

en: The enrollment took place at Okija General Hospital, where some top government officials, business moguls, traditional rulers, clergies and witnessed the event.
ibo: Ndenye aha a bụ nke e mere n'ụlọọgwụ Okija, ebe ụfọdụ ndị isi gọọmentị, ndị isi ahịa, ndị igwe, ndị ụkọchukwu bịara emume ahụ.

en: Gov. Willie Obiano of Anambra, who flagged off the exercise, was represented by his Deputy, Dr Nkem Okeke.
ibo: Gov. Willie Obiano nke Anambra, onye kwụpụrụ nke ahụ bụ osote ya, Dr Nkem Okeke nọchitere anya ya.

en: The governor said that the health insurance scheme was introduced to offer medical succour to the low income earners as well as those living in the rural areas of the state.
ibo: Gọvanọ ahụ kwuru na e webatara atụmatụ ahụike ahụ iji nyere ndị na-akpata obere ego yana ndị bi n'ime ime obodo nke steeti ahụ aka.

en: Obiano commended the Foundation for making free medical care available, noting that the scheme would enable the indigenes especially the elderly ones among them to visit the hospitals regularly.
ibo: Obiano toro ntọala/Foundation ahụ maka inye nlekọta ahụike n'efu, na-ekwupụta na atụmatụ a ga-enyere ụmụ amaala ahụ aka ọkachasị ndị agadi nọ n'etiti ha ije nleta n'ụlọọgwụ oge niile.

en: He said that the enrollees would pay little or no amount in medical bills as the exercise would help to eliminate the spread and use of fake drugs in the communities.
ibo: O kwuru na ndị debanyere aha ga-akwụ obere ụgwọ maọbụ ha agaghị akwụ ụgwọ n'ụgwọ ahụike dịka ihe ọmụmụ ahụ ga-enyere aka wepụ mgbasa na ịṅụ ọgwụ adịgboroja n'obodo.

en: We are here to extend the scheme to Okija through Dozzy Foundation,' he said.
ibo: O kwuru na 'Anyị nọ ebe a iji bulite atụmatụ a n'Okija site na Dozzy Foundation.'

en: The governor also inaugurated the upgraded Okija General Hospital by Dozzy Foundation.
ibo: Gọvanọ mepekwara ụlọọgwụ Okija nke Dozzy Foundation wulitere.

en: He thanked the Executive Chairman Dozzy Group, Dr Daniel Chukwudozie for the kind gesture.
ibo: O kelere onyeisi oche Dozzy Group, Dr Daniel Chukwudozie maka ezi ihe ahụ.

en: The governor, then, urged other well-to-do Ndi Anambra to emulate the group in bringing development to the state.
ibo: Gọvanọ ahụ rịọkwara ndị Anambra ọzọ ji ego ka ha ṅomie ndị otu ahụ n'iweta mmepe na steeti ahụ.

en: Executive Secretary ASHIA, Dr Simeon Onyemaechi, said Dozzy Foundation had taken the bull by the horn' in engaging 1,500 persons into the scheme.
ibo: Onye odeakwụkwọ ASHIA, Dọkịta Simeon Onyemaechi kwuru na Dozzy Foundation akpaala ike n'itinye mmadụ otu puku na narị ise n'atụmatụ ahụ.

en: We wish to commend them for understanding the need for functional health system,' Onyemaechi said.
ibo: 'Anyị chọrọ ịja ha mma maka ịghọta mkpa ụlọọrụ ahụike na-arụsi ọrụ ike dị,' Onyemaechi kwuru.

en: The ASHIA boss urged beneficiaries to ensure proper use of the opportunity.
ibo: Onyeisi ASHIA ahụ gbara ndị na-erite uru ume ka ha hụ na ha jiri ohere ahụ kpọrọ ihe.

en: Days of visiting quacks are over and the people of Okija can now access quality healthcare using their ASHIA cards,' Onyemaechi said.
ibo: 'Oge nleta adịgboroja a gaala aga, ndị Okija nwekwaa ike inweta ahụike dị mma n'iji kaadị ASHIA ha,' Onyemaechi kwuru.

en: He said that the foundation had taken care of financial aspect of the enrollees as N12, 000 annual fees per person had been paid for all 1,500 individuals.
ibo: O kwuru na ntọala ahụ elekọtara ihe banyere ego nke ndị debanyere aha ha dịka puku naịra iri na abụọ bụ ụgwọ onye ọbụla ga-akwụ n'afọ ụgwọ nke ọ kwụrụ maka mmadụ otu puku na narị ise niile.

en: Dr Onyemaechi also thanked Dozzy Foundation for spending millions of naira in renovating the Okija General Hospital, describing the act as philanthropy at its best'.
ibo: Dr Onyemaechi kelekwara Dozzy Foundation maka imefu nde kwuru nde naịra n'ịhazigharị ụlọọgwụ Okija, na-akọwa ihe ahụ dịka 'ọrụ ebube kacha mma'.

en: Anambra State Government is quite appreciative of the support from Dozzy group through its various interventions in Okija and environs,' he said.
ibo: O kwuru, 'Gọọmentị steeti Anambra na-ekele nkwado nke ndị otu Dozzy site n'enyemaka ya dị iche iche n'Okija na gburugburu ya,'

en: In an address, Executive Chairman Dozzy group, Dr Chukwudozie said the foundation had over the years embarked on programmes aimed at empowering the less privileged.
ibo: N’okwu a, onyeisi oche otu Dozzy, Dr Chukwudozie kwuru na ntọala ahụ amalitela kemgbe n'ihe omume a iji nyere ndị o nweghi ka ọ ha aka.

en: These includes, offering scholarship to indigent students and putting smiles on faces of the widows.
ibo: Ndị a gụnyere, inye ụmakwụkwọ enweghi ego agụmakwụkwọ n'efu na ime ka ihu ọchị waa ụmụnwaanyị ajadu.

en: He said that the Foundation had recognised inability of many people to pay their hospital bills.
